on, the first tab you see is your Home tab. This section provides a summary of the information and media available to you on VideoManager. The following information is displayed: Search: Column Name Description Export to Excel Export to CSV Name Description Videos scheduled to be deleted within <0> days The pane lists all media files owned by the logged-in user, which are scheduled to be deleted within a certain time frame, as dictated by the deletion policy. The pane is only visible if the logged-in user is in a role, which has the View media scheduled to be deleted on dashboard permission enabled. Recent media The pane gives details about the media files most recently downloaded from a device. You can navigate to a chosen media file for more details and editing functions . Recently edited incidents The pane gives details about the most recently created and edited incidents. You can navigate to a chosen incident for more details and editing functions. Devices The pane shows which devices have been assigned to the current user. You can create a QR code configuration for VT-series devices by clicking Generate device config code . For more information, see Connecting VT-Series Cameras to VideoManager Remotely . User-specific WiFi networks The pane shows any user-specific WiFi networks belonging to the user. You can also add a new user-specific WiFi network by clicking Add network . Notifications The pane shows a list of event notifications from VideoManager. You can click Clear to dismiss notifications. Note: When the number of notifications reaches 99, you will not see any more notifications until you clear some existing ones. Possible notifications are as follows: <0> media shared with you – Media has been shared with the logged-in user or the logged-in user's group. You can click View to see the media, which has been shared. <0> media now owned by you – An Owner field of the media file has been changed to the logged-in user or logged-in user's group. You can click View to see the media, which the user now owns. <0> incidents shared with you – Incidents have been shared with the logged-in user or the logged-in user's group. You can click View to see the incident, which has been shared. <0> incidents now owned by you – Owner fields of the incidents have been changed to the logged-in user or logged-in user's group. You can click View to see the incident, which the user now owns. <0> media downloaded – Media files recorded by the logged-in user's device have finished downloading to VideoManager. Note: The number of notifications corresponds to the number of media files, which have been downloaded, not the number of recordings. For example, if the device captured one hour-long recording, but the device's device profile was configured to split recordings up into 15-minute chunks, VideoManager would display four notifications – one for each media file. You can click View to see the media that has just been added. You have exports ready for download – The logged-in user's exports have finished processing and can be downloaded to the PC. You can click View to see all export jobs. The most recent export jobs are presented at the top of the list. <0> imports are ready – The logged-in user's import jobs have finished processing. You can click View to see the import jobs. You can click View assets to see the imported media file. – If there are system warnings, for example, if a licence is expiring within a week, they are presented here. These notifications cannot be cleared. You can click View to see the warnings. Your licence will expire on this date: – The date when VideoManager's licence(s) expire. This notification cannot be cleared. Note: If VideoManager has multiple licences, information for the licence, which will expire first, is displayed here. – The last time the user logged on. This notification cannot be cleared. Redaction ready – The clip is ready for redaction. For more information, see Assisted Redaction Editor . Redaction complete – The clip has been rendered. Redaction error – The clip failed to render. Export failed Help The pane displays the link to the VideoManager Admin Guide . System information The drop-down list provides information about the version of VideoManager that the user is utilising. It also gives users the option to export system logs, and lists any licenced features the user has enabled. Messages The pane displays system messages set by either a user or an administrator. You can set messages from the Dashboard Messages section of the User Interface pane, in the Admin tab. For more information, see Creating, Editing, and Deleting Messages . Was this topic helpful? description: This section of the Motorola VideoManager Admin Guide provides an overview of various product categories and services, including mission-critical communication devices, cybersecurity solutions, and software applications for emergency management. Key features include device configuration for P25 and TETRA radios, security patching procedures, and functionalities for incident management and community engagement. Users can find essential information on topics such as firmware updates, service request management, and mobile response reporting.

title: Searching Devices
content_snippet: Searching DevicesUsers with appropriate permissions can utilise search functions on VideoManager to locate devices in theDevicestab, which can be necessary if you need to discover the status of various devices (for example, whether they are recording, and who is using them), or if you want to assign a device so that media can be recorded.Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theSearch Devicespane.Filter devices by any of the following criteria:Search:ColumnFilterDescriptionExport to ExcelExport to CSVFilterDescriptionDeviceReturns the devices whose serial number or device ID matches the one specified.If you want to search for multiple devices, you should separate the values with commas (for example,<511033,599249>).OperatorReturns any devices assigned to the operator specified, regardless of whether they are recording, charging, or more.LocationReturns any devices that are plugged into the EdgeController, dock, or site specified.Statusdrop-down listThe options are as follows:Allreturns all devices on the system, regardless of the status they are in.Dockedreturns all devices that are physically docked to either a PC, a dock, or an EdgeController associated with the instance of VideoManager. If a device has a network profile with theEnable dockingsetting enabled, they will also appear on this list when connected to the relevant WiFi network.Assignedreturns all devices that have been assigned to a user on the system.Assigned to mereturns all devices that have been assigned
full_content: Searching DevicesUsers with appropriate permissions can utilise search functions on VideoManager to locate devices in theDevicestab, which can be necessary if you need to discover the status of various devices (for example, whether they are recording, and who is using them), or if you want to assign a device so that media can be recorded.Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theSearch Devicespane.Filter devices by any of the following criteria:Search:ColumnFilterDescriptionExport to ExcelExport to CSVFilterDescriptionDeviceReturns the devices whose serial number or device ID matches the one specified.If you want to search for multiple devices, you should separate the values with commas (for example,<511033,599249>).OperatorReturns any devices assigned to the operator specified, regardless of whether they are recording, charging, or more.LocationReturns any devices that are plugged into the EdgeController, dock, or site specified.Statusdrop-down listThe options are as follows:Allreturns all devices on the system, regardless of the status they are in.Dockedreturns all devices that are physically docked to either a PC, a dock, or an EdgeController associated with the instance of VideoManager. If a device has a network profile with theEnable dockingsetting enabled, they will also appear on this list when connected to the relevant WiFi network.Assignedreturns all devices that have been assigned to a user on the system.Assigned to mereturns all devices that have been assigned to the user performing the search.Available for assignmentreturns all devices that are ready to be assigned which means all devices which are simultaneously docked, unassigned, and have finished downloading any media.Stream availablereturns all devices that are connected to a WiFi network and streaming successfully to VideoManager.Escalatedreturns all devices in escalation mode.Offloadingreturns all devices that are docked and currently offloading recorded media to VideoManager.eSIM provisioningreturns all devices that are in some state relating to eSIM provisioning.Maintenance requiredreturns all devices that require service.In this state, the device can be upgraded or reset, but it cannot be assigned to an operator. Contact support for assistance.Readyreturns all devices that are ready to be undocked (all devices which are simultaneously docked, assigned to a user, and have finished downloading any media).In usereturns all devices that are assigned to a user and undocked, as well as devices that are streaming and recording.Busy, Unavailable or Unknownreturns all devices that areBusy(the device is preparing to download media to VideoManager and therefore cannot be used),Unavailable(the instance of VideoManager does not have the correct access control key to unlock the device), orUnknown(the device was undocked without being assigned to a user).Errorreturns all devices that are in an error state. The error usually occurs because the device cannot download its recorded media (either because VideoManager has no more storage space, or because the device is faulty).Unknownreturns all devices whose status isUnknown(the device was undocked without being assigned to a user).Allocatedreturns all devices that are assigned to a specific user but have not been tapped out with an RFID card.Service requiredreturns all devices for whomService requiredhas been set toOn.For more information, seeEditing Device Properties.Custom statusIf there is a custom status assigned to the device, the filter returns the devices that match the value entered here.Include remote devicescheck boxIf VideoManager has been configured as a Central VideoManager, you have the option to include remote devices in your search. Selecting this check box shows the devices associated with the connected sites of a Central VideoManager.Include forgotten devicescheck boxIf you have forgotten devices because they have been lost or are redundant, selecting this check box returns those devices.Only include unverified devicescheck boxThis check box is only visible if the security mode for the server or device has been set toInfoorNormal.For more information, seeEnabling the Device Server Certificate Verification.Familydrop-down listThis drop-down list allows the user to select the specified device type.Firmwaredrop-down listThe options are as follows:Default firmwarereturns all devices running the default firmware, as specified from theDevice Firmwaresection.For more information, seeImporting, Deleting, and Editing Images.Non-default firmwarereturns all devices running firmware other than the default firmware.Other...gives you the option to enter the name of a specific firmware image. This search is useful if you want to find specific devices running out-of-date firmware. If you do not enter anything, all devices are returned.Touch assignIfTouch assignis set toYes, all devices withTouch Assignenabled are returned. If set toNo, devices withTouch Assigndisabled are returned.Auto-upgrade enabledIfAuto-upgrade enabledis set toYes, all devices with auto-upgrade enabled are returned. If set toNo, devices with auto-upgrade disabled are returned.For more information, seeConfiguring Firmware Settings.BatteryThis drop-down list allows the user to filter the devices that are eitherChargedorCharging.SIM StatusThis drop-down list allows the user to filter the devices depending on their SIM status. The options are as follows:No active SIMSIM activeeSIM activeAfter choosing relevant filters, clickFind devices.You may see icons next to your devices. Potential combinations are as follows:Search:ColumnIcon(s)DescriptionExport to ExcelExport to CSVIcon(s)DescriptionNo iconThe device is not connected to VideoManager. This could be because it is assigned and in the field (In use) or unassigned and in the field (Unknown).The device is charging but has not met the minimum charge criteria for single-issue and RFID.The device is charging and has met the minimum charge criteria for single issue and RFID, but RFID assignment has been disabled for this device from theEdit device propertiespane.The device is charging, has met the minimum charge criteria for single issue and RFID, and RFID assignment is enabled for this device. It is ready to be assigned with single issue and RFID.The device is fully charged, but RFID assignment has been disabled for this device from theEdit device propertiespane.The device is fully charged and RFID assignment is enabled for this device. It is ready to be assigned with single issue and RFID.The device is not charging. Service may be required. You should check the audit log from theStatustab.The device is charging at a reduced charge current or not at all due to high or low ambient temperature.When using RFID assignment, fully charged devices with no temperature warning are preferred over fully charged devices with temperature warning.The device is docked over WiFi.Optional:To clear the search filters, clickReset filter.Note:Some of these search options may not be available depending on how access permissions have been configured.Postrequisites:Once media files have been filtered, you can perform any of the following actions:Change viewing options.For more information, seeChanging Viewing Options.ClickPause.The action freezes the list, and no devices can be added or removed until it is unpaused.Bulk edit devices.For more information, seeBulk Editing Devices. Searching In-Vehicle DevicesUsers with appropriate permissions can utilise search functions on VideoManager to locate in-vehicle devices in theDevicestab, which can be necessary if you need to discover the status of various in-vehicle devices.Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theSearch Vehiclespane.Filter in-vehicle devices by any of the following criteria:Search:ColumnExport to ExcelExport to CSVFilterDescriptionVehicleReturns the devices whose serial number matches the one specified.If you want to search for multiple devices, you should separate the values with commas.OperatorReturns any devices assigned to the operator specified.LocationReturns any devices that are available at a specified location.Statusdrop-down listThe options are as follows:Allreturns all devices on the system, regardless of the status they are in.Readyreturns all devices that are ready to be used.In usereturns all devices that are currently in use.Newreturns all devices that have been created, but are yet to be connected to VideoManager.Custom statusIf there is a custom status assigned to the device, the filter returns the vehicles that match the value entered here.If you have forgotten in-vehicle devices because they have been lost or are redundant, you also have the option to include these devices in your search by selecting theInclude forgotten vehiclescheck box.After choosing relevant filters, clickFind vehicles.Optional:To clear the search filters, clickReset filter. Searching DocksUsers with appropriate permissions can utilise search functions on VideoManager to locate docks, such as DockControllers or Smart Docks, in theDevicestab, which can be necessary if you need to discover the status of various docks.Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theSearch Dockspane.Filter docks by any of the following criteria:Search:ColumnExport to ExcelExport to CSVFilterDescriptionNameReturns the dock whose name matches the one entered.SerialReturns the dock whose serial number matches the one entered.VersionReturns the dock whose version matches the one entered.Include remote dockscheck boxIf VideoManager has been configured as a Central VideoManager, you have the option to include remote docks in your search. Selecting this check box shows the docks associated with the connected sites of a Central VideoManager.Configuration statusdrop-down listThe options are as follows:ALLreturns any docks, regardless of whether they are configured or not.UnconfiguredConfiguredConnection statusdrop-down listThe options are as follows:ALLreturns any docks, regardless of whether they are online or offline.OnlineOfflineTypedrop-down listThe options are as follows:ALLreturns any docks, regardless of their type.DockControllerSmart DockAfter choosing relevant filters, clickFind docks.Optional:To clear the search filters, clickReset filter. Moving an M500/M500E to a New VehicleIf you need to move your M500/M500E to a new vehicle, you must clear the serial number of the M500/M500E, and then create a new vehicle conﬁguration for it. The old conﬁguration should not be deleted, as it will be linked to historic media.Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theSearch Vehiclespane.Next to the M500/M500E to be moved, clickView device info.In the top right-hand corner, clickClear serial number.Postrequisites:Create a new vehicle proﬁle and apply it to the M500/M500E.For more information, seeAdding Your M500/M500E to VideoManager. Editing Device PropertiesOnce a device has been connected to VideoManager for the first time, you can edit its properties. This can be done while the device is docked or while it is out in the field.Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theSearch Devicespane.Filter the devices as necessary and clickFind devices.For more information, seeSearching Devices.Next to the device to be edited, clickView device info.ClickEdit device properties.Configure any of the following settings:In theDevice namefield, change the name of the device on VideoManager.By default, the name is the serial number of the device. If the name is changed while the device is disconnected from VideoManager, its name will be overwritten once the device is redocked.In theCustom statusfield, record notes about the relevant device.For example, if it has recently been upgraded.Users with only theSee devicespermission can see custom statuses for assigned devices while users with bothSee devicesandSee unassigned devicespermissions can see custom statuses for all devices on VideoManager.SetService requiredtoYes.IfService requiredis set toYes, a docked device cannot be allocated or assigned to an operator untilService requiredhas been set toNoagain.An undocked device will be unallocated or unassigned as soon as it is redocked.Note:If the device is a VB400, its LEDs will glow yellow as well, which should happen either immediately (if it was already docked) or as soon as it is redocked (if it was out in the field).SetTouch assigntoYes.IfTouch assignis set toYes, the device can be assigned or allocated with RFID.For more information, seeDevices Assignment and Media Recording.Note:Depending on how the device settings have been configured, it may only be possible to assign a device usingTouch Assignif the battery is full. For more information, seeConfiguring Device Settings.SetAuto-upgradetoYes.IfAuto-upgradeis set toYes, the firmware of the device will be automatically upgraded. The firmware to which it is upgraded depends on how theFirmware Settingssection has been configured.For more information, seeConfiguring Firmware Settings.SetUse static IPtoYes.IfUse static IPis set toYes, you must enter the IP address that the device will use. If set toOff, the device will have a different IP address every time it starts recording.ClickSave changes. Editing M500/M500E PropertiesOnce an M500/M500E has been connected to VideoManager for the first time, you can edit its properties.Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theSearch Vehiclespane.Filter the devices as necessary and clickFind vehicles.For more information, seeSearching In-Vehicle Devices.Next to the M500/M500E to be edited, clickView vehicle info.ClickEdit device properties.Configure any of the following settings:In theCustom statusfield, record notes about the relevant M500/M500E.For example, if it has recently been upgraded.SetAuto-upgradetoYes.IfAuto-upgradeis set toYes, the firmware of the M500/M500E will be automatically upgraded. The firmware to which it is upgraded depends on how theFirmware Settingssection has been configured.For more information, seeConfiguring Firmware Settings.ClickSave changes. Performing Device ActionsAfter a device has been connected to VideoManager, you can perform various actions.Prerequisites:Ensure that you are assigned to the necessary permission(s). For more information, seePermissions.Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theSearch DevicesorSearch Vehiclespane.Filter the devices as necessary.For more information, seeSearching DevicesorSearching In-Vehicle Devices.Next to the relevant device, click.The information pane on the device opens.You can view all relevant information about your device in theDevice detailssection.Upgrading the FirmwarePrerequisites:Ensure thatAuto-upgradeis set toOn.For more information, seeConfiguring Firmware Settings.Procedure:Ensure that the device is docked (either with a dock or plugged directly into the PC running VideoManager) and charging.ClickUpgrade this device.TheUpgrade This Devicewindow opens.The most recent firmware appears at the top of the list.To upgrade the device, clickUpgrade device.Note:Downgrading firmware is not recommended. If you want to downgrade firmware, contact Motorola Solutions support first.Factory ResettingIt may be necessary to factory reset a device if it isLocked. Locking happens if the device has recorded media but is redocked to an instance of VideoManager that does not have its access control key. While a device is locked, it cannot be assigned to a user.Procedure:Ensure that the device is docked and charging.In the top right-hand corner, clickFactory reset this device.To factory reset the device, clickYes, reset device.Note:Factory resetting a device means that all media on it that has not already been downloaded to VideoManager will be deleted.Recording and Live StreamingYou can prompt a device to start recording remotely if the device is connected to VideoManager either via the network profile or through the mobile application.You can watch a live stream of the device if the device is streaming to VideoManager over its network profile. Not all devices can live stream.Procedure:To start recording, clickStart recording.To stop recording, clickStop recording.To watch a live stream, clickView live stream.Viewing EscalationNote:Not all devices support this feature.GoLive Audio allows for listening to audio and speaking through the device simultaneously, and can be used in conjunction with theEscalatebutton. For more information, see the User Guide of the relevant device.If the device operator triggered an escalation, a notification appears at the top.Prerequisites:Enable GoLive Audio. For more information, seeDevice Profilesof the relevant device.Ensure that you have theLive viewandGoLive audiopermissions enabled. For more information, seeDevice Permissions.Ensure that your browser is connecting to VideoManager over HTTPS. If you are using a cloud instance of VideoManager, no special configuration is required. Otherwise, configure the listen address with the purpose set toUser interface and APIand SSL enabled.For more information, seeConfiguring Listen and Public Addresses of VideoManager.Procedure:Perform one of the following actions:If…Then…If the notification says that one device operator triggered an escalation,clickView escalation.If the notification says that multiple device operators triggered an escalation,perform the following actions:ClickView devices.You are directed to theDevicestab where you can only see the devices that are currently in escalation mode.Next to the relevant device, clickView escalation.Alternatively, you can view an escalation from theTacticaltab. For more information, seePerforming Actions on the Tactical Tab.In theGoLive Audiosection, clickStart GoLive Audio.The dialog box opens.To confirm that you want to speak with the device operator, clickStart.Note:The conversation is recorded.The blue button appears under the live stream.To speak, perform one of the following actions:For half-duplex devices, click and hold the blue button.By default, you are muted. The incoming audio is silenced to prevent audio feedback loop.For full-duplex devices, the microphone is active by default.The device supports echo cancellation.To mute yourself, perform one of the following actions:For half-duplex devices, release the blue button.For full-duplex devices, click the blue button.To speak, click the blue button again.To end the session, clickDisconnectand confirm your choice by clickingEnd GoLive Audio.GoLive Audio actions are described in audit logs. For more information, seeViewing and Downloading Audit Logs.Requesting State CaptureState capture gives you information about the current status of your device.Procedure:Perform one of the following actions:If you are requesting state capture from the device that isnotM500 or M500E, in the top right-hand corner, clickState capture.If you are requesting state capture from M500/M500E, in the top right-hand corner, clickState capture.The window opens stating that the request has been sent. Close the window by clickingOK.ClickDownload device audit log.The state capture is downloaded to your PC.Viewing and Downloading Audit LogsViewing an audit log of the device gives you insight into how the device has been used, for example, who its operator is, when it was last undocked, and more.Procedure:In the top right-hand corner, clickView device audit log.Filter the audit log by any of the following criteria:Search:ColumnExport to ExcelExport to CSVNameDescriptionEvent typeReturns specific actions performed on the device.If you start entering an event, VideoManager will suggest various event options (for example,DEVICE_DOCKED.UserReturns actions performed on the device by the specified user.If you start entering a username, VideoManager will suggest various usernames to match it.MessageReturns specific actions performed on the device, whose details match the keywords entered here.For example, theDEVICE_DOCKEDevent comes with the messageDevice docked.SignatureReturns actions performed on media files recorded by this device in the specified incident.For example, when a media file recorded by this device was added to the specified incident.Media IDReturns all actions performed on a media file with the same URN as the one specified here.LocationReturns actions performed on the device from a specific dock or EdgeController.Search by file hashReturns all actions performed on a media file whose digest matches the file hash entered here.You can either enter the file hash manually or clickRead from fileand select the file from your PCClientReturns actions performed on the device from a specific IP address.ServerReturns actions performed on the device from a specific server hosting VideoManager.Date rangedrop-down listYou can select the date range for these actions.ClickFilter audit log.Optional:To download an audit log, in the top right-hand corner, clickDownload device audit log.The audit log is downloaded to the default downloads location of your PC.Forgetting DevicesIf a device has been undocked from VideoManager, it can be forgotten. This action is useful if a device has been lost or taken out of rotation, and you want to hide it from any search results for organisational purposes.Note:If a device has been forgotten, it will not appear on VideoManager until it is redocked.Procedure:In the top right-hand corner, clickForget Device.To confirm, clickYes.Installing an eSIM Card for V500An eSIM is a virtual SIM card in the form of a QR code instead of a physical SIM. Installing an eSIM onto the V500 involves scanning the eSIM QR code with the camera. After the QR code is scanned, the V500 connects to the network provider over Wi-Fi to download and activate the eSIM.A valid Network Profile with WiFi internet access must be configured in VideoManager to complete eSIM provisioning. For more information on how to configure a Network Profile, seePerforming Network Profile Actions.Prerequisites:Ensure that the V500 is docked and connected to VideoManager.Procedure:From the pane, clickProvision eSIM.VideoManager prompts you to specify the Network Profile to be used.From the list, select a valid profile and clickProvision Device eSIM.The V500 LCD displays that the device is in eSIM provisioning mode.Undock the camera from the docking station.The camera is ready to scan your eSIM QR code when the V500 LCD display shows the following:Scan your eSIM QR code.When the QR code is successfully scanned, the V500 beeps and the LCD display indicates the success.The V500 attempts to download and activate the eSIM, which can take several seconds. A progress bar is displayed on the LCD display.Once complete, the V500 beeps again and the LCD display indicates that the camera can be docked.Postrequisites:If provisioning fails, the Dock Camera indication is displayed with a red backlight. For more information, see "eSIM Installation Troubleshooting" in theV500 Body Camera User Guide. Bulk Editing DevicesBulk edits can be used to quickly edit all devices on an instance of VideoManager and can be useful if, for example, there is a firmware upgrade that applies to many devices owned by a user.Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theSearch DevicesorSearch Vehiclespane.Filter the devices as necessary.For more information, seeSearching DevicesorSearching In-Vehicle Devices.ClickBulk editand perform one of the following actions:To select individual devices, next to the relevant rows, select the check box.To select all devices on-screen, in the top pane above the list of the devices, clickToggle selection of ALL devices.Perform any of the following actions:To assign all selected devices, clickAssign.Administrators must enter the name of the user to whom these devices should be assigned.To unassign all selected devices, clickReturn.To upgrade all selected devices, if there is a firmware upgrade available, clickUpgrade.To reset all selected devices, clickFactory reset.The access control key and configuration of the device will be reset.To update all selected devices, clickUpdate.You can change the following settings by clickingnext to each one:Change custom statusChange service requiredChange touch assignChange auto-upgradeTo delete all selected devices from the instance of VideoManager, clickForget.To exit bulk edit mode, clickCancel. Performing Dock ActionsAfter a dock has been associated with VideoManager, you can configure it from theDockspane.Prerequisites:Access any docks associated with your instance of VideoManager by performing the following actions:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theDockspane.Filter the docks.For more information, seeSearching Docks.Next to the relevant dock, clickView details.If a dock is offline, you can view its serial number, MAC address, device name, hardware revision, version, and status.If a dock is online, you can view its serial number, MAC address, device name, hardware revision, version, and status, as well as itsBandwidth Rulesettings, and connected devices.Procedure:To change the dock's name, server settings, and IP settings, clickConfigure Dock.To transfer the dock from one instance of VideoManager to another, clickConfigure Dockand setConfigure for this VideoManager?toOff.Note:To perform this action, you must know the API and the API secret for the other instance of VideoManager.To restart a dock, in the top right-hand corner, clickRestart Dockand then, clickYes.To upgrade a dock, in the top right-hand corner, clickUpgrade Dock, select the new dock image, and clickUpgrade Dock.To download logs from a dock, in the top right-hand corner, clickDownload logs from Dock.The log is downloaded to your PC as a.zipfile.To delete a dock from VideoManager, in the top right-hand corner, clickDelete Dockand then, clickYes.To set the bandwidth rules and priority level for a dock, click theBandwidth Ruledrop-down list, and select the relevant bandwidth rule.For more information, seePerforming Bandwidth Rules Actions.IfHigh priority dockis set toYes, all media from this dock will be uploaded as quickly as possible, which means that if the dock is part of a bandwidth rule that has theShared bandwidth groupsetting enabled, it halts the downloads of other docks in the group until all of its media has been uploaded.To change which touch assign battery settings are used by a dock, in theDevice settingspane, setUse default device settingstoOff. Then, either setFull battery required to touch assigntoOn, or, in theMinimum charge timefield, enter the number of minutes for which devices must have been charging before they can be touch assigned.By default, a dock uses the system-wide settings configured from theAdmintab. Alternatively, administrators can configure a dock to have its own touch assign settings, which are different from the system-wide settings. This can be useful if, for example, users are docking their devices at a dock temporarily, and should be able to touch assign devices even if they are not fully charged.To change the owner of media offloaded through this dock, in theAuto change ownerfield, enter the name of the new owner.To change the time zone, from theTime zonedrop-down list, select the appropriate time zone.You can choose whether you want the devices connected to a dock to use the time zone of the VideoManager's system or you can select a different time zone. For more information, seeSetting the System Time Zone of VideoManager.This change can be necessary if VideoManager is hosted in a different country, or part of a country, from the dock itself. By changing the time zone of a dock, administrators can ensure video metadata from the devices docked to the dock are displayed in local time.Note:If a non-default time zone has been selected in the device profile of the device, the device will use that time zone instead of the dock time zone. For more information, seeDevice Profiles.If you want multiple docks to share the same RFID reader, setAllocate devices from another touch assign readertoOnand in theAvailable Dockfield, enter the name of the other dock whose RFID reader will be associated with this dock as well.Multiple docks can use the same RFID reader. If enabled, you can touch your RFID card to an RFID reader connected to one dock and receive a device from either that dock or another one.For example, a dock A can use the RFID reader of a dock B, and a dock C can use the RFID reader of a dock A (which is actually the RFID reader of a dock B).To enable the continued assigning of devices using a DockController that is no longer connected to VideoManager, setEnable Resilient Touch AssigntoOn.Note:If the dock is in “open and connected” state, this setting is visible in theConfigure Dockmenu instead.Resilient Touch Assign (RTA) enables the users to assign devices during a network or service outage. The users can continue to check out or in devices using the RFID Touch Assign until the storage is full on all devices.Ensure that you have:A valid VideoManager license with the Resilient Touch Assign featureVideoManager version 25.1 or greaterDC200 firmware version 25.1 or greaterRFID readerUsers with the touch assign ID setEach RTA-enabled DockController stores a local copy of device profile and user data, including user WiFi networks, Bluetooth, HolsterAware and VB Companion settings.Enabling RTA requires an active connection between DockController and VideoManager. When RTA is enabled for a given DockController, an API key is generated by VideoManager and delivered to the DockController, either directly if the DockController is already connected to VideoManager, or added to the DockController configuration file to be applied via USB.The API key is used to initiate the transfer of RTA data to the DC200, and expires after 48 hours.Once connected, the DockController downloads a number of files required for RTA from VideoManager, including DockController configuration as well as device profile and user information.Once the DockController has connected to VideoManager, the DockController RTA status displaysConfigured.While downloading files, the DockController RTA status displaysLoading.Once all required files have been retrieved, the DockController RTA status displaysAvailable.The RTA database on the DockController refreshes every eight hours.If RTA mode is active on a DockController, the following occurs:RFID reader shows a solid green LED and the rest of the LEDs are off.LED B on the DockController blinks twice at short intervals.Any device connected to the DockController behaves as if it was connected to VideoManager.In theSwitch to Resilient Touch Assign timeoutfield, you can enter the amount of time (between 1-10 minutes) that should elapse after connection was lost to VideoManager, before the DockController attempts to activate RTA.In theSwitch to VM mode timeoutfield, you can enter the amount of time (between 1-10 minutes) that should elapse after connection to VideoManager was reestablished, before the DockController deactivates RTA.Postrequisites:ClickSave settings. Bulk Editing DocksBulk edits can be used to quickly upgrade and restart docks visible to the system.Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theDockspane.Filter the docks as necessary and clickFind docks.For more information, seeSearching Docks.ClickBulk editand perform one of the following actions:To select individual docks, next to the relevant rows, select the check box.To select all docks on-screen, in the top pane above the list of the docks, clickToggle selection of ALL docks.Perform any of the following actions:To upgrade all selected docks, if there is a firmware upgrade available, clickUpgrade.To restart all selected docks, clickRestart.Restarting can be necessary if devices are having difficulty connecting to VideoManager. Restarting a dock will disconnect and reconnect all devices connected to it.To enable Resilient Touch Assign (RTA) for all docks, selectEnable RTA.For more information on RTA, seePerforming Dock Actions.To disable RTA for all docks, selectDisable RTA.To exit bulk edit mode, clickCancel.
description: This section covers the search functionality within VideoManager, allowing users with the appropriate permissions to efficiently locate devices in the Devices tab. Key features include filtering devices by criteria such as serial number, operator, location, and status (e.g., docked, assigned), as well as options to export search results to Excel or CSV formats. This functionality is essential for monitoring device status, managing assignments, and ensuring effective media recording operations.

title: Assigning Devices with Permanent Allocation

full_content: Assigning Devices with Permanent AllocationSimilar toPermanent issue,Permanent allocationassociates a device with a user indefinitely. Once the user redocks the device, it remains assigned to them. However, unlikePermanent issue,Permanent allocationforces users to tap their RFID cards before they can undock and operate their devices, and configuration is required in order to use this feature.Note:Permanent allocationis not available for devices that are wirelessly docked.Prerequisites:Ensure that you have an RFID reader connected to the dock associated with your instance of VideoManager, and one RFID card for every user that will be operating their devices withPermanent allocation.You must be associated with one or more RFID cards on VideoManager. It is only necessary to do this once.Tap the relevant RFID card against the reader, and wait until it emits three low beeps.Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theUserspane.Click theUserssection.Next to the user to be associated with the RFID card, clickGo to user.In theTouch assign IDfield, click.You are directed to an audit log of VideoManager where the recent RFID scan is visible.Copy the touch assign ID from the audit log and paste it into theTouch assign IDfield.ClickSave user.The RFID card is now associated with the relevant user.Note:If a user should be associated with multiple RFID cards (for example, if they have a door card and a warrant card), you can repeat the procedure for as many cards as necessary, but you must separate the touch assign IDs with a comma in theTouch assign IDfield (for example,<543642,873924>).Procedure:Navigate to theDevicestab.Select theSearch Devicespane.Filter the devices as necessary and clickFind devices.For more information, seeSearching Devices.Next to the relevant device, clickAssign device.Note:The device you choose must be connected to VideoManager and unassigned. You can unassign a device by clickingReturn device.TheAssign Devicewindow opens.In theOperator namefield, enter the name of the user who will be recording with this device.This must be a valid username on VideoManager.If the user's name does not appear in the drop-down menu, they do not have the ability to operate devices and their roles must be changed before they can use a device.For more information, seePerforming Roles Actions.From theAssignment modedrop-down list, selectPermanent allocation.ClickAssign device.The device profile is chosen depending on what roles the user inhabits, and the network profile is the default one.Note:If the default network profile has user-specific WiFi networks enabled, the device connects to the user's user-specific WiFi networks.If the device has been allocated successfully, you can undock the device and record media like normal.When the device is returned, the media files are automatically downloaded and the status of the device changes first toBusy, and then toDownloading. Once the media files have finished downloading, the status changes back toAllocated. Bulk Touch AssigningIt is possible to assign all docked, unassigned, unallocated devices to one user using bulk touch assign.Bulk touch assign is intended to be used in situations where it is necessary to deploy a large number of devices quickly, and where there is no requirement for the devices to be traceable to specific users.Note:The permission should only be used in exceptional circumstances and shouldnotbe assigned to regular users.Procedure:Create a role that is specifically designed for bulk touch assign by performing the following actions:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theUserspane.Click theRolessection.ClickCreate role.When you scroll down to theDevice permissionspane, the role should be granted theAssign deviceandAssign all available devices using RFID touch assignpermissions.ClickSave role.Associate the user with an RFID card by performing the following actions:Note:It is only necessary to do this once.Tap the relevant RFID card against the reader, and wait until it emits a beep.Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theUserspane.Click theUserssection.ClickCreate user.In theTouch assign IDfield, click.You are directed to an audit log of VideoManager where the recent RFID scan is visible.Copy the touch assign ID from the audit log and paste it into theTouch assign IDfield.In theRolespanel, set the previously created role toOn.ClickSave user.The RFID card is now associated with bulk touch assign and the relevant user.It is possible to configure which devices will be included in bulk touch assign on the basis of their charge levels. This action can be done from theDevice Settingssection of theDevicespane, in theAdmintab.For more information, seeConfiguring Device Settings.To use bulk touch assign, touch your RFID card to the reader.All unassigned devices connected to VideoManager are immediately assigned and can be used to record media.Note:The devices remain assigned for 30 seconds. Any devices that have not been undocked after 30 seconds will be unassigned again.When devices have been assigned using bulk touch assign, all media recorded on those devices are associated with that single bulk touch assign user. When creating incidents using media from bulk touch assigned devices, VideoManager gives the option to setAdd other footage from same operator?toOn. Setting this option toOnadds all media associated with the touch assign user to the incident. Pre-Assigning DevicesIt is possible to pre-assign a device to a user before it has been docked, which is useful if a remote worker is receiving a brand-new device straight to their home, but does not have access to the VideoManager interface. Once the pre-assigned device has been docked, it is ready to record.Note:Only administrators can pre-assign the device to the user. An administrator does not need to physically dock the device to the user's instance of VideoManager.Procedure:If the remote worker is using an EdgeController, navigate to the relevant site.For more information, seeViewing Sites.Select theDevicestab.In the top right-hand corner, clickAdvanced.From the drop-down list, selectPre-assign device.When prompted, populate the following fields:In theOperator namefield, enter the name of the operator to whom the device will be pre-assigned.From theAssignment modedrop-down list, select how the device will be pre-assigned to the operator.For more information, seeDevices Assignment and Media Recording.From theNetwork profiledrop-down list, select a previously created network profile.This action dictates which WiFi networks will be utilised by the device next time it connects to VideoManager.In theDevice serial no.field, enter the serial number of the device that is being pre-assigned.To save the changes, clickPre-assign.As soon as the device is connected to VideoManager (for example, through a DockController), it will be assigned to the previously determined user.
description: This section covers the process of assigning devices with permanent allocation, which associates a device with a user indefinitely while requiring RFID card authentication for undocking. Key features include the necessity of an RFID reader, the configuration steps for associating RFID cards with users in VideoManager, and the limitation that permanent allocation is not available for wirelessly docked devices. Users will find detailed procedures for setting up RFID card associations and managing user access to devices.
