Performing Device Profiles Actions Device profiles are used to control the interface between devices and VideoManager, as well as the recording behaviour and settings. For more information, see Configuring Device Settings . Creating Device Profiles Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Device Profiles section. Click Create profile . In the Name field, enter a name for the device profile. From the Device family drop-down list, select to which device family the device profile should apply. Note: These details cannot be changed later. Configure the device profile settings. For more information, see Device Profiles . To save the device profile, click Save settings . Postrequisites: After a device profile has been created, it can be applied to devices. The options are as follows: If an operator is obtaining their device through Single Issue or Permanent Issue , they can manually select the device profile when they assign their device. For more information, see Devices Assignment and Media Recording . If an operator is obtaining their device through Permanent Allocation , VideoManager automatically selects the default device profile of the system, unless the operator is in a role that has a different device profile associated with it. For more information, see Performing Roles Actions . Editing Device Profiles Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Device Profiles section. From the Family drop-down list, select a device type. Note: Device families that are not present on your instance of VideoManager will still be presented as an option in the drop-down list. Next to the profile to be edited, click Go to profile . Make the relevant changes. For more information, see Device Profiles . Click Save settings . Reordering Device Profiles Reordering device profiles can be necessary if users belong to multiple roles with different assigned device profiles. The device profile that is highest in the list is the one given to the device. Furthermore, the device profile that is highest overall in the list is the system default. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Device Profiles section. From the Family drop-down list, select a device type. Click Reorder profiles . Make the necessary changes and click Confirm new order . Deleting Device Profiles Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Device Profiles section. From the Family drop-down list, select a device type. Next to the device profile to be deleted, click Delete profile . Any roles that had this device profile as their default immediately switch back to the VideoManager-wide default. Importing or Exporting Device Profiles You can import/export all device profiles on VideoManager from the Import/Export System Config section of the System pane, in the Admin tab. For more information, see Exporting and Importing the Configuration of VideoManager . Configuring Device Settings You can configure settings which apply to all devices on VideoManager, regardless of their type. Unlike device profiles, these settings do not need to be applied to devices individually. They are automatically applied when a device is connected to VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Device Settings section. Optional: In the Touch assign section, perform one of the following actions: If only devices with a full battery should be eligible for touch assign, set Full battery required to On . If you set Full battery required to Off , enter a minimum charge time, before which the device cannot be assigned by RFID. Devices that have been permanently allocated to a user are the exception. In this case, the devices can be tapped out by an RFID card even when they have not met the minimum charge time. Optional: In the Device discovery section, perform one of the following actions: If VideoManager should discover all devices that are connected via USB, configured docks, or unconfigured docks, set Enable device discovery to On . If VideoManager should only discover devices that are connected to docks, set Enable device discovery to Off . Any devices connected by USB do not appear on the Devices tab. Optional: In the Device setup section, perform any of the following actions: From the Default device assignment mode drop-down list, select which device assignment mode should be the default. This action saves time when devices are being assigned and one assignment mode is used consistently in an organisation. The options are as follows: Single issue – The device is assigned to a user and when it is redocked, it becomes unassigned and must be reassigned manually. Permanent issue – The device is assigned to the user and when it is redocked, it stays assigned to the same user. Permanent allocation – The device is allocated to a user, who must tap an RFID card before they can use it in the field. When the device is redocked, it stays allocated to the same user. Note: In the Device Field Trip , Operator Recorder Summary , and User Summary reports, devices in this mode are marked as Unassigned if they have been allocated but not tapped out with an RFID card. Set Show public QR code bootstrap screen to either On or Off . If set to On , users have the option to launch a public version of the QR config page when configuring a VT-series device, which is useful if remote workers do not have access to VideoManager, but still need to assign their devices. An administrator can send them the link to the public page, and the remote worker can use it to assign their devices from their own office or home. If set to Off , only users with direct access to VideoManager can assign VT-series devices via QR code. For more information, see Connecting VT-Series Cameras to VideoManager Remotely . Set Configure External Application account credentials to On . Note: Configure External Application account credentials should only be set to On if directed to do so by Motorola Solutions support. In the Bluetooth address prefix field, set the range of MAC addresses with which devices can pair. For more information about setting up radio integration with VB400s, see VideoManager and Tetra Radio Integration Explained or VB400 and MOTOTRBO Radio Integration Explained . Optional: In the Device offloads section, perform any of the following actions: To set the limit for the offload speed of simultaneous offloads performed by devices, in the Limit simultaneous offloads to field, enter the desired number of megabits per second. This value is an approximation used to limit the number of offloads performed at once, and does not do any rate limiting. Increasing this value beyond the total available bandwidth of connected docks does not increase the offload throughput. When a media download is interrupted and connection is then re-established, to resume downloading from the same point before connection was broken, set Fast download recovery to On . If set to Off , when a media download is interrupted and connection is then re-established, the download starts from the beginning. If you want devices to offload their oldest media to VideoManager first, set Offload oldest media file first to On . Note: The system default offloads most recent media first. This action is necessary if media are to be transferred to an Avigilon Control Center system. Optional: In the Device properties section, perform any of the following actions: Set Battery life extender to On . On supported devices, enabling this toggle extends the device battery lifetime by reducing the maximum device charge. Note: Battery life extender should only be set to On if users regularly leave devices charging in their docks for 24 hours or longer. In the Default Media Owner field, enter the name of the user who will become the owner of the media that do not have an owner. Set Reduced Power Consumption Mode to On . Note: Not all devices support this feature. When enabled, the device is shut down after charging is complete and the device is in an idle state. You must manually undock or turn on the device again to return it to operation. The device cannot be assigned when turned off. Enabling this feature can impact the management of large device fleets. Optional: In the Shift-long field trips section, set Enable shift-long field trips to On . If set to On , a device assigned to a user has an affinity with that user once it is redocked in the middle of a shift. This means that if an operator redocks their device mid-shift and then undocks it later in the shift, VideoManager automatically assigns the same device to them, unless one of the following conditions is met: The device is fully charged. The device is manually unassigned on VideoManager. The shift ends, as determined by the number of hours entered into the Maximum shift length field. Note: This function does not apply to devices that have been assigned with permanent issue or permanent allocation because VideoManager associates the user to the device permanently anyway. Optional: In the Footage signing section, set Enable footage signing to On . You can enable footage signing if you have also created or imported a certificate authority from the Device Certificate Authorities section. If Footage signing is set to On , each device is provided with a certificate that they will use to sign media files. When the media files are downloaded, VideoManager checks if the signatures of media files match the certificates of the devices, and if the certificates can be trusted. Note: This action only works if a certificate authority has been created or imported into VideoManager. If you have not created or imported a certificate authority, this action does nothing. For more information, see Performing Device Certificate Authorities Actions . Optional: In the Device Maintenance section, perform any of the following actions: If you set Enable maintenance on dock to On , maintenance is performed on supported devices when they are docked. If you set Enable scheduled maintenance to On , the Scheduled maintenance time field appears where you can set the time for daily scheduled maintenance. Optional: In the Device profiles section, from the Default device profile family drop-down list, select the device profile that should appear first by default in the Device Profiles section. Alternatively, the device profile that you visited last becomes the default device profile . Click Save settings . Configuring Dock Settings Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Dock Settings section. In the Switch to Resilient Touch Assign (RTA) mode after <number> minutes disconnected field, you can enter the amount of time (between 1-10 minutes) that should elapse after connection was lost to VideoManager, before the DockController attempts to activate RTA. In the Switch off RTA mode <number> minutes after reconnecting field, you can enter the amount of time (between 1-10 minutes) that should elapse after connection to VideoManager was reestablished, before the DockController deactivates RTA. Creating, Importing, and Deleting Access Control Keys Access control keys are the mechanism that VideoManager uses to encrypt media files. The keys prevent devices from communicating with unauthorised instances of VideoManager. Creating Access Control Keys Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Access Control Key Management section. Click Create key . In the Description field, enter a name for the access control key. Click Create key . After an access control key has been created, you can make it the default, by which all new or factory reset devices are authenticated, by clicking Set as default key . Note: It is recommended that all access control keys are exported upon creation to somewhere secure. In event of a system failure, the export ensures that users can still access media on their devices that has not been downloaded already. Importing Access Control Keys If you want to move a device to another instance of VideoManager, you must import the corresponding access control key into that instance of VideoManager. Otherwise, the device appears as Locked and you cannot access any media on the device that has not already been downloaded to VideoManager. Procedure: In the original VideoManager instance, next to the access control key, click Export key . The access control key is downloaded to your PC. In the new instance of VideoManager, click Import key and select the previously downloaded key. Deleting Access Control Keys You can delete an access control key if the devices associated with it are no longer connected to the same instance of VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Access Control Key Management section. Next to the access control key to be deleted, click Export key . Note: If an access control key is deleted while devices associated with it are still in the field, those devices appear as Locked when redocked and all media that was not already downloaded to VideoManager is permanently inaccessible, unless you have exported the access control key and can import it into VideoManager again. Click Delete key . Set Confirm that you want to delete this key to On . Click Delete . Performing Device Certificate Authorities Actions VideoManager can verify media that has been downloaded from devices, to check whether the media has been tampered with and whether it comes from a trusted source such as a genuine Motorola Solutions device. In order for this feature to function, you must first create or import a certificate authority into VideoManager, which signs the certificates issued to devices. You must then enable media signing. Note: If there is an existing certificate authority on VideoManager, the newly created or imported certificate authority replaces it as the signing certificate authority, that is VideoManager uses the new certificate authority to issue certificates to new devices from now on. However, devices that already have certificates created from the old certificate authority continue to sign files using their old certificates, and previously downloaded files contain signatures that refer to the old certificate authority. For this reason, the old certificate authority is retained so that VideoManager can use it to validate the media files from these devices. If devices should be issued new certificates based on the new certificate authority, the administrator must factory reset them. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Device Certificate Authorities section. Perform one of the following actions: Option Actions Creating new certificate authorities Click Create new device certificate authority . VideoManager automatically populates the Common Name field with the public address + root CA . You can change the name, if you want. Optional:In the Organisation field, enter the name of your organisation. For example, Motorola Solutions Optional:In the Organisational unit field, enter the name of the department that the certificate authority is for. For example, Research and Development Click Create . Importing existing certificate authorities Click Import device certificate authority . Click Choose file . Note: Any imported certificate must be a certificate authority and must be accompanied by a private key. Both the certificate and private key must be packaged as a PKCS#12 file. Certificates issued by public certificate authorities are unlikely to be suitable for import. Usually, if you want to use your own certificate authority, you must create it yourself. Select the certificate and click Open . Click OK . Perform the following actions: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Device Settings section. Scroll down to the Footage signing section. Set Enable footage signing to On . For more information, see Configuring Device Settings . From now on, all upgraded devices that are docked are issued with signing certificates. All media files downloaded from these devices are accompanied by a digital signature: VideoManager will check if the downloaded media files match their signatures and that the certificate associated with the signature is trusted by VideoManager. You can check whether the media files match this certificate from the Media tab. For more information, see Viewing and Editing Media File Properties . Exporting Certificate Authorities If devices are moved from one instance of VideoManager to another, you should export the certificate authorities of those devices from the original instance and import it into the new instance. This action ensures that media files from those devices can have their signatures checked against the original certificate. Only the public part of the certificate authority is exported, so there is no security risk from importing these certificates into a less trusted system. Procedure: On the old instance of VideoManager, navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Device Certificate Authorities section. Next to the certificate authority to be exported, click View Certificate Authority . Click Export device certificate authority . The certificate authority is downloaded to your PC. On the new instance of VideoManager, navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Device Certificate Authorities section. Click Import device certificate authority . Click Choose file . Select the certificate authority and click Open . Click OK . Deleting Certificate Authorities If media files from a particular source should no longer be trusted, you can delete the corresponding certificate authority from VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Device Certificate Authorities section. Next to the certificate authority to be deleted, click Delete device certificate authority . If there is no icon next to the certificate authority, it means that the certificate authority is still actively signing certificates. Only certificate authorities that are being used for verification can be deleted. Select the check box and click Delete . From now on, media files that would have been signed by the deleted certificate authority are not trusted by the system when downloaded, and media files that were already downloaded and signed by the deleted certificate are no longer trusted. In both cases, the Signature field of those media files reads as Untrusted Certificate . Setting an In-Vehicle Administrator Password Only users who know the in-vehicle administrator password can change administrative settings on their M500. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Vehicle Security Settings section. In the In-vehicle admin password field, enter the password and make a note of it somewhere secure. Click Save settings . Configuring RFID Settings The RFID settings allow you to configure how a tag should be processed on a per-tag type basis. For each tag type, it is possible to configure a mode and a post-processing script. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Devices pane. Click the Touch Assign Settings section. Perform one of the following actions: Option Actions Retaining previous RFID settings as configured in the Advanced Settings In the Legacy RFID Settings section, set Use legacy settings to On . Note: This section is only available if you have already had RFID settings configured in the Advanced Settings . The Legacy settings box displays your previously configured RFID settings and is read-only. When you change the values in the advanced settings, the change will be reflected in this box. Creating new RFID settings In the RFID Card Types section, click . From the Card type drop-down list, select your card. Result: The Mode drop-down list automatically selects the accurate mode depending on your card type. For most cards, the default is Standard (Read UID) which only returns the UID of the tag. The additional modes are for MIFARE and DESFire cards. If you selected the MIFARE or DESFire card, fill in the additional fields that appear. To process the ID read from the card with a Lua post-processing script, set Enable post-processing (Advanced) to On . Result: The Post-processing script box appears. Use this box to edit the Lua script that transforms the raw card ID. This action is useful if your stored user IDs do not match the raw value read from the card. For more information, see Post-Processing Script . The Example input text and Expected result fields appear so you can test the script. Enter a sample raw ID and the exact output you expect and click Test . If the script output matches the expected result, a success message appears. You must have at least one successful test before you can save your changes. Click Save . Postrequisites: For newly created RFID settings, you can perform any of the following actions in the RFID Card Types section: To delete the RFID setting, next to the relevant setting, click and confirm by clicking Yes . To edit the the RFID setting, next to the relevant setting, click . Connectivity In the Connectivity pane, you can edit aspects of VideoManager related to WiFi and sites. For more information, see Performing Vehicle Network Profile Actions . In the LTE APNs section, you can create APNs. For more information, see Creating APNs . For more information, see Performing Bandwidth Rules Actions . In the Email Settings section, you can: Configure how emails are sent and received in VideoManager. For more information, see Configuring Email Notifications . In the Mobile App Settings section, you can configure mobile application settings, if the mobile application has been licenced from Motorola Solutions. For more information, see Configuring Mobile App Settings . Performing Network Profile Actions VideoManager uses network profiles to control the connectivity options available for a device. A network profile is a collection of WiFi networks, which a device can connect to when attempting to live stream media. Creating Network Profiles Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Network Profiles section. Click Create network profile . In the Name field, enter a name for the network profile. If you want the network profile to be the default, set Default profile to On . If set to On , devices assigned with single issue via RFID and Permanent allocation will automatically use this network profile. If you want a user's user-specific WiFi networks to be added to the network profile, set User-specific networks to Yes . User-specific WiFi networks are networks that only appear on a user's session of VideoManager. This action is useful if multiple users have their own individual mobile hotspots that should only be used by devices assigned to them. For more information, see Creating User-Specific WiFi Networks . The following sections appear: VT50/VT100 and V200/VB400/V500 . If User-specific networks is enabled, configure the following settings: If Enable streaming is set to On , users with appropriate permissions can live stream media over VideoManager from devices in the field. Note: This option controls only a single network for a V200. If there is more than one network created for a VB400 or V500 and at least one of them has Enable streaming set to On , streaming will be available for all networks. V200/VB400/V500 only: If Enable video offloading is set to On , media that has been recorded on the device will be offloaded to VideoManager over the WiFi networks within this user-specific network profile. Note: This option controls only a single network for a V200. If there is more than one network created for a VB400 or V500 and at least one of them has Enable video offloading set to On , offloading will be available for all networks. If Enable docking is set to On , devices offload media and are fully manageable in VideoManager when charging and connected to WiFi. Enabling this option facilitates wireless media offload and enables remote management functions such as firmware upgrades, device assignment, or configuration changes. Note: Factory reset is not supported at the moment for V200 cameras. Firmware V200 version V25.4 is required to support this functionality. Configure WiFi networks to the network profile by clicking Add network and performing any of the following actions: Note: Unlike user-specific WiFi networks, these WiFi networks can be used by all devices that have this network profile assigned to them, regardless of their operator. In the Network name (SSID) field, enter the SSID of the WiFi network. From the Security type drop-down list, select the security type of the WiFi network. In the Passphrase field, enter the passphrase for the WiFi network. Usually, you can find these credentials on the bottom of the WiFi router. From the Band drop-down list, select which frequencies the devices should attempt to connect to. The options are as follows: Any makes devices connect to both 2.4GHz and 5GHz frequencies. 2.4GHz only makes all devices connect to 2.4GHz frequencies. 5GHz only makes devices connect to 5GHz frequencies. Set Disconnect on low signal to On . If set to On , devices disconnect from the network if it has a low signal. The user can configure for how long the device must be connected to the weak signal, after which the device disconnects. If you want to enable devices to connect to hidden networks, set Hidden network to On . Note: Hidden network should only be set to On if the networks within a network profile are hidden networks. Perform the configurations as described in 8 . If multiple networks should be contained within the network profile, repeat 9 until all the necessary networks have been added. Note: You can prioritise the networks by using Move up and Move down . Devices will attempt to connect to the first network shown in the list, while the last network in the list will only be used if all the other networks are unavailable. V500 only: In the Mobile networks section, perform any of the following actions: Set Enable LTE to Yes . Note: Assigning a network profile to a device that has both WiFi and LTE enabled will not send the WiFi configuration. The device can only use WiFi if it is assigned with a network profile that has LTE disabled. If you want to enable devices to be able to live stream media over LTE networks in this network profile, set Enable streaming to On . If you want the media that has been recorded on the device to be offloaded to VideoManager over the LTE networks within this network profile, set Enable wireless offload to On . If you have configured device profiles so that the device can place bookmarks in a media file, then only bookmarked media files are downloaded over the LTE networks. If you have not configured the device profiles, then all media files are downloaded over the LTE networks when the device is connected to power. For more information, see Performing Device Profiles Actions and Device Profiles . Click Save profile . Postrequisites: After a network profile has been created, it can be applied to devices. The options are as follows: If an operator is obtaining their device through Single Issue or Permanent Issue , they can manually select the network profile when they assign their device. For more information, see Devices Assignment and Media Recording . If an operator is obtaining their device through Permanent Allocation , VideoManager automatically selects the default network profile of the system. Editing Network Profiles Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Network Profiles section. Next to the profile to be edited, click Go to profile . Make the relevant changes and click Save profile . Deleting Network Profiles Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Network Profiles section. Next to the profile to be deleted, click Delete profile . Note: The default network profile cannot be deleted. You must first select another network profile to become the default instead. You can do so by clicking Go to profile next to the network profile, setting its Default profile to On , and clicking Save profile . The outdated network profile can now be deleted. Duplicating Network Profiles Duplicating network profiles can be useful if VideoManager should have multiple similar network profiles. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Network Profiles section. Next to the profile to be duplicated, click Duplicate network profile . The Create Network Profile pane opens, with the original information of the network profile pre-set. Optional: Edit the network profile like normal. By default, the Name of the network profile is set to <name of the duplicated network profile> (copy) . Note: Each network profile must have a unique name on VideoManager. You cannot save a network profile whose name is identical to an existing network profile. Click Save profile . Exporting Network Profiles Exporting network profiles can be useful if sites should have the same network profiles as their Central VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Network Profiles section. Next to the profile to be exported, click Export network profile . The network profile is exported to the default download location of your PC, and can be imported to other instances of VideoManager. Importing Network Profiles Importing network profiles can be useful if sites should have the same network profiles as their Central VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Network Profiles section. Next to the profile to be imported, click Import network profile . Select the relevant file from your PC. Click Import . The network profile should appear on your instance of VideoManager. Alternatively, if you want to import/export all of your network profiles simultaneously, you can do so from the Import/Export System Config section of the System pane, in the Admin tab. For more information, see Exporting and Importing the Configuration of VideoManager . To move the network up in the list of networks, click . To move the network down in the list of networks, click . To permanently delete the network, next to the network that you want to delete, click . The configured networks allow the M500E to offload evidence using WiFi. Under the M500 Interview Recording System section, define parameters of the connection to the specific IP devices. Note: IP devices are to be installed only for the M500 used in the interview room. Click Save profile . Editing Vehicle Network Profiles Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Vehicle Network Profiles section. The Create Vehicle network profile pane opens, with the original information of the vehicle network profile pre-set. Optional: Edit the vehicle network profile like normal. You cannot save a vehicle network profile whose name is identical to an existing vehicle network profile. Click Save profile . Exporting Vehicle Network Profiles Exporting vehicle network profiles can be useful if sites should have the same vehicle network profiles as their Central VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Vehicle Network Profiles section. Next to the profile to be exported, click Export vehicle network profile . The vehicle network profile is exported to the default download location of your PC, and can be imported to other instances of VideoManager. Importing Vehicle Network Profiles Importing vehicle network profiles can be useful if sites should have the same vehicle network profiles as their Central VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Vehicle Network Profiles section. Next to the profile to be imported, click Import vehicle network profile . Select the relevant file from your PC. Click Import . The vehicle network profile should appear on your instance of VideoManager. Alternatively, if you want to import/export all of your network profiles simultaneously, you can do so from the Import/Export System Config section of the System pane, in the Admin tab. For more information, see Exporting and Importing the Configuration of VideoManager . Creating APNs Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the LTE APNs section. Performing Bandwidth Rules Actions You can configure bandwidth rules, which affect how much bandwidth is used when downloading data from both sites and docks. Creating and Applying Bandwidth Rules Procedure: On the Central VideoManager (if creating a bandwidth rule for sites), or on VideoManager (if creating a bandwidth rule for docks), navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Bandwidth Rules section. Click Create bandwidth rule . In the Name field, enter a name for the bandwidth rule. Optional: If you want all docks that are added to this rule to be part of the same "group" and share the same bandwidth limit, set Shared bandwidth group to On . This action is useful if multiple docks are on the same network connection, and you want to stagger the downloads. If you want all docks who are added to this rule to continuously download media to VideoManager, ignoring the overall download limit, set Slow connection to On . This action is useful if the docks have a slow network connection. To create an individual rule, click Add rule . You can create multiple rules within one bandwidth rule, which is useful if there are certain "busy" times when media and other data should not be offloaded, and other "quiet" times when media and data should be offloaded. If there are multiple rules within one bandwidth rule, you should order them using the controls next to each rule. If there are two overlapping rules, for example, two rules apply on Saturday, the rule that is highest in the list takes priority. You can delete an individual rule within a bandwidth rule by clicking Delete bandwidth rule . Configure any of the following settings: The day(s) of the week when the rule should occur. In the from field, enter the time of day when the rule should begin. In the until field, enter the time of day when the rule should finish. In the limit to field, enter the number of kilobits per second to which uploads should be limited while the rule applies. Click Create bandwidth rule . After a bandwidth rule is created, it must be manually applied in order to take effect. Perform one of the following actions: Option Actions Applying a bandwidth rule to a dock Navigate to the Devices tab. Select the docks pane. Next to the relevant dock, click View details . You can filter docks by Name , Serial , and Version . In the Bandwidth Rule pane, click the drop-down menu, and select the relevant rule. Optional:If you want all media from the selected dock to be downloaded as quickly as possible, set High Priority dock to On . If the dock is part of a bandwidth rule that has the Shared bandwidth group setting enabled, it halts the downloads of other docks in the group until all of its media has been downloaded. Click Save Bandwidth Rule . Applying a bandwidth rule to a site The bandwidth rule can either be applied upon creation or the site can be edited afterward to include the rule. For more information, see Configuring Sites . Copying Bandwidth Rules Copying bandwidth rules enables to create multiple, similar bandwidth rules. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Bandwidth Rules section. Next to the relevant bandwidth rule, click Copy bandwidth rule . The name of the copied bandwidth rule is the name of the original bandwidth rule with _1 (if it is the first copy of the bandwidth rule) at the end. Note: Unlike groups and users, it is possible to create two bandwidth rules with the same name, but it is not recommended. Make any necessary changes to the copy of the bandwidth rule, and click Save bandwidth rule . Editing Bandwidth Rules Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Bandwidth Rules section. Click Go to bandwidth rule . Make the relevant changes, and click Save bandwidth rule . The bandwidth rule automatically updates across all docks to which it has been applied. Deleting Bandwidth Rules Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Bandwidth Rules section. Next to the relevant bandwidth rule, click Delete bandwidth rule . Note: If the deleted bandwidth rule was previously applied to a dock or site, the bandwidth setting for those docks and sites immediately changes to No restriction until another bandwidth rule is manually reapplied. Configuring Email Settings Configuring email settings is necessary to enable additional functionality: users can reset their own passwords, self-register without administrative help, and receive notifications when specific actions are performed on VideoManager. Prerequisites: Enable the Notification licence. For more information, see Importing and Deleting Licences . Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Email Settings section. Set Email notifications enabled to On . In the Default properties section, configure the following settings: In the Sender email address field, enter the email address from which all VideoManager emails should be sent. This includes email notifications, password reset emails, and user profile creation emails. In the Host field, enter the host from which emails should be sent. For Gmail, the host is smtp.gmail.com In the Port field, enter the port from which emails should be sent. For Gmail, the port is 587 If Authentication is set to On , enter the username and password belonging to the email address entered in the Sender email address field. Note: The password is not necessarily the same password that is utilised to log on to the email address's account. Gmail only: Create an app password by performing the following actions: Open the account settings pane for the email address entered in the Sender email address field. Click the Security section. Click App passwords . From the Select app drop-down list, select Other (Custom name) . Enter VideoManager Click Generate . Copy the password and paste it into the Password field. If STARTTLS enable is set to On , all emails sent from VideoManager are protected with Transport Layer Security (TLS). If Trust server certificates is set to On , VideoManager trusts the SMTP server. If set to Off , VideoManager will check server certificates. Optional: In the Custom properties section, add specific properties that dictate how VideoManager interacts with the SMTP server by performing the following actions: Click Add property . In the Property field, enter the name of the property. This should be the name of a JavaMail SMTP property. For example, mail.smtp.timeout or mail.smtp.reportsuccess In the Value field, enter the value of the property. The format of the value (milliseconds, true/false, host name, and more) depends on the property name entered in the Property field. Optional: In the Custom templates section, configure the notification email that is sent to users when specific actions are taken on VideoManager by performing any of the following actions: If you want to configure the email that users receive when another user on VideoManager logs on for the first time, set First time login to On . If you want to configure the email that users receive when a device starts streaming, set Device stream start to On . This could be the user's own device, or a device assigned to someone they supervise, depending on the way the user's permissions are configured. Optional: In the Test Properties section, in the Test recipient field, enter the email address to which the test email should be sent, and click Test . Postrequisites: You can also configure how password reset emails and user profile creation emails are sent. For more information, see Configuring User Self Service . Configuring Email Notifications After you have configured email settings on VideoManager, you can enable and configure email notifications. This action involves optionally configuring the email template which users will receive for various events, enabling notifications for individual roles, and ensuring that users in those roles have email addresses associated with them. Procedure: Optional: Configure the emails that users will receive when specific actions are taken on VideoManager by performing the following actions: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Email Settings section. Scroll down to the Custom templates section. The options are as follows: If First time login is set to On , you can configure the email that users receive when another user on VideoManager logs on for the first time. If left as Off , the default message is User has logged in to <system> for the first time. User <username> <displayName> has logged in. If Device stream start is set to On , you can configure the email that users receive when a device starts streaming. This could be the user's own device, or a device assigned to someone they supervise, depending on the way the user's permissions have been configured. If left as Off , the default message is Device started streaming. <device> started streaming to <system> . If File storage threshold warning is set to On , you can configure the email that users receive when one of file spaces of VideoManager is nearly full. If left as Off , the default message is A File Space on <system> has exceeded the threshold: <#list storageWarnings as message> <message.category> : <message.level> </#list> . Configure which users should receive notifications on a role-by-role basis by performing the following actions: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Users pane. Click the Roles section. Next to the role to be edited, click Go to role . Enable the relevant permissions. First time login – Users receive a notification when other users first log on to VideoManager. Personal device stream start – Users receive a notification when a device assigned to them starts streaming. Supervised device stream start – Users receive a notification when a device assigned to users they supervise starts streaming. File storage threshold warnings – Users receive a notification when VideoManager is low on storage space. Click Save role . Ensure that all users in the notification-enabled roles have email addresses associated with them on VideoManager by performing the following actions: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Users pane. Click the Users section. Locate the user to be edited by filtering users in one of the following ways: In the Name field, enter the user's username or display name. In the Authentication ID field, enter the user's authentication ID. In the In group field, enter the group name of the user's group. If you enter a group name in the In group field, you have the option to change if Only immediate members is set to On or not. If set to On , only users that are assigned directly to the specified group are returned, as opposed to if user A is assigned indirectly to group B because A belongs to group C, which is assigned to group B. In the Email field, enter the user's email. In the User UUID field, enter the user's UUID which is a unique, non-sequential ID for a user. Note: You need correct permissions to either view or search by this field. For more information, see User Permissions . From the Role drop-down list, select the user's relevant role. You can click to reset the filter. Next to the user to be edited, click Go to user . In the Email notifications field, enter an email address for the user. Click Save user . Configuring Mobile App Settings If the mobile application has been licenced from Motorola Solutions, you can configure its settings from VideoManager. You should do this before you start operating your mobile application. For more information about setting up the mobile applications with VideoManager, you can navigate to https://www.motorolasolutions.com/en_xu.html and search for VideoManager: VB SmartControl User Guide , VideoManager VB Companion Guide or SmartControl User Guide . Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Connectivity pane. Click the Mobile App Settings section. In the VB Companion settings section, perform the following actions: In the Update app configuration after field, enter the number of days after which VB Companion must receive an updated configuration from VideoManager. Note: For the action to be successful, the phone running VB Companion must be able to reach the instance of VideoManager from which it was provisioned, for example over a WiFi network or VPN, and the administrator must click Refresh config in VB Companion. If VB Companion cannot reach VideoManager within the number of days specified, it stops working. In the Devices must be docked every field, enter the number of days after which the devices associated with individual instances of VB Companion must be redocked.
