Optional: If you want all communication between the device and the user's phone to be encrypted with SSL, set Use SSL to Yes . If enabled, you are presented with an SSL certificate which you must download and install onto the phone which is running VB Companion. In the VB SmartControl settings section, perform any of the following actions: If you want all communication between the device and the user's phone to be encrypted with SSL, set Use SSL to Yes . If you want watermarks to be displayed on video playback in the mobile application, set Enable playback watermarks to Yes . From the SmartControl default auth mode , select which authentication method you will use during provisioning. The options are as follows: Client certificate or Bluetooth . Note: Depending on the mobile application, a device supports different authentication modes: For VB Companion, a device supports only Client Certificate mode. For VB SmartControl, a device supports only Bluetooth Authentication mode. For SmartControl, a device supports both Client Certificate and Bluetooth Authentication modes, with Client Certificate as the default. Note: V500 supports only Bluetooth Authentication mode. Click Save settings . Integrations In the Integrations pane, you can edit aspects of VideoManager relating to reoccurring rules and settings. From the Integrations pane, you can access the following sections: In the API Key Management section, you can create API keys, which enable VideoManager to securely communicate with external software. For more information, see Creating, Viewing, and Deleting API Keys . In the ONStream section, you can configure ONStream settings. For more information, see Configuring ONStream . In the Maps section, you can change map settings. This action is necessary if administrators want to use Tactical VideoManager, view location data for recorded media, and filter recorded media by location. For more information, see Enabling and Configuring Maps . In the Antivirus Integration section, you can configure whether VideoManager scans imported media for viruses. For more information, see Enabling and Configuring the Antivirus Policy . In the Assisted Redaction Settings section, you can enable staff with the correct permissions to redact videos using the Assisted Redaction service. For more information, see Enabling Assisted Redaction Settings . In the Analytics section, you can enable sending the user data to improve VideoManager and configure the privacy settings. For more information, see Enabling and Configuring Analytics . Creating, Viewing, and Deleting API Keys API keys dictate how VideoManager communicates with external software or devices. Creating API Keys Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Integrations pane. Click the API Key Management section. Click New API key . In the Name field, enter a name for the API key. The name is not required to be unique on VideoManager but it is strongly recommended. If you want the API key to be automatically generated upon creation, set Generate key to On . Note: Setting to On is necessary if you are creating an entirely new API key. If set to Off , you can enter the key manually, which is necessary if you are adding a previously existing API key to VideoManager. If you want the API secret to be automatically generated upon creation, set Generate secret to On . Note: Setting to On is necessary if you are creating an entirely new API key. If set to Off , you can enter the secret manually, which is necessary if you are adding a previously existing API key to VideoManager. From the API key roles drop-down list, select which role is most appropriate for the API key. Note: If you will be integrating your own software with VideoManager, the Use System Role option is recommended. If you selected the Use System Role option, from the Roles drop-down list, select which roles of VideoManager the API key should inhabit. Verify that the information entered is correct. Note: API keys cannot be edited after creation. To save the API key, click Confirm . The API key and API secret are presented. Note: You must make a note of the API secret because it cannot be viewed again. Viewing API Keys Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Integrations pane. Click the API Key Management section. Filter the API keys as necessary, and click Search . You can enter the name of the API key in the Name / Key field, and select the role of an API key from the API key roles drop-down list. You can click Reset filter to clear the search filters. Next to the API key to be edited, click View API key . You can view here the Name , Key , and API key role . Click Close . Deleting API Keys Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Integrations pane. Click the API Key Management section. Filter the API keys as necessary, and click Search . You can enter the name of the API key in the Name / Key field, and select the role of an API key from the API key roles drop-down list. You can click Reset filter to clear the search filters. Next to the API key to be deleted, click Delete API key . Configuring ONStream Before the system can be configured, ONStream must be configured and enabled from VideoManager. Process: Enable ONStream on VideoManager with a licence. This step is only necessary if the user is running VideoManager version 14.2 or earlier. For more information, see Enabling ONStream . Configure ONStream settings. These settings dictate how the system connects to VideoManager. For more information, see Configuring ONStream Settings . Create outputs. These outputs determine how VideoManager users and devices are mapped onto the system. For more information, see Creating and Resetting Outputs . Enabling ONStream From version 14.3 onwards, VideoManager enables ONStream by default as long as the user has at least one device associated with VideoManager. For instances of VideoManager which are running version 14.2 or earlier, ONStream must be manually enabled by importing a licence into VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Licences section. Click Import licence . Note: You should select the ONStream licence provided to you by Motorola Solutions. Click Choose file . Select the certificate and click Open . Enter the password. Click OK . Confirm again by clicking Import . If successful, the licence appears as Valid in the Licences section. Configuring ONStream Settings Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Integrations pane. Click the ONStream section. Set Enable ONStream to On . From the Video codec drop-down list, select the codec to be used to compress the live streams between devices and the system. The options are MPEG4 or H264 . From the Authentication mode drop-down list, select whether users must enter additional credentials when connecting their instance of VideoManager to the system. If no additional authentication is required, select None . If users should be prompted to create a Username and Password on VideoManager, select Basic . These credentials must be entered in the system when it is being configured to connect to VideoManager. From the Multi device mode drop-down list, select whether VideoManager presents as a single multi-channel encoder, or multiple encoders. If the system will be used with 16 devices or fewer, select Off . If the system will be used with more than 16 devices, select either IP addresses or Domain names . In the RTSP port field, configure the port that VideoManager should use to pass streams to the system. By default, the port is 554 . The administrator may need to change the default port if any software on the same machine as VideoManager is using port 554 . Optional: Set Allow historic footage fetch to On . If set to On , the system has access to, and can copy, all media on VideoManager. This process does not start until the administrator has also configured the system to retrieve historic media. Note: Enabling Allow historic footage fetch permits the system to retrieve restricted media. Set Enable back channel audio to On . Enabling this setting controls whether, when GoLive Audio is active, VideoManager informs a connected client that back channel audio is available. Click Save settings . Creating and Resetting Outputs Creating Outputs There must be one output for every user or device that will be streaming to the system. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Integrations pane. Click the ONStream section. Set Enable ONStream to On . Scroll to the Outputs section. Click Create . The Create ONStream Outputs window opens. Enter the number of required outputs and click Confirm . Select the type of output to be created. If streams should correspond to the specified device, regardless of the operator using the device, select Device and enter the serial number of the device. VideoManager will suggest serial numbers that match the one entered. If streams should correspond to the specified operator, regardless of the device used to stream media, select Operator and enter the username of an operator. If streams should correspond to the specified number of panels, select Tactical view panel and enter the number. Click Save settings . Resetting Outputs If the number of outputs should be raised or lowered after the outputs have been created, the outputs should be reset. Preexisting outputs will not be affected if the total number of outputs is raised. However, if the new number is lower than the previous number, a user's outputs will be deleted to match that number. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Integrations pane. Click the ONStream section. Scroll to the Outputs section. Click Reset . Enter the new number of required outputs. Click Save settings . Enabling and Configuring Maps You can enable or disable maps, select between map and location lookup providers, and set the default location for media recorded without a GPS track. Prerequisites: If you will be using the private ArcGis service, you must first register VideoManager as an app on the service. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Integrations pane. Click the Maps section. Set Enable maps to On . From the Map provider drop-down list, select the maps provider. This action enables you to perform actions such as utilising Tactical VideoManager, adding location data to videos, and filtering videos based on this location data. The options are as follows: If you selected Google Places , enter an API key in the Google API key field. An API key can be generated from the Google developers' page, which can be found at https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/javascript/get-api-key . If you selected OpenStreetMap , enter a server URL in the OSM tile server URL field. A list of free tile providers can be found at https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Raster_tile_providers . If you selected ArcGIS , enter a server URL in the ArcGIS tile server URL field. Note: If you are using a private ArcGis service, you must copy the client ID and paste it into the ArcGIS client ID field, copy the client secret and paste it into the ArcGIS client secret field, and copy the authentication URL and paste it into the ArcGIS authentication URL field. If you are not using a private ArcGis service, Motorola Solutions recommends copying and pasting the server URL. If you selected Géoportail (Luxembourg) , enter a server URL in the Tile server URL field. From the Location lookup provider drop-down list, select the location lookup provider. This action enables you to enter specific addresses and postcodes when filtering videos based on your location and editing video location data. The options are as follows: If you selected Google Places , enter an API key in the Google API key field. For more information, see 5 . If you selected Nominatim , enter a server URL in the Nominatim server URL field. Nominatim providers can prompt you to enter an API key into the Nominatim API key field. If you selected ArcGIS , enter a server URL from your ArcGis account into the ArcGIS search server URL field. If you are not using a private ArcGis service, Motorola Solutions recommends copying and pasting the server URL. You can fill out the rest of the fields as described in 5 . If you selected Géoportail (Luxembourg) , no further details are required. If you selected -- , go to 7 . No further details must be entered. Note: If you select this option, you cannot enter specific addresses and postcodes when setting location data for videos. You will only be able to drag and drop a location pin. From the Distance units drop-down list, select the unit of measurement that should be used by VideoManager when presenting maps. The options are: Imperial (ft/mi) and Metric (m/km) . Optional: In the Default location field, set a default location for videos that do not have GPS data. For example, because the device on which the videos were recorded is not GPS-enabled. To confirm the choice, click Set . To clear the field, click . Click Save settings . Enabling and Configuring the Antivirus Policy Users can import media files from external sources into VideoManager. If administrators have an OPSWAT account, they can use it to automatically scan these media files for viruses as they are being imported into VideoManager. Prerequisites: Configure the antivirus policy. The antivirus policy dictates the type of files to be scanned for viruses. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Integrations pane. Click the Antivirus Integration section. In the OPSWAT MetaDefender section, set Enable OPSWAT to On . In the API endpoint URL field, enter https://api.metadefender.com/v4/ If you have an on-premise OPSWAT account, the URL will be different. For more information, you should contact the system administrator. In the API Key field, enter the API key associated with your OPSWAT account. To find the API key, log on to the OPSWAT portal and navigate to the Dashboard tab. The API key is shown in the My API Key section of the MetaDefender Cloud pane. Click Save settings . To ensure that the API key is valid, click Check OPSWAT connection status and check the Current connection status: section. If the status displays Connection succeeded , the API key is valid and working correctly. If the status displays Connection failed , the API key is invalid and should be entered again. In the File size limit field, enter the size of imported files in megabytes, above which VideoManager will not attempt to scan them for viruses. The file size upper limit depends on your OPSWAT account. A free account has an upper limit of 140MB, a commercial account has an upper limit of 256MB, and an enterprise account does not have a limit. Note: The larger an imported file, the longer OPSWAT takes to scan it for viruses. Optional: From the Media files and Non media files drop-down lists, determine the default scan policies for media (JPG, JPEG, MP4) and non-media (PDF, XLS/XLSX, CSV) imports, respectively. The options are as follows: Scan files below the limit, fail files which are too large Scan files below the limit, pass files which are too large Do not scan any files Click Save settings . From now on, depending on the configuration, media files are scanned for viruses as they are imported into VideoManager. If a media file fails the antivirus scan, it cannot be imported. Enabling and Configuring Analytics Enabling analytics for the system or users allows to send the data for analysis to further improve VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Integrations pane. Click the Analytics section. To enable sending the user data, set Turn on Analytics? to Yes . If you want to keep analytics anonymous with the data tied to an anonymous identifier, set Anonymise user data to Yes . By disabling this option, the username is applied directly to the analytics data. Note: Changing this option only applies to future events. If you want all administrators to read the system wide agreement and allow them to reject or accept it, in the System agreement configuration section, set Admin must accept system wide agreement to Yes and perform the following actions: Note: Disabling this option allows the data to be automatically sent. Ensure that you enable the Accept analytics agreement permission for administrators. For more information, see Advanced Permissions . In the System wide agreement window, customise the agreement that will appear to every administrator as soon as they log on. System wide agreement enrolment state is a status of whether the agreement was accepted or refused. To resend the agreement to administrators, next to Reset enrolment state to pending acceptance , click Reset state . The window appears informing you that administrators with sufficient permissions will need to accept the agreement again to use analytics. Select the I understand. check box and click Confirm . Administrators are automatically logged out and once they log on, the window appears where they can refuse or agree to sending their analytics data. If you want all users to read the privacy statement and configure the users' consent, in the User privacy statement configuration section, set Users must accept privacy statement to Yes and perform the following actions: Note: Disabling this option allows the data to be automatically sent. In the Privacy statement window, customise the privacy statement that will appear to every user as soon as they log on. From the Initial user enrolment state drop-down list, perform one of the following actions: Note: You need correct permissions to view or edit the Initial user enrolment state drop-down list. For more information, see User Permissions . If you want the user data to be automatically sent, select Automatically consented . If you want to allow each user to decide for themselves whether they want to consent to sending their data, select Pending user consent . If you select this option, the following toggles appear: To allow users to consent to or reject the privacy statement, set Allow users to see consent to Yes . To allow users to change whether they consent to or not to the privacy statement any time, set Allow users to change consent to Yes . If you select Pending user consent , to resend the privacy statement to users, next to Reset user enrolment state , click Reset state . Select the I understand. check box and click Confirm . Users are automatically logged out and once they log on, the window appears where they can refuse or agree to sending their analytics data. Click Save settings . Infrastructure In the Infrastructure pane, you can edit aspects of VideoManager relating to reoccurring rules and settings. From the Infrastructure pane, you can access the following sections: If VideoManager has been configured as a Central VideoManager, Metadata/Footage Replication and Configuration Replication settings determine which aspects of its configuration, for example, users and roles, are automatically shared with its connected sites. For more information, see Configuring Sites . In the Site Manager section, you can configure sites. If VideoManager is not already acting as a Central VideoManager, this pane allows you to enable your instance of VideoManager to act as a site. Note: The Site Manager section is not available if VideoManager is acting as a Central VideoManager. For more information, see Configuring Sites . In the Streaming Server section, you can import and export a streaming server configuration. Network profiles can be configured so that devices live stream to a streaming server rather than streaming to this instance of VideoManager. For more information, see Importing and Exporting a Streaming Server Configuration . Importing and Exporting a Streaming Server Configuration Importing a Streaming Server Configuration Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Infrastructure pane. Click the Streaming Server section. Click Import config for streaming to an external VideoManager . Select the relevant file from your PC. Click Import . Exporting a Streaming Server Configuration Prerequisites: Configure a public web server address before generating a streaming server configuration. For more information, see Configuring the Public Address of VideoManager . Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Infrastructure pane. Click the Streaming Server section. Click Export new config for streaming to this VideoManager . The streaming server configuration is exported to the default download location of your PC, and can be imported to other instances of VideoManager. Media and Playback In the Media and Playback pane, you can edit aspects of VideoManager relating to reoccurring rules and settings. From the Media and Playback pane, you can access the following sections: In the Media Fields section, you can perform the following actions: Transfer copies of media fields from one instance of VideoManager to another. For more information, see Exporting and Importing Media Fields . Control the format of information entered into media fields. For more information, see Creating and Applying Validators . Reorder media fields. For more information, see Reordering Media Fields . Create media fields. Media fields enable users to categorise media files, using more complex fields than those which VideoManager provides by default. For more information, see Creating Media Fields . Edit default media fields, which are built into VideoManager and can have various aspects of their configuration changed. For more information, see Editing Default Media Field Visibility . Edit the M500/M500E event category media field. For more information, see Editing the M500/M500E Event Category Media Field . Add M500/M500E event tags to make other existing media ﬁelds compatible with the M500/M500E. For more information, see Adding Other M500/M500E Event Tags . Configure user-defined field layouts. For more information, see Configuring User-Defined Field Layouts . Media playback reason fields prompt users to enter a reason as to why they are watching an outdated media file. It is used in tandem with the playback policy configured in the Playback Policy section. In the Media Playback Reason Fields section, you can perform the following actions: Transfer copies of media playback reason fields from one instance of VideoManager to another. For more information, see Exporting and Importing Media Playback Reason Fields . Control the format of information entered into media playback reason fields. For more information, see Creating and Applying Validators . Reorder media playback reason fields. For more information, see Reordering Media Playback Reason Fields . Create media playback reason fields. Media playback reason fields enable users to categorise media files, using more complex fields than those which VideoManager provides by default. For more information, see Creating Media Playback Reason Fields . In the Media/File Exports section, you can configure whether recorded media should be sent straight from a device to a predetermined location on a PC or server, in addition to being stored on VideoManager. For more information, see Configuring Media File Exports . In the Media List section, you can change how all users view media files on their homepage. For more information, see Configuring the Media List . In the Import Profiles section, you can configure import profiles. These profiles dictate which media fields are automatically populated when a media file is imported into VideoManager. For more information, see Configuring Import Profiles . You can also test the export-import feedback mechanism. For more information, see Testing the Export-Import Feedback Mechanism . In the Playback Policy section, you can: Configure whether users must record their reason for watching a media file after a set period of time. It is used in tandem with the media playback reason fields configured in the Media Playback Reason Fields section. For more information, see Configuring the Playback Policy . Change the default quality at which media files are played on VideoManager. For more information, see Configuring Player . In the Playback Watermark section, you can add and create watermarks to be displayed on media files when played back. For more information, see Configuring Playback Watermarks . In the Thumbnails section, you can change the default thumbnail for media files that have been imported without a built-in thumbnail. For more information, see Configuring Thumbnails . In the Thumbnail Watermark section, you can enable watermarks to be displayed on the thumbnails of the media files. Note: You must have the video playback watermarking enabled. Otherwise, even if you enable this feature, the watermark will not appear on the thumbnail. For more information, see Configuring Playback Watermarks . In the Video Metadata Overlay Settings section, you can add metadata display settings for all media on VideoManager, which affects which metadata is recorded alongside media files and subsequently displayed when users watch media that has been recorded on a device. For more information, see Configuring Video Metadata Overlay Settings . Exporting and Importing Media Fields If you have multiple instances of VideoManager, you can transfer a copy of your media fields from one instance to another. Procedure: In the original instance of VideoManager, navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Media Fields section. Click Export . The media fields are saved to the default download location of your PC. In the new instance of VideoManager (or a site, if User-defined Fields has been set to Off in the Metadata/Footage Replication section), navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Media Fields section. Click Import . Select the previously downloaded media fields. Click Import . Alternatively, if you want to import all of your media fields simultaneously, you can do so from the Import/Export System Config section of the System pane, in the Admin tab. For more information, see Exporting and Importing the Configuration of VideoManager . Creating and Applying Validators You can control the format of information entered into media fields. This action can be done through the creation of validators, which can be configured to accept certain patterns and reject others, for example, a UK postcode or a URL. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Media Fields section. Click Edit validators . Click Create validator . In the Identifier field, enter a unique name for the validator. In the Description field, enter the text which users should see when populating a media field. The description should detail the format to which the media field should adhere. In the Pattern field, enter the pattern of the validator. This action should be done utilising regular expressions. Optional: If you want the validator to ignore the case of the text entered into the media field, set Case insensitive to On . If set to Off , the case of the text entered into the media field must match that of the Pattern field. Optional: If you want to test the validator, in the Test text field, enter the example text. VideoManager determines whether the example text would be accepted by the validator or not. Click Confirm . Postrequisites: After validators have been created, they must be individually applied to media fields, which ensures that the media fields obey the patterns detailed in the validators. This action must be done during media field creation. Validators cannot be edited after a media field has been created. For more information, see Creating Media Fields . Reordering Media Fields You can reorder media fields, which changes the order in which they are presented during editing media files. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Media Fields section. Click Reorder fields . Grab the left-hand side of the relevant media field and drag it to the desired location in the list. Click Confirm . When users edit a media file, the media fields to be populated are presented in the same order which has been configured here. Creating Media Fields VideoManager comes with some built-in media fields , which enable users to categorise media files as they are being edited . Administrators can also create their own media fields to reflect the unique needs of their organisation. Prerequisites: Before you create new media fields, you can create validators, which define how information entered into media fields must be formatted, for example, as a UK postcode. For more information, see Creating and Applying Validators . If the new media field should show users a different display name based on their session language, you should change the language for your own session before you create the field so that it does not match the server language of VideoManager. This action can be done from either the account menu or the Language section. For more information, see Configuring the Language on VideoManager . Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Media Fields section. Click Create field . In the Identifier field, enter an identifier for the media field. The identifier should be all lowercase, and unique. In the Display name field, enter a display name for the media field. The display name is what the media field is called in the VideoManager UI. Note: An optional second display name field appears if your session language does not currently match the server language of VideoManager. The field enables you to enter a display name for the field in both languages. If the display name should be set in more than two languages, you must complete the field, save it, then change your session to the third language and edit the field. From the Type drop-down list, select the type of a media field to be created: Search: Column Export to Excel Export to CSV Name Description Text In this media field, users can enter text related to the media file, which is useful if users need to search for a specific phrase or word, such as Assault , Arrest , and more. Text List In this media field, users can select one or more texts related to the media file. Date In this media field, users can select a date related to the media file. Date & Time In this media field, users can select a date and time related to the media file. Drop down In this media field, users can select an option from a drop-down list related to the media file. Check box In this media field, users can either select or unselect a check box related to the media file. URL In this media field, users can enter a URL related to the media file. Computed In this media field, users can create URLs from previously created media fields. Administrators can also configure computed fields to appear, and change their appearance, based on how other media fields are populated. Tag List In this media field, users can select one or more tags related to the media file. Note: The type of the media field cannot be changed later. Optional: If you do not want users to be able to save a media file unless they populate the field, set Mandatory to Yes . Optional: From the Display timeout drop-down list, select how long this field should stay on the screen before it disappears. Note: This option is only available on devices that support it and if the field is not mandatory. From the Permission group drop-down list, select to which access group the media field should apply. Any users in the selected access group are able to view and edit the media field when creating and editing media files. If all users should be able to utilise the media field when creating and editing media files, you can select Public . Computed fields do not need to have the same permission groups as the other media fields that determine whether they appear or not. For example, if only some administrators should be able to populate the review-status field with sensitive information, but all users should be able to see the more general reviewed-already computed field, review-status could be set to Access Group One , while reviewed-already could be set to Public . Optional: If you have selected Text from the drop-down type list, if you want in-vehicle devices to capture event information, set Is Event Tag? to Yes . From the Column width drop-down list, select how wide the column of the media field should appear in media search results. This action is only relevant if the media field is configured to appear in the media search results pane. For more information, see Configuring User-Defined Field Layouts . Depending on the type of media field to be created, perform one of the following actions: If you have selected Text , see Creating Text Fields . If you have selected Text List , see Creating Text List Fields . If you have selected Date , see Creating Date Fields . If you have selected Date & Time , see Creating Date and Time Fields . If you have selected Drop down , see Creating Drop Down Fields . If you have selected Check box , see Creating Check Box Fields . If you have selected URL , see Creating URL Fields . If you have selected Computed , see Creating Computed Fields . If you have selected Tag List , see Creating Tag List Fields . Postrequisites: After you have created media fields, there are actions which can be performed on these media fields from the Media Fields pane. You can: Export media fields from one instance of VideoManager, and import them into another instance. For more information, see Exporting and Importing Media Fields . Configure how media fields are presented when viewing media in the Search Media pane. For more information, see Configuring User-Defined Field Layouts . Reorder media fields, which affects how media fields are presented when editing a media file. For more information, see Reordering Media Fields . Creating Text Fields After you have selected Text from the Type drop-down list, the following configuration options appear in the Text section. Procedure: In the Number of lines field, enter the number of lines (1-50) which should be displayed at once when viewing the text field in a media file. This action does not restrict the actual number of lines which can be entered. For example, if the number of lines is set to 3 and there are four lines of text in the text field of a media file, a scroll bar appears on the right-hand side of the pane to show the last line. In the Maximum number of characters field, enter the number. If the field is left empty, the field will be unrestricted. Some devices do not enforce this restriction. Optional: From the Input type drop-down list, select the type of input display to be used to enter the value on displays that support it, such as in-vehicle devices. Export-Import Feedback Mechanism An export-import feedback mechanism manages the secure transfer of sensitive data from System A to System B, without compromising system access constraints. Overview Consider a police officer who has collected crucial video evidence during an investigation. This evidence, stored in their VideoManager system (System A), needs to be accessed by a court official (System B). However, the court official does not have access to the police officer's system due to institutional restrictions or data protection concerns. The process starts when the police officer creates an incident in System A, attaching the necessary video media. This incident is then designated for export, leading to the data being transferred into a shared storage that both systems can access. In parallel, System B has an automated import process that continuously scans the shared storage for new exports from System A. Upon detecting new data, System B initiates processing of the files. Once completed, System B generates a confirmation file that includes important information like the export job signature and a URL for direct access to the video. This file is written into another shared location accessible by System A. Simultaneously, System A maintains an automated import process that monitors for "import confirmations" from System B. When such a confirmation is ingested, System A updates the associated original export job with the URL provided by System B, and notifies the user who initiated the export, completing the data exchange process. Export-Import Feedback Mechanism Configuration Requirements There are three configuration elements required for System A to automatically export to System B: System A requires an export profile to write the exported files to some mutually accessible location. The signature of the export job must be included in metadata. System B requires an automatic import profile to monitor the location being used for System A's exports. This import profile must also define the location of the commit file and the location and contents of the confirm file used by System A. The confirm file must contain the export job signature to allow System A to confirm when the process completes. Both commit and confirm files must be written to a mutually accessible location, which does not have to be the same as for the System A exports. For more information, see Importing System Configuration for Automatic Imports . System A must have an automatic import profile, which will be monitored and is used to import the confirmation files generated by System B. This profile does not create any commit/confirm files. System B will use the export job signature written into the confirm file by System A in order to complete the export-import process. For more information, see Exporting System Configuration for Import Confirmations . Importing System Configuration for Automatic Imports The importing VideoManager must be configured to automatically detect and import exported files from another exporting VideoManager. This requires configuring an import profile to detect when a new export is ready to be imported by the importing VideoManager, and creating the files used by the exporting VideoManager to verify when the import has completed. Once an automatic import profile is created, VideoManager uses it to automatically detect and import any files matching the given profile and at the specified, to be monitored, location. To configure an import profile, see Configuring Import Profiles . Field values The key fields for configuring an automatic export are: Profile is a JSON file defining properties used for the import of files. It requires specification of a monitorPath . The importing VideoManager observes this location, and all subdirectories, to detect when the exporting VideoManager places new exports within it, which is indicated by a *.exportcompletion file being written. An archivePath must also be defined. When cleanupMode is "MOVE" , imported files are archived at that location. The filters property is used to exclude any files not to be imported, including the exportcompletion file. For more information, see Exporting System Configuration for Import Confirmations . Commit file path is a FreeMarker template which, when rendered, defines the absolute path for writing the commit file. Both the commit and confirm file paths will be partially rewritten as part of creating the files, such that the commit/confirm files are placed in a subdirectory identified by the import signature. For example, if a path is configured at c:\test\READY , the actual file will be written to c:\test\{exportSignature}\READY . Confirmation file path is a FreeMarker template defining the absolute path for writing the confirmation file. The filename should end with the extension exportcompletion . Confirmation file contents is a FreeMarker template defining the contents of the confirmation file. The FreeMarker should resolve to JSON and include a mapping for the exportSignature , which is used to indicate completion of the import to the exporting system. Automatic import should be set to On to allow VideoManager to apply the new profile towards detecting and importing new files in the monitored location(s). Example of the Import Profile In the following example, the profile will monitor the path c:\\test_auto_import\\export_to for any new subdirectories to import. Completed imports, due to "cleanupMode": "MOVE" , will be moved into the archivePath . { "owner":admin", "cleanupMode": "MOVE", "archivePath": "C:\\test_auto_import\\import_archive\\{name}", "moni torPath": "C:\\test_auto_import\\export_to", "maxRetries": 3, "filters": [ { "pattern": "*.exportconfirmation" } ] } Example of the FreeMarker Template for Commit File Path C:\\test_auto_import\\import_confirmation\\${exportJobSignature}_confirmation\\READY Example of the Confirmation Path C:\\test_auto_import\\import_confirmation\\${exportJobSignature}_confirmation\\export.exportcompletion Example of the Commit File Contents { "exportSignature": "${exportJobSignature}"<#if (media[0])??>, "url": "${publicWebUri}/app/videos/${media[0].mediaId}/info"</#if> } Note: The above example uses FreeMarker conditionals to only render the URL if there is a media item in the import to link to. If so, the IRL is the first media file in the list. Corresponding Exporting System Profile For reference, the matching profile in the exporting system is as follows: Profile { "owner": "admin", "requires": "READY", "cleanupMode": "DELETE", "archivePath": "C:\\test_auto_import\\export_confirm_archive", "monitorPath": "C:\\test_auto_import\\import_confirmation", "monitorDetectionPattern": ".*confirmation", "maxRetries": 3, "filters": [ { "pattern": ". *exportcompletion" } ] } The exporting system auto-import profile does not require values to be set for the commit path, confirm path or confirm contents. Further References FreeMarker Template Field Values The import process creates a key:value map, subsequently used to populate variables within the FreeMarker templates defined in the import profile for commit file path, confirmation file path, and confirmation file contents. When the import contains non-sidecar metadata files, the key:value entries within will also be extracted and exposed for use in rendering FreeMarker. The import must provide an *.exportconfirmation file in the JSON format, used to determine the exportJobSignature. The import will fail if the file is not present, as the value is necessary to the file that notifies the exporting system when the import job has completed. predetermined location, populating it with a special metadata file. The auto-importer of the exporting system scans this location for new folders matching a pattern specified in the profile, ingests the metadata, and completes the export, while populating the "url" of the export job. Generation of Import Confirmations exportcompletion File Naming The metadata file should have the file extension .exportcompletion . The rest of the filename is not important to the importer, but may usefully contain other information about the export or importing system. exportcompletion File Format The confirmation file is in the form of a JSON text file and must have the following properties: exportSignature is the signature of the export you want to confirm the import of. url is the URL in the destination system for this export. An example of the file content: { "exportSignature": "abc123", "url": "http://server.host:9080/link/to/media/12345" } Generation of Subfolders The contents of the subfolder should also include a "requires" file that triggers the importer to begin processing the folder. The file should be created in the subfolder after the creation of the .exportcompletion file. It is important that a separate file is used for this purpose, otherwise the importer could attempt to read the .exportcompletion file before it has been fully written to the subfolder. The following example shows a possible layout of a generated subfolder: export_abc123_20230713162000_confirmed/ abc123.exportcompletion READY Ingestion of Import Confirmations The export system runs an automatic importer to scan for import confirmations from the other system, which requires the configuration of an automatic import profile. Import Profile On the export system, you must create an automatic import profile. The profile should include "requires" , "monitorDetectionPattern" , and "filters" properties. The following is an example of such import profile: { "owner": "USER", "requires": "READY", "cleanupMode": "MOVE", "archivePath": "/import_confirmation_archives/{name}-{sign}", "monitorPath": "/import_confirmations", "monitorDetectionPattern": ".*confirmed", "maxRetries": 3, "filters": [ { "pattern": "*.exportcompletion" } ] } owner is a valid system user. requires is the filename to detect in the subfolder, which triggers the import. In the example above, an appearance of a file called READY triggers the importer to process the subfolder. monitorDetectionPattern is an expression which matches the name of the subfolder containing the confirmation data. In the example above, the importer detects any subfolder with a suffix of "confirmed". For example, a subfolder named export_abc123_20230713162000_confirmed would be presumed to contain the relevant data, but a subfolder named export_abc123_20230713162000 would not, and would be ignored. filters shoud be set to use the pattern *.exportcompletion , which will allow the importer to correctly identify and process the confirmation file. As usual for automatic imports, other properties can be configured : cleanupMode specifies what should happen to the imported directory after completion of the import. For a standard direct mode import, the default is NONE , that is, tile directory is left where it is. For autoimports, the default is RENAME , which attempts to rename the directory and applies any formatting defined in archivePath . If the renamed directory already exists, the import job signature is usually applied as a suffix. Other options are MOVE and DELETE . DELETE attempts to completely remove the directory while MOVE attempts to move the directory to a location specified by archivePath . archivePath is a location and/or some filename formatting to be applied during the cleanup phase of an import. Tags include {name} for the original directory name, {sign} for the import job signature, {year} for the current year ( 2018 ), {month} for the current month ( 05 ), and {day} for the current day ( 03 }. monitorPath is the main directory the importer monitors for new import subfolders. Configuring VideoManager for Export Confirmation Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Exports section. Perform one of the following actions: In the Export Profiles section, click Create new export profile . For more information, see Creating DVD Export Profiles , Creating MP4 Export Profiles , or Creating Evidence Export Profiles . In the Export Profiles section, next to the relevant profile, click Edit export profile . From the Export location drop-down list, select Directory and set a path. Ensure that the path has write access and is visible for both systems, including export/import grid workers. Set Await export confirmation to Yes . Note: Enabling this setting without setting up a confirmation mechanism prevents exports from completing. Optional: If you want the export to include an incident metadata file, in the Export metadata section, set Add metadata file to On . To create an export, select the incident with some clips in it and select Export Incident . For more information, see Searching Incidents . The export begins. You can find your export in the My Exports pane in the Incidents tab. The export displays the Awaiting Confirmation status until the importing system acknowledges that the export was successfully imported. Once the importing system acknowledges a successful import, the export completes and the status changes to Ready . If available, you can copy the destination URL by clicking Copy destination URL next to the export. You can also access the URL from the Destination URL section in the Export details page. Testing the Export-Import Feedback Mechanism Prerequisites: Ensure that you have two VideoManager systems. Ensure that the shared storage is visible by the two instances. It can be a folder in the local machine. Create parent folders manually. Note: The path set in monitorPath , archivePath , commit file path , and confirm file path must exist. You must create the necessary folders to make the paths available to the systems. Procedure: Configure an Export Evidence export profile. For more information, see Configuring VideoManager for Export Confirmation . Configure an import profile by performing the following actions: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Import Profiles section. Click Create new profile . Set the profile name and the profile details. For more information, see Configuring Import Profiles . For example: { "owner": "{vmgr-user}", "requires": "READY", "cleanupMode": "MOVE", "archivePath": "D:\\SharedData\\confirmations_archive\\{name}-{sign}", "monitorPath": "D:\\SharedData\\confirmations\\", "maxRetries": 3, "filters": [ { "pattern": "*.exportcompletion" } ] } Set Automatic import to On . Click Save Profile . The export system (System A) scans any subfolders under D:\\SharedData\\confirmations\\ for a commit file called READY and imports any file with extension exportcompletion . Configure an import profile by performing the following actions: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Import Profiles section. Click Create new profile . Set the profile name and the profile details. For more information, see Configuring Import Profiles . For example: { "owner": "{vmgr-user}", "requires": "Commit.txt", "cleanupMode": "MOVE", "archivePath": "D:\\SharedData\\exports_archive\\{name}-{sign}", "monitorPath": "D:\\SharedData\\exports", "maxRetries": 3 } Enter the commit file path and name. For example: D:\\SharedData\\confirmations\\READY or D:/SharedData/confirmations/READY Enter the confirmation file name with exportcompletion as the extension. For example: D:\\SharedData\\confirmations\\{filename}.exportcompletion or D:/SharedData/confirmations/{filename}.exportcompletion Set the confirmation file contents. Note: It is important to have at least the export job signature. Otherwise, it will not work. For example: { "exportSignature": "${exportJobSignature}" <#if media??> , "url": "${publicWebUri}/app/videos/${media[0].mediaId}/info" </#if> } Set Automatic import to On . Click Save Profile . The import system scans any subfolders under D:\\SharedData\\exports and imports any contents inside them. After the import is successful, it generates the commit and confirmation files to let the exporting system know that the import was successful. The content of the confirmation file contains a url which is the URL of the importing system. The URL is visible in the exporting system. For more information, see Configuring VideoManager for Export Confirmation . Note: In some scenarios, the shared space is located in the network. If this is the case, the absolute path will be in the form of either \\\\vmware-host\\Shared Folders\\ or //vmware-host/Shared Folders/SharedFolder . Configuring the Playback Policy You can control whether, after a certain time, media files cannot be viewed on VideoManager without the user first recording their reason for viewing, and whether all media files on VideoManager have a watermark when played back. Prerequisites: Create a media playback reason field. This action enables users to provide their reason for rewatching media files. If a media playback reason field is not created after the playback policy is configured, then users must still acknowledge that they are rewatching a media file after a certain amount of time has elapsed, but VideoManager does not prompt them for a reason. For more information, see Creating Media Playback Reason Fields . Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Playback Policy section. If you want users to record their reason for watching a media file after a set number of days, set Enable playback reason auditing to On . In the Require media playback reason section, enter the number of days since the media file was recorded, after which a user must give a reason for watching it. From the Protection mode drop-down list, select one of the following options: If you want to enable authenticated and authorised users to use download tools, select Disabled . If you want to protect videos against download tools running on modern web browsers only, select Default protection . If you want to protect videos against download tools running on modern web browsers and reject play attempts from older web browsers, select Strict protection . Note: If you select Strict protection , all users must be on modern web browsers in order to play videos. Click Save settings . Configuring Player You can select the default quality at which media files are played in the VideoManager player. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Playback Policy section. From the Default quality drop-down list, select the default media file quality. The options are as follows: Highest , Standard , Low , Lower , Very low , and Lowest . Click Save settings . Any changes come into effect only when you log on again or when you refresh the page. Users who have the Control playback quality permission enabled can override this default when they watch media files from the Media tab. Users without the permission must watch all media files from the Media tab in the selected quality. For more information, see Viewing Media Files . Configuring Playback Watermarks You can customise the playback video by adding different watermarks in different positions. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Playback Watermark section. Set Enable playback watermarking to On . The Standard watermark and Tiled watermark panes display. The tiled watermark displays diagonally over the video. Depending on the watermark, you can configure different parameters. In the Text box, enter the text to be displayed. Next to the Text box, click and from the drop-down list, select which live field you want to add to the text. The options are: Playback signature , Username , Date , and Time . From the Size drop-down list, select the desired size of the watermark. From the Background opacity drop-down list, select the desired opacity level of the watermark background. From the Font opacity drop-down list, select the desired opacity level of the font. From the Text colour drop-down list, select the desired colour of the text. From the Position drop-down list, select where the watermark should be displayed. Optional: To delete the watermark, next to the watermark to be deleted, click . Optional: To add more standard watermarks, click Add watermark . Click Save settings . Configuring Thumbnails You can utilise markdown to create a phrase that will appear in the place of a thumbnail for media files that were imported without a built-in thumbnail. The following procedure describes how to edit the custom thumbnails for imported media files. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Thumbnails section. Edit any of the following fields: Audio file expression dictates the default thumbnail for audio media files. PDF file expression dictates the default thumbnail for PDF media files. Other files expression dictates the default thumbnail for other types of media files. There are some thumbnail-specific functions that you can input. The functions are as follows: \n creates a line break. + strings multiple values together. text() returns a string representation of whatever input it is given. This could be a number, or dates. formatInterval() rearranges a number of seconds into a more readable format. For example, formatInterval(100) would return 1m40s . Note: The expression entered is formatted with markdown. Click Save settings . Configuring Video Metadata Overlay Settings VideoManager enables you to add metadata to recorded media. This metadata is stored in the media file and can be displayed in an overlay during playback and export. These settings apply to all media files recorded by devices whose device profiles have been configured to include metadata. Note: GPS performance may vary depending on location, usage, and other conditions. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Media and Playback pane. Click the Video Metadata Overlay Settings section. To add a metadata element to the media file overlay, scroll down to the bottom of the pane, and from the Add element drop-down list, select an element. Note: The order in which you choose the metadata elements determines the order in which the elements appear when a media file is played (left to right). Not all devices display all options. The element options are as follows: Search: Column Export to Excel Export to CSV Name Description Device serial number The serial number of the device on which the media was recorded. Operator name The name of the operator who recorded the media. You can configure how many characters of the name should be visible over the media file, and how many spaces should be added to "pad" the name out to a minimum size. Date and time You can configure the following: Timezone UTC – Greenwich Mean Time, but without adjustments for day-light savings time Local Time – taken from the server of VideoManager Time & date format sets the format for date and time metadata. The options are as follows: ISO standard 8601 – If selected, the time and date is presented in an internationally standardised manner. Custom – If selected, more options are presented, as detailed below: Time display – 24-Hour Display (for example, 19:00) or 12-Hour Display With AM/PM Markers (for example, 12AM) Timezone display – None , Show time zone offset In hours:minutes (for example, +01:00), or Show time zone name (for example, GMT) Date format – DD/MM/YY , MM/DD/YY , YY/MM/DD , DD-MM-YY , MM-DD-YY , or YY-MM-DD Years format – YY (for example, '19'), or YYYY (for example, '2019') Frame counter Shows the user which frame is currently being shown in the playback viewer. Recording time Shows the length of the recording. You can configure whether the recording time should start from when the operator pressed the record, or when the first frame was actually recorded. If you select the former option, any pre-recorded media appears as negative time in the metadata overlay, for example, -00:23:45. Pre/Post-record marker Indicates which part of the media file has been pre-recorded or post-recorded, if any. Text You can enter text to give more information about the device, operator, and more. Unlike other elements, you can add as many Text elements as necessary. GPS Displays the latitude and longitude of the device. You can enable the following settings: If you set Include speed to On , the speed of the device is displayed in meters per second. If you set Include track to On , the track of the device is displayed in degrees. Device name The name of the device, as configured from the Edit device properties pane. Battery level The level of battery of the device when it recorded the media. Optional: To delete a metadata element, click Delete element . The deleted element returns to the drop-down list, and can be reselected for use again. To save the changes, click Save settings . These changes affect all devices whose device profile has Show video metadata overlay set to On . The changes do not apply retroactively to media files that have already been recorded. Exporting and Importing Incident Fields If you have multiple instances of VideoManager, you can transfer a copy of your incident fields from one instance to another. Procedure: In the original instance of VideoManager, navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Fields section. Click Export . The incident fields are saved to the default download location of your PC. In the new instance of VideoManager (or a site, if User-defined Fields has been set to Off in the Metadata/Footage Replication section), navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Fields section. Click Import . Select the previously downloaded incident fields. Click Import . Alternatively, if you want to import all of your incident fields simultaneously, you can do so from the Import/Export System Config section of the System pane, in the Admin tab. For more information, see Exporting and Importing the Configuration of VideoManager . Creating and Applying Validators You can control the format of information entered into incident fields. This action can be done through the creation of validators, which can be configured to accept certain patterns and reject others, for example, a UK postcode or a URL. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Fields section. Click Edit validators . Click Create validator . In the Identifier field, enter a unique name for the validator. In the Description field, enter the text which users should see when populating a incident field. The description should detail the format to which the incident field should adhere. In the Pattern field, enter the pattern of the validator. This action should be done utilising regular expressions. Optional: If you want the validator to ignore the case of the text entered into the incident field, set Case insensitive to On . If set to Off , the case of the text entered into the incident field must match that of the Pattern field. Optional: If you want to test the validator, in the Test text field, enter the example text. VideoManager determines whether the example text would be accepted by the validator or not. Click Confirm . Postrequisites: After validators have been created, they must be individually applied to incident fields to ensure that the incident fields obey the patterns detailed in the validators. This action must be done during incident field creation. Validators cannot be edited after a incident field has been created. For more information, see Creating Incident Fields . Reordering Incident Fields You can reorder incident fields, which changes the order in which they are presented during incident creation. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Fields section. Click Reorder fields . Grab the left-hand side of the relevant incident field and drag it to the desired location in the list. Click Confirm . When users create an incident, the incident fields to be populated are presented in the same order that has been configured here. For more information, see Creating Incidents Manually and Performing Incident Actions . Creating Incident Fields VideoManager comes with some built-in incident fields, which enable users to categorise incidents. Administrators can also create their own incident fields and edit built-in fields to reflect the unique needs of their organisation. Prerequisites: Before you create new incident fields, you can create validators, which define how information entered into incident fields must be formatted, for example, as a UK postcode. For more information, see Creating and Applying Validators . If the new incident field should show users a different display name based on their session language, you should change the language for your own session before you create the field so that it does not match the server language of VideoManager. This action can be done from either the account menu or the Language section. For more information, see Configuring the Language on VideoManager . Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Fields section and perform one of the following action s : If you are creating an incident field which users must populate while creating an incident, click Create field . If you are creating a incident field which users must populate before deleting an incident, scroll to the Incident Deletion Fields section and click Create field . In the Identifier field, enter an identifier for the incident field. The identifier should be all lowercase, and unique. In the Display name field, enter a display name for the incident field. The display name is what the incident field is called in the VideoManager UI. Note: An optional second display name field appears if your session language does not currently match the server language of VideoManager. The field enables you to enter a display name for the field in both languages. If the display name should be set in more than two languages, you must complete the field, save it, then change your session to the third language and edit the field. From the Type drop-down list, select the type of a incident field to be created: Search: Column Export to Excel Export to CSV Name Description Text In this incident field, users can enter text related to the incident, which is useful if users need to search for a specific phrase or word, such as Assault , Arrest , and more. Text List In this incident field, users can select one or more texts related to the incident. Date In this incident field, users can select a date related to the incident. Date & Time In this incident field, users can select a date and time related to the incident. Drop down In this incident field, users can select an option from a drop-down list related to the incident. Check box In this incident field, users can either select or unselect a check box related to the incident. URL In this incident field, users can enter a URL related to the incident. Computed In this incident field, users can create URLs from previously created incident fields. Administrators can also configure computed fields to appear, and change their appearance, based on how other incident fields are populated. Tag List In this incident field, users can select one or more tags related to the incident. Auto-delete In this incident field, users can enter the conditions for auto-delete and the date when the incident should be automatically deleted. Note: The type of incident field cannot be changed later. Optional: If you do not want users to be able to save an incident unless they populate the field, set Mandatory to On . From the Permission group drop-down list, select to which access group the incident field should apply. Any users in the selected access group are able to view and edit the incident field when creating and editing incidents. If all users should be able to utilise the incident field when creating and editing incidents, you can select Public . Computed fields do not need to have the same permission groups as the other incident fields that determine whether they appear or not. For example, if only some administrators should be able to populate the review-status field with sensitive information, but all users should be able to see the more general reviewed-already computed field, review-status could be set to Access Group One , while reviewed-already could be set to Public . From the Column width drop-down list, select how wide the column of the incident field should appear in incident search results. This action is only relevant if the incident field is configured to appear in the incident search results pane. For more information, see Configuring User-Defined Field Layouts . Depending on the type of incident field to be created, perform one of the following actions: If you have selected Text , see Creating Text Fields . If you have selected Text List , see Creating Text List Fields . If you have selected Date , see Creating Date Fields . If you have selected Date & Time , see Creating Date and Time Fields . If you have selected Drop down , see Creating Drop Down Fields . If you have selected Check box , see Creating Check Box Fields . If you have selected URL , see Creating URL Fields . If you have selected Computed , see Creating Computed Fields . If you have selected Tag List , see Creating Tag List Fields . If you have selected Auto-delete , see Creating Auto-Delete Fields . You can: Export incident fields from one instance of VideoManager, and import them into another instance. For more information, see Exporting and Importing Incident Fields . Editing Default Incident Fields You can create incident fields to meet unique needs of your organisation. However, VideoManager comes with two types of built-in incident field, which can be edited as well. The steps for editing default fields differ, depending on the type of field. Default incident fields, which are manually populated by users when creating incidents, can have every aspect of their configuration edited, which is similar to non-default incident fields. These aspects are the following fields: Title , Incident time , Reference code , and Notes . Default incident fields which are automatically populated by VideoManager when the incident is saved can only have specific aspects of their configuration edited. These aspects are the following fields: Creation time , Update time , Clip count , Owner , and Signature , and have an icon next to their display names. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Fields section. Next to the relevant default field, click Edit field . Perform one of the following actions: You can edit any of the following criteria. They are not mandatory. Option Actions Editing an incident field that is manually populated In the Identifier field, enter an updated identifier for the incident field. The identifier should be all lowercase, and unique. In the Display name field, enter an updated display name for the incident field. If you want users to be unable to save an incident unless they populate this field, set Mandatory to On . From the Permission group drop-down list, select to which access group this incident field should apply. Any users in the selected access group will be able to view this incident field when creating and editing incidents. From the Column width drop-down list, select how wide the column for the incident field should appear in incident search results. This action is only relevant if the incident field is configured to appear in the incident search results pane. For more information, see Configuring User-Defined Field Layouts . Depending on the type of incident field that is being edited, edit other settings: If you are editing the title , reference-code , or notes field, you can change the configuration in the Text section. For more information, see Creating Text Fields . If you are editing the incident-time field, you can change the configuration in the Date & Time section. For more information, see Creating Date and Time Fields . Editing a incident field which is automatically populated by VideoManager In the Display name field, enter an updated display name for the incident field. From the Permission group drop-down list, select to which access group this incident field should apply. Any users in the selected access group will be able to view this incident field when creating and editing incidents. From the Column width drop-down list, select how wide the column for the incident field should appear in incident search results. This action is only relevant if the incident field is configured to appear in the incident search results pane. For more information, see Configuring User-Defined Field Layouts . If you do not want the incident field to be visible when users edit and view incidents, set Show in summary to No . Click Save settings . Editing Incident Clip Field Visibility When a media file is added to an incident, it becomes an incident clip. Incident clips have four properties: Operator , Origin , Duration , and Notes . By default, all users on VideoManager can see these four fields. However, administrators can restrict which fields can be seen by users, based on the users' permission groups. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Fields section. Scroll to the Incident Clip Fields section, and next to the field to be edited, click View field . There are four fields – one for each incident clip property. From the Permission group drop-down list, select which users should be able to view the incident clip property. By default, the drop-down list is set to Public , meaning that all users on VideoManager and anyone with an incident link can view this property. The administrator can select a specific permission group from the drop-down list, so users can only view this property if one of their roles has this permission group enabled. For more information, see Field Permissions . Note: The administrator cannot edit the incident clip field further. Incident clip fields cannot be deleted, either. Click Save settings . Postrequisites: You can configure which of these fields are visible when viewing an incident link. For more information, see Configuring Incident Sharing . Incident Fields and Rules Configuration for the M500/M500E After you have conﬁgured media ﬁelds for the M500/M500E, you can dictate whether these ﬁelds are synchronized to corresponding incident ﬁelds, meaning they will be visible in an incident form containing the video, and whether VideoManager will automatically create incidents from videos tagged as critical. Creating an M500/M500E Event Category Incident Field The M500/M500E event category media ﬁeld enables operators to categorise recordings on the M500/M500E itself. However, by default, the value selected in this ﬁeld only appears alongside the individual recording, and it does not appear in incidents the recording is added to. To synchronize this media ﬁeld, so that its value appears in associated incidents, you must create a new incident ﬁeld. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Fields section. In the top right-hand corner, click Create field . In the Identifier field, enter EventCategory Note: The identiﬁer must be set to EventCategory , or the two ﬁelds will not synchronize. In the Display name field, enter a display name for the incident field. The display name is what the incident field is called in the VideoManager UI. Note: An optional second display name field appears if your session language does not currently match the server language of VideoManager. The field enables you to enter a display name for the field in both languages. If the display name should be set in more than two languages, you must complete the field, save it, then change your session to the third language and edit the field. From the Type drop-down list, select Drop down . If you want users to complete this field before they can proceed, set Mandatory to Yes . From the Permission group drop-down list, select which access group should be able to see this field when viewing the video on VideoManager. From the Column width drop-down list, select how much space this field should take up when displayed on VideoManager. Scroll down to the Drop down section and recreate all of the values of the EventCategory media field by clicking in the top right-hand corner, and adding each value one by one. Note: The incident ﬁeld must have the exact same values as the media ﬁeld, or the two ﬁelds will not synchronize. For more information, see 10 in the Editing the M500/M500E Event Category Media Field . Optional: To conﬁgure whether the ﬁeld only appears in the Edit properties pane of a video when another drop down ﬁeld or check box ﬁeld has been populated in a speciﬁc manner, scroll down to the Conditions section and perform the following actions: Ensure that there is at least one drop down ﬁeld or check box ﬁeld on VideoManager already. Conditions can only be used on these ﬁelds. In the top right-hand corner, click New condition . From the Field drop-down list, select which drop down ﬁeld or check box ﬁeld should dictate the appearance of this ﬁeld. From the Value drop-down list, select which values of the drop down ﬁeld or check box ﬁeld should dictate the appearance of this ﬁeld. Procedure: In the original instance of VideoManager, navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Share Reason Fields section. Click Export . The incident share reason fields are saved to the default download location of your PC. In the new instance of VideoManager (or a site, if User-defined Fields has been set to Off in the Metadata/Footage Replication section), navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Creating and Applying Validators You can control the format of information entered into incident share reason fields. This action can be done through the creation of validators, which can be configured to accept certain patterns and reject others, for example, a UK postcode or a URL. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Share Reason Fields section. Click Edit validators . Click Create validator . In the Identifier field, enter a unique name for the validator. In the Description field, enter the text which users should see when populating an incident share reason field. The description should detail the format to which the incident share reason field should adhere. In the Pattern field, enter the pattern of the validator. This action should be done utilising regular expressions. Optional: If you want the validator to ignore the case of the text entered into the incident share reason field, set Case insensitive to On . If set to Off , the case of the text entered into the incident share reason field must match that of the Pattern field. Optional: If you want to test the validator, in the Test text field, enter the example text. VideoManager determines whether the example text would be accepted by the validator or not. Click Confirm . Postrequisites: After validators have been created, they must be individually applied to incident share reason fields to ensure that the incident share reason fields obey the patterns detailed in the validators. This action must be done during incident share reason field creation. Validators cannot be edited after a incident share reason field has been created. For more information, see Creating Incident Share Reason Fields . Reordering Incident Share Reason Fields Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Share Reason Fields section. Click Reorder fields . Grab the left-hand side of the relevant media field and drag it to the desired location in the list. Click Confirm .
