The options are as follows: For all incident levels – There are separate metadata files for the main incident and the nested incidents. Only the main incident – There is only a metadata file for the main incident. Only nested incidents – There is only a metadata file for the nested incidents. In the Metadata filename template field, enter the filename template for the metadata file. In the Metadata content template field, enter the content template for the metadata file. If Include commit file is set to Yes , a file is created and exported that indicates the export has been completed. Original footage Controls what original media is exported alongside the incident. It is only visible if Include original footage is set to Yes . If Use template for filename is set to On , you must enter a filename template in the Filename template field. If Add metadata file is set to On , there are separate metadata files for each original piece of media. You must enter a metadata filename template and content template in the Metadata filename template and Metadata content template fields, respectively. Clip footage Controls what clipped media are exported alongside the incident It is only visible if Include clip footage is set to Yes . lf Use template for filename is set to On , you must enter a filename template in the Filename template field. If Add metadata file is set to On , there are separate metadata files for each incident clip. You must enter a metadata filename template and content template in the Metadata filename template and Metadata content template fields, respectively. You can set Include transcription PDF to On . You can configure other aspects of an evidence bundle. These aspects are controlled through toggles. The toggles in the left-hand column control whether the features are enabled, and the toggles in the right-hand Overridable? column control whether users can override the predetermined configuration when exporting an incident. If Watermark logo is set to Yes , the export includes the previously configured watermark over the media in the incident. This option can be configured in the Theme section. For more information, see Theme . If Watermark signature is set to Yes , the automatically created signature of the export is shown over the media of the incident. This option corresponds with the information shown in the Job column in the My Exports pane. If Include original footage is set to Yes , the export includes the original, full-length media from which the incident clips were taken. If Include clip footage is set to Yes , the export includes the clips of the incident. If Include confidential metadata is set to Yes , the export includes the fields of the incident as a JSON file. This action is useful if the user is planning to upload the incident to another instance of VideoManager. This action allows VideoManager to automatically populate the incident fields when the incident is uploaded. If Single file per incident clip is set to Yes , the export includes every redacted incident clip as individual media files instead of one long media file. Click Save settings . Configuring Incident Sharing Users can share incidents externally using a link. Administrators can configure which email address these links are sent to, if most or all links will be sent to the same address. Administrators can also set the default expiry time for a link, after which the incident becomes inaccessible to anyone who does not have an account on VideoManager, and configure which incident clip fields are visible in a link. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Sharing section. In the Default email address field, enter the email address, which should be the default recipient for incident links. Users can override this email address when creating a link from the Incidents tab. In the Default expiry time field, enter the default number of days for which a link should be active, before it expires. Users can override this expiry time when creating a link from the Incidents tab. For more information, see Sharing Incidents Externally Using a Link . Optional: In the Incident link visible fields section, configure which incident clip fields are visible when an incident is shared via an incident link. This action depends on which incident clip fields are visible to specific permission groups, as configured in the Incident Fields section. For example, if the Operator field is configured so that only users in permission group one can view it, then you could enable Access Group One here. This means that the Operator property would be visible in the incident link. For more information, see Editing Incident Clip Field Visibility . Click Save settings . Configuring Incident Settings If VideoManager was upgraded to 17.0 or higher, media files, which have been added to an incident, that is incident clips, are presented by default as separate clips within that incident, regardless of which recording they came from. However, you can configure VideoManager to present incident clips as children of the original recording they came from. This action enables other users on the system to directly compare the original recording to the redacted and shortened incident clips. If VideoManager was installed with 17.0 or higher, incident clips are presented by default as children of the original recording they came from. However, you can configure VideoManager to present incident clips as separate clips within that incident, regardless of which recording they came from. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Incident Settings section. Set Group incident clips by recording to either Yes or No . From the Incident label field drop-down list, select a single custom field to be used to identify this incident. This must be a publicly visible, unconditional, single-line incident text field. Click Save settings . Note: This change applies retroactively to all incidents on the system. Enabling and Configuring Automatic Incident Creation You can configure VideoManager so that it automatically creates incidents, depending on how the media fields of a media file have been populated. Prerequisites: Ensure that the Media Properties and Incidents features are enabled on VideoManager. Contact your account manager to obtain these features. For more information, see Importing and Deleting Licences . Procedure: Create media fields as necessary. For more information, see Creating Media Fields . Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Incidents pane. Click the Auto Incident Creation section. Set Auto incident creation enabled to On . Optional: If you want an entire recording to be added to an automatically generated incident if one media file within it meets the requirements for automatic incident creation, set Use whole recording to On . If set to Off , a recording is not added to an incident if one of its media files meets the requirements for automatic incident creation. Instead, VideoManager only creates incidents for the individual media files that meet the requirements. In the Auto incident creation criteria field, use Motorola Solutions custom predicate language to determine which media fields should prompt VideoManager to create an incident automatically. For more information, see Custom Predicate Language . Click Save settings . User Interface In the User Interface pane, you can edit aspects of VideoManager relating to the appearance and layout of the user interface. From the User Interface pane, you can access the following sections: In the Dashboard Messages section, you can create messages that all users can view on their homepage. For more information, see Creating, Editing, and Deleting Messages . In the Theme section, you can change the logos displayed on VideoManager and its colour scheme. For more information, see Theme . In the Language section, you can change the default language in which the VideoManager user interface is displayed. For more information, see Configuring the Language on VideoManager . In the Tactical section, you can configure viewing options for the Tactical tab. For more information, see Configuring Tactical . Creating, Editing, and Deleting Messages Messages are displayed on the dashboard when a user logs on. From the appropriate pane, you can create, edit, and delete messages. Creating Messages Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Dashboard Messages section. Click Create message . In the Title field, enter a title for the message. The title appears in bold at the top of the message. From the Type drop-down list, select the type of message to be created. General – appears next to the message. Warning – appears next to the message. Tutorial – appears next to the message. In the Text field, enter the message. Optional: Customize the text using any of the following settings: Search: Column Export to Excel Export to CSV Name Description Bold Any text within the asterisks appears bold. Italic Any text within the underscores appears italicised. Heading Any text on the same line as ### appears as heading text. URL/Link You are prompted to enter a hyperlink. A link description can be entered in the square brackets. Image You can enter a URL for an image. An image description can be entered in the brackets. Unordered List Any text after the hyphen appears as part of a bullet point list. Unordered List must be clicked for each individual list entry. Ordered List Any text after the hyphen appears as part of a numbered list. Ordered List must be clicked for each individual list entry. The numbers appear in order once the message is previewed. Code Any text within the single quotation marks appears as code. Quote Any text on the same line as > appears as a quote. Clicking the buttons again undoes the changes. By clicking Preview , a previewable version becomes visible. You can edit the text by clicking Preview again. Optional: In the Link field, enter the address of another website. The address appears at the bottom of the message, and users can click on it to learn more about the message. Optional: If you want users to be able to hide the message on their own dashboard by clicking Hide , set User can hide to On . Note: This action only hides the message on the user's personal dashboard. Other users on VideoManager will still be able to see the message until they hide it themselves. Click Create message . Editing Messages Editing messages can be necessary if the content or formatting of the message should be changed. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Dashboard Messages section. Next to the message to be edited, click Go to message . Make the relevant changes and click Save message . Deleting Messages Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Dashboard Messages section. Next to the message to be deleted, click Delete message . In the confirmation window, click Yes . Theme You can specify certain aspects of images, colour scheme, and branding of VideoManager. There are two aspects to configuring theme resources: Changing colour scheme For more information, see Changing the Colour Scheme of VideoManager . Changing logos For more information, see Changing Logos of VideoManager . Changing the Colour Scheme of VideoManager You can change the colour scheme of VideoManager to match the corporate branding of an organisation. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Theme section. Next to the Colour scheme row, click Replace theme resource . You can enter a specific colour name as either a HTML/CSS colour name or a Hex code. For example, orangered and #ff4500 would produce the same colour in the UI. Alternatively, you can click the box on the right-hand side to choose the colour manually. Optional: In the General colours section, configure any of the following categories: Background colour changes the background colour of VideoManager. Text colour changes the colour of the text in body of VideoManager, as well as the colour of icons when the cursor is held over them. Link colour changes the colour of UI controls that take the user to a different page. For example, Find incidents . Dark areas changes the colour of pane headings. Light areas changes the colour of unselected heading options. Optional: In the Navigation Bar colours section, configure any of the following categories: Text colour changes the colour of unselected text in the main navigation bar. Background colour changes the colour of the background in the main navigation bar. Current section text colour changes the colour of the selected text in the main navigation bar. Current section background colour changes the colour of the selected background in the main navigation bar. Background colour (when mouse over) changes the colour of the background in the main navigation bar when the mouse is hovering over it. Optional: In the Media panel colours section, configure Header background colour (in incidents) . This option changes the colour of the headings for media files that are included in one or more incidents. To save the colour scheme, click OK . Optional: To reset the colour scheme, click Reset to defaults . Transfering Copies of the Colour Scheme Transfering a copy of a colour scheme from one instance of VideoManager to another can be necessary if the instance of VideoManager is acting as a Central VideoManager. Colour schemes in a Central VideoManager are not automatically updated in its respective sites. Procedure: On the original instance of VideoManager, navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Theme section. Next to the colour scheme to be exported, click Export . The colour scheme is downloaded to your PC. On the new instance of VideoManager (or a site), navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Theme section. Click Import . Select the previously downloaded colour scheme and click Import . Changing Logos of VideoManager Every instance of the Motorola Solutions logo can be replaced with still or animated images in .jpg, .jpeg, .png or .gif format. This action enables users to change logos of VideoManager to match the branding of their organisation. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Theme section. The options presented are as follows: Login background – The image used as the background when users log on Login logo – The image used in the top left-hand corner of the login box Navigation bar logo – The image visible in the top left-hand corner of the navigation bar along the top of the VideoManager user interface Export watermark logo – The image used as the watermark for exported incidents The image must be a PNG file with a transparent background. Favicon – The icon shown in the VideoManager tab The icon must be a file that is 16 x 16 pixels. PDF export logo – The image used in the PDF of an audit log Next to the image to be edited, click Replace theme resource . The Import theme resource window opens. Select Choose file . Select the file to be used, and click OK . The new graphics are updated immediately. Optional: To reset the logo, next to the icon to be reset, click Reset to default . Configuring the Language on VideoManager You can perform a range of actions regarding the language of VideoManager. You can change the language in which the VideoManager interface is presented to all users, as well as import new language files, and disable languages. Note: You must ensure that you have the permission to edit the Language section enabled. For more information, see Advanced Permissions . Changing the Server Language of VideoManager Server language is the default language in which all users navigate VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Language section. In the top pane, from the Server language drop-down list, select a language. Note: The server language cannot be deleted while it is acting as a server language. The English and Key language files cannot be deleted at all, even if they are not acting as a server language. Click Save settings . Ignoring the Browser Language at Login Ignoring the browser language at login can be useful if the browser running VideoManager is in one language, but users want to use it in another. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Language section. Set Ignore browser language at login to Yes . If set to No , VideoManager will try to use the browser language. Click Save settings . Changing the Language of the Current Session Changing the language of your current session is useful if you want to navigate VideoManager in a different language for the duration of your personal session. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Language section. Next to the relevant language, click Select language for current session . The language of VideoManager is changed only until you log out or your session expires. You can select your own language by clicking in the top right-hand corner and selecting Language . This selection is tied to your user only and permissions to do so must be configured by an administrator. The relevant permission is Select Language for login session , under Advanced permissions. Click Save settings . Importing Language Files Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Language section. Perform one of the following actions: If you want to import the language file to navigate VideoManager in that language, in the top right-hand corner of the User Interface language pane, select Import language file . If you want to import the language file to be able to change the language of an audit log, in the top right-hand corner of the Audit language pane, select Import audit language file . The Import language file window opens. Click Choose file , select the file to be imported, and click Import . Disabling Language Files If a language has been disabled, users cannot select it from their drop-down list. However, a disabled language can still be set as the server language of VideoManager, or the language for an individual's session. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Language section. Next to the relevant language or audit language file, click Enable / disable language . Set Enable language to No . Click Save changes . Changing the Language of Audit Logs Prerequisites: Ensure that you have the Audit log language and Select language for audit log permissions enabled to perform this procedure. For more information, see Advanced Permissions . Procedure: Import the relevant audit language file. For more information, see Importing Language Files . Next to the relevant audit language file, click Enable / disable language . The window opens. Set Enable language to Yes and click Save changes . Only languages that have been enabled at the moment of creating an audit log are available. Note: The content of an audit log remains in English. Only the template information is translated. In the top pane, from the Server language drop-down list, select a language in which you want the audit logs to be displayed and click Save settings . The server language is the default language of audit logs as well. For more information on audit logs, see Performing Audit Log Actions . Configuring Tactical Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the User Interface pane. Click the Tactical section. Perform any of the following actions: Set Show events panel to On . When enabled, the events panel displays at the bottom of the map in the Tactical tab, and lists device events. Set Show global video wall to On . When enabled, you can open the global video wall and add streams to it. Set Show user video wall to On . When enabled, you can open the user video wall and add streams to it. Click Save settings . Firmware In the Firmware pane, you can edit aspects of VideoManager relating to the device firmware. From the Firmware pane, you can access the following sections: In the Firmware Settings section, you can change global firmware settings, regarding auto-upgrades. For more information, see Configuring Firmware Settings . In the Device Firmware section, you can import , delete, and edit body worn device images. For more information, see Importing, Deleting, and Editing Images . In the Vehicle Firmware section, you can import , delete, and edit in-vehicle devices images. The procedure is the same as for body worn devices. For more information, see Importing, Deleting, and Editing Images . In the LTE Firmware section, you can import , delete, and edit LTE images. The procedure is the same as for body worn devices. For more information, see Importing, Deleting, and Editing Images . In the Dock Firmware section, you can import , delete, and edit dock images. The procedure is the same as for body worn devices. For more information, see Importing, Deleting, and Editing Images . Configuring Firmware Settings VideoManager can automatically upgrade devices when new firmware is released, which eliminates the need for users to manually upgrade their devices from the Devices tab. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Firmware pane. Click the Firmware Settings section. In the Auto-upgrade section, configure whether the devices, in-vehicle devices, docks, and EdgeControllers should be automatically upgraded by VideoManager to whichever firmware is set as the default. If set to Off , you must manually upgrade devices, in-vehicle devices, docks, and EdgeControllers from the Devices tab. Optional: If you have selected Auto-upgrade docks to On , in the From: and Until: fields, enter the times between which docks will attempt to upgrade. This action minimises disruption to the system. Note: If a dock is upgrading, all devices connected to it will be inaccessible until a dock has finished upgrading, which means that they cannot be assigned or allocated. In the Default firmware section, configure which firmware on VideoManager is set as the default. If Use latest firmware as default is set to On , the default images for devices, in-vehicle devices, docks, and EdgeControllers are automatically set to the most recent. The effect this action has depends on how the Auto-upgrade section is configured. If auto-upgrade is enabled for devices, they are upgraded to the most recent firmware automatically. If auto-upgrade is disabled for devices, the most recent firmware is presented as default when a user tries to upgrade them manually from the Devices pane. Users can override this default. Click Save settings . Importing , Deleting, and Editing Images Importing Images Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Firmware pane. Perform one of the following actions: Click Device Firmware . Click Vehicle Firmware . Click LTE Firmware . Click Dock Firmware . Click Import image . Select a file to import as a new image. Optional: If you want the image to become the default, set Default Image to On . When users upgrade a device from the Devices tab, this image will be presented first. However, users can change which image is used. This setting is only available if Use latest firmware as default is set to Off in the Firmware Settings section. For more information, see Configuring Firmware Settings . To confirm the choice, click OK . Deleting Images Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Firmware pane. Perform one of the following actions: Click Device Firmware . Click Vehicle Firmware . Click LTE Firmware . Click Dock Firmware . Next to the image to be deleted, click . Note: A default image cannot be deleted. Devices retain their images, even if the image has been deleted. To confirm deletion, click OK . Editing Images Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Firmware pane. Perform one of the following actions: Click Device Firmware . Click Vehicle Firmware . Click LTE Firmware . Click Dock Firmware . Next to the image to be edited, click . Optional: In the Name field, change the name of the image. Optional: If you want the image to become the default, set Default Image to On . When users upgrade a device from the Devices tab, this image will be presented first. However, users can change which image is used. This setting is only available if Use latest firmware as default is set to Off in the Firmware Settings section. For more information, see Configuring Firmware Settings . Optional: To learn more about the type of image and the hardware that the image can support, click More details . To confirm the changes, click Confirm . Security In the Security pane, you can manage certificates for improved authentication and secure communication between clients and servers. From the Security pane, you can access the following sections: In the VideoManager Certificate Authority section, you can create or import VideoManager certificate authorities as well as import trust anchors. For more information, see Performing VideoManager Certificate Authority Actions . In the Device Server Certificate Verification section, you can enable the device server certificate verification for the docks and select the security mode. For more information, see Enabling the Device Server Certificate Verification . In the Trusted Timestamping section, you can import, export, view, and delete certificate authorities. Certificate authorities validate media files and ensure they have not been tampered with. The actions are analogous to the ones described in Performing Device Certificate Authorities Actions . Performing VideoManager Certificate Authority Actions In the VideoManager Certificate Authority section, you can: Create or import a VideoManager certificate Note: Once you create or import a VideoManager certificate, the certificate cannot be replaced. If an incorrect certificate is uploaded, it cannot be undone. Import server or client trust anchors Server trust anchors are certificates used by clients (devices or docks) to authenticate the webserver certificate presented by the server (VideoManager). The trust anchors are usually root certificates. Client trust anchors are root certificates that can be used to authenticate clients from different authentication estates. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Security pane. Click the VideoManager Certificate Authority section. Perform one of the following actions: Option Actions Creating new certificate authorities Click Create new . VideoManager automatically populates the Common Name field with the public address + root CA . You can change the name, if you want. Optional:In the Organisation field, enter the name of your organisation. For example, Motorola Solutions Optional:In the Organisational unit field, enter the name of the department that the certificate authority is for. For example, Research and Development Click Create . Importing existing certificate authorities Click Import . Click Choose file . Note: Any imported certificate must be a certificate authority and must be accompanied by a private key. Both the certificate and private key must be packaged as a PKCS#12 file. Certificates issued by public certificate authorities are unlikely to be suitable for import. Usually, if you want to use your own certificate authority, you must create it yourself. Select the certificate and click Open . Click OK . To import a server or client trust anchor, perform the following actions: Next to the relevant trust anchor, click . Click . The window opens prompting you to choose a certificate file. Click Choose file . Note: Any imported certificate must be a certificate authority and must be accompanied by a private key. Both the certificate and private key must be packaged as a PKCS#12 file. Certificates issued by public certificate authorities are unlikely to be suitable for import. Usually, if you want to use your own certificate authority, you must create it yourself. Select the certificate and click Open . Click OK . Enabling the Device Server Certificate Verification Unverified devices are not secure and can pose security risks. Unverified devices are devices that are not enrolled, have expired certificates, belong to a different estate, are connected to the wrong site, or have outdated firmware. If you see an unverified device in your device list, contact your administrator for further investigation. If immediate action is necessary, depending on your permissions, you can factory reset or force offload data from unverified devices. You can perform those actions from the Devices tab by clicking View device info next to the relevant device. Note: VB400, V500, and V200 are the only devices that support device server certificate verification. Prerequisites: Ensure that you have created or imported a VideoManager certificate authority. For more information, see Performing VideoManager Certificate Authority Actions . Ensure that you have imported at least one trust anchor. For more information, see Performing VideoManager Certificate Authority Actions . Upgrade device firmware to V25.3 or later. Configure access control key authenticated devices to have their own listen address. For more information, see Migrating Access Control Key Authenticated Devices to New Addresses . Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the Security pane. Click the Device Server Certificate Verification section. Set Enable certificate verification to On . When enabled, all docked devices are automatically enrolled based on the current VideoManager certificate authority and server trust anchor(s). Note: If any changes are made to the VideoManager certificate authority, all devices will have to be factory reset. The following drop-down lists appear: Server security mode and Device security mode . Select the security mode for the server and/or the device. The options are as follows: In Open mode, if the device is unverified, data is offloaded as usual, and the device is not flagged. In Info mode, if the device is unverified, data is offloaded as usual, but the device is flagged. New devices can be added as long as they are connected to a trusted dock. In Normal mode, if the device is unverified, the device appears Locked and cannot offload data. New devices can be added as long as they are connected to a trusted dock. Click Save settings . System In the System pane, you can edit aspects of VideoManager relating to storage and server configuration. Note: The System pane should not be accessed unless the administrator has working knowledge of their PC. From the System pane, you can access the following sections: In the Deletion Policy section, you can configure when outdated media and incidents are automatically deleted. For more information, see Configuring Deletion Policies . In the Storage section, you can: Configure file containers, if you will be using S3 Object Storage or Azure Blob Storage instead of a filesystem. For more information, see Creating and Editing File Containers . Configure file spaces and free up space on an instance of VideoManager. For more information, see Performing File Spaces Actions . Configure file space warnings, which appear when one of the file spaces of VideoManager is almost full. For more information, see Configuring File Space Warnings . In the Reports section, you can configure when outdated reports are automatically deleted, and at what time of day scheduled reports are run. For more information, see Configuring Report Settings . In the Web Server section, you can: Configure web server settings and discover the public and listen addresses of the server For more information, see Configuring Listen and Public Addresses of VideoManager and Configuring SSL Certificates for Device Authentication . Access the migration wizard to migrate access control key authenticated devices to new addresses For more information, see Migrating Access Control Key Authenticated Devices to New Addresses . In the Backup Databases section, you can configure how often backups are performed. For more information, see Creating and Configuring Backup Databases . In the Licences section, you can import or renew licences. Licences determine which actions users can perform on VideoManager. For example, Tactical VideoManager is a licenced feature. For more information, see Importing and Deleting Licences . In the Advanced Settings section, you can configure the advanced settings file. For more information, see Advanced Settings Configuration . In the System Time Zone section, you can configure the system time zone of VideoManager. For more information, see Setting the System Time Zone of VideoManager . In the Import/Export System Config section, you can import or export key aspects of the configuration of VideoManager. For more information, see Exporting and Importing the Configuration of VideoManager . In the Preview Features section, you can preview features that are suitable for demonstration and field trial. In the Server Controls section, you can restart the server. This action allows certain changes to come into effect. For example, if the administrator has changed the server listen address of VideoManager. In the About section, you can view information about VideoManager related to legality and the terms of service. For more information, see Viewing Legal Information . Configuring Deletion Policies Deletion policies are used to control the way in which media, incidents, exports, and audit logs are automatically deleted from the system to free storage space. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Deletion Policy section. Click the Media section and configure any of the following: Name Description Retain media based on If Recording date or Offload date is set to On , enter the number of days for which media should be kept after it was recorded/offloaded before it is deleted. If Export status is set to On , the deletion policy is suspended for individual media files until they have been exported. After a media file has been exported, the original media file on VideoManager is subjected to the deletion policy like normal. Note: This option should not be enabled unless you have also enabled automatic incident exports, as determined from the Incident Exports section of the Incidents pane, in the Admin tab. Categories are set up in the Media Fields section using either a tag list or drop down field. For more information, see Creating Media Fields . If Category is set to On , select the category source from the drop-down list. You can manage your category sources from the Media Fields section. Each category has a Retention period and Start time . Retention period allows you to keep a specific category for a specified number of days, months or years. From the Start time drop-down list, you can choose between Recording date and Offload date after which the retention period begins. Note: Incidents always take precedence with deletion policies. Once removed from an incident, retention policy falls back to the media retention policy. Some devices enable users to bookmark media in the field, drawing attention to certain portions of media. If Bookmark status is set to On , from the drop-down list, select how bookmarked media should be treated by the deletion policy of VideoManager. From the drop-down list, you can select for how long bookmarked media should be kept: the same period as non-bookmarked media – If this option is selected, the deletion policy treats bookmarked and non-bookmarked media identically. specified amount of time – If this option is selected, you have the option to configure for how long bookmarked media is kept. The default is 90 days. If If it is part of a recording is set to On , an entire recording is kept if one media file within it has been added to an incident. If set to Off , only media files that have been added to incidents are preserved. The larger recording is subject to the deletion policy of VideoManager like normal. Overrides & recovery If Incident grace period is set to On , enter the number of days for which media is protected after it has been removed from an incident. Media in an incident is never deleted unless: It has been manually removed from the incident. The incident it is a part of has been deleted, in which case the media is subject to normal deletion policies. Forced deletion is set to On . If Recovery period is set to On , enter the number of days for which media is kept after deletion is requested, in case a media file has been deleted accidentally. If Forced deletion is set to On , media is deleted even if it is part of an incident. Normally, media is never deleted while it is part of an incident. Click the Incidents section and select one of the following: Search: Column Export to Excel Export to CSV Name Description Never delete incidents The default selection. Delete after a certain amount of time Allows you to specify the amount of time in days, months or years after the start date after which the incidents should be deleted. From the start date drop-down list, you can choose between Creation date , Earliest incident clip start time , and Latest incident clip start time . Delete based on their category Categories are set up in the Incident Fields section using either a tag list or drop down field. For more information, see Creating Incident Fields . Select the category source from the drop-down list. You can manage your category sources from the Incident Fields section. Each category has a Retention period and Start time . Retention period allows you to keep a specific category for a specified number of days, months or years. From the Start time drop-down list, you can choose between Creation date , Earliest incident clip start time , and Latest incident clip start time after which the retention period begins. Note: Incidents always take precedence with deletion policies. Once removed from an incident, retention policy falls back to the media retention policy. Use advanced configuration If selected, the deletion policy automatically deletes outdated incidents from VideoManager. There is some configuration involved: From the Incident Fields section, create a new incident field like normal. For more information, see Creating Incident Fields . From the Type drop-down list, select Computed Auto-delete . Note: There can only be one Computed auto-delete incident field per instance of VideoManager. If one already exists, this option is not visible in the drop-down list. In the Delete incident if field, enter the conditions under which this policy should go into effect, using the Motorola Solutions custom predicate language. The most simple input would be true , which would delete all incidents meeting the date specified in the Auto-deletion date field. For more information, see Custom Predicate Language . In the Auto-deletion date field, enter the relevant time period, which determines when an incident should be deleted, using the Motorola Solutions custom predicate language. The most simple input would be something similar to dateAdd( <6, day, creation-time> ) , which would delete incidents that are six days old. For more information, see Custom Predicate Language . Click Save settings . Navigate back to the Deletion Policy section. Set Automatically delete old incidents to On . If there are incidents to be deleted within the next seven days due to the policy configured in the Auto-deletion date field, you can preview these incidents by clicking <0> incidents will be scheduled for deletion over the next seven days . If there are incidents to be deleted immediately due to the policy configured in the Auto-deletion date field, you can preview these incidents by clicking <1> incident is scheduled for immediate deletion . Click Save settings . Click Yes, make these changes. and then, Yes again to save the changes. Result: The following toggle appears: Enable email alerts for incidents nearing deletion . If Enable email alerts for incidents nearing deletion is set to On , the User or group to notify field appears where you can add users or groups to receive email notifications for incidents scheduled to be deleted within 30 days. You should ensure that selected users or groups have valid emails. Note: To enable email alerts, you must enable email notifications. For more information, see Configuring Email Settings . Click the Exports section, set Automatically delete old exports to On and enter the number of days for which exports are kept after being created. If set to On , outdated exports on VideoManager are automatically deleted, even if the export has not yet been downloaded to the user's PC. Note: The original incident is never deleted, only the export is. Click the Audit logs section and configure any of the following: If Rolling audit log deletion is set to On , determine for how many days audit logs should be retained before they are automatically deleted by VideoManager. If Annual audit log deletion is set to On , determine for how many years an audit log entry should be retained before it is automatically deleted by VideoManager. The age of the audit log entry is calculated from midnight, January 1st. If a log entry is not the configured number of years old by that date, it is kept until the next year. For example, if the deletion policy is configured so that all entries are kept for one year, an audit log entry created on January 2nd 2020 will be deleted on January 1st 2022, because it was not one year old on January 1st 2021. Note: If both Rolling audit log deletion and Annual audit log deletion are set to On , audit logs are deleted in line with whichever policy sets the earlier deletion date. Click the Dashboard section and in the Show media scheduled to be deleted in <7> days field, enter the number of days within which a media file should be deleted, before it will show up on a user's dashboard. This setting only applies to users that have the View media scheduled to be deleted on dashboard permission set to Yes . Optional: Click Download change summary . This action downloads a CSV file directly to your PC. The file contains information about any changes to which media files and incidents should be deleted as a result of the new policy. Click Save settings . Creating and Editing File Containers If media and other data are stored in object storage instead of a file system, administrators must create file containers on VideoManager, which contain information about the object store. This action enables file spaces on VideoManager to connect to the cloud. Note: You can only perform this procedure if you are using Amazon S3 Object Storage or Azure Blob Storage. If you are using filesystem storage, you can skip this procedure. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Storage section. Click Create file container . In the Name field, enter a name for the file container. The file container will be identified by that name on VideoManager. From the Type drop-down list, select either S3 Object Storage or Azure Blob Storage . Perform one of the following actions: If… Then… If you are using S3 Object Storage, perform the following actions: In the Bucket name field, enter the bucket name. Motorola Solutions suggests using a unique fully qualified domain name of VideoManager In the Endpoint field, enter the endpoint of the file container. To check this information, you must open the AWS console, navigate to the Properties tab, and select the Bucket overview pane. In the Region section , make a note of the region. Then, you must enter the region in the Endpoint field, with the following format: s3. <region code> .amazonaws.com where <region code> is the region. Note: The endpoint must match the region where the bucket was created. In the Key and Secret fields, enter the key and secret of the IAM user, respectively. You can only get this information immediately after creating an IAM user with S3 access. If you do not have the key and secret for the IAM user, you must create another user and make a note of the key and secret's information, which is presented when the user is saved. If you are using Azure Blob Storage, perform the following actions: In the Container name field, enter the name of the container. You can either enter the name of a container that already exists in your Azure account, or enter the name for a new container. If a new container name is entered, Azure Blob Storage automatically creates the container. To check whether the action has been successful, on Azure, navigate to the Storage accounts tab, select the Storage account pane, and click the Containers section. The new container should be visible. In the Endpoint field, enter the endpoint of the file container. To check this information, in the Endpoints tab, you must click the Blob service pane, and copy and paste the value from the Blob service field. In the Account field, enter the name of the Azure Blob Storage account. In the Secret field, enter the secret of the container. To check this information, on Azure, you must navigate to the Access Keys tab, click Show keys , and copy and paste either of the keys. Click Confirm . Performing File Spaces Actions File spaces determine where files from VideoManager are stored, how much space VideoManager can use, and whether the files are encrypted when they are stored. Files can be stored on the administrator's PC (if administrators have accepted the default file space configuration, file spaces are stored on the PC with the path C:\ProgramData\Motorola Solutions\VideoManager. ), network-attached storage, or Amazon S3 Object Storage/Azure Blob Storage (if it has been purchased). It is important to note that some files, such as temporary files and config files, are always kept on the local hard drive, even if VideoManager has been configured to use a different kind of storage. Note: VideoManager only supports Amazon S3 Object Storage or Azure Blob Storage. Other kinds of object storage are not compatible and cannot be used to store files from VideoManager. Devices generate large numbers of very large files. It is important to consider how much storage capacity will be required and how much bandwidth the storage system will require, which is why Motorola Solutions recommends dedicated network-attached storage. When file spaces are full, associated system functions will stop working. For example, devices will be unable to download media files, and will enter an error state. You can administer your file spaces, which includes creating new file spaces, moving files within them, increasing their sizes, and deleting them. Creating File Spaces You can create new file spaces alongside existing ones. This action can be necessary if files should be stored in a different location, or if a file space of one type is becoming full and more space should be added. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Storage section. Click Create file space . The Create file space window opens. Enter the path for the new file space. If you have purchased S3 Object Storage or Azure Blob Storage, you should enter the name of a folder within the bucket, which will then be created. Note: If you are using a grid configuration, you must ensure that the path can be accessed by all workers in the grid. For more information about setting up grids with VideoManager, see VideoManager and Grids Explained . From the Category drop-down list, select a category for the file space. The options are as follows: Footage is where media on VideoManager are stored. Additionally, imported media files are stored here, too. Exports is where exports on VideoManager are stored. Reports is where reports on VideoManager are stored. Backups is where system backups on VideoManager are stored. Resources is where theme resources, such as logos, colour schemes, and device firmware, are stored on VideoManager. Import Workspace is where temporary files are stored. This option is only necessary if a grid system with import workers is being used with VideoManager. From the Container field, select the type of container for the file space. The options are as follows: Filesystem – The file space is contained in the filesystem. If you have created a file container whose details correspond to either a S3 Object Storage or Azure Blob Storage container, you can select either of these storages. In the Max size field, enter the maximum size that VideoManager should use in the file space. Motorola Solutions recommends that the maximum size is not set to the absolute upper limit of the disk/drive, as VideoManager will behave incorrectly when the disk/drive is completely full. Note: Because many object storage systems do not have a maximum capacity, this field ensures that storage costs are capped. From the State drop-down list, select a state for the file space. In most cases, the option is Online . The other options are as follows: OBSOLETE – Files in an obsolete file space are still available, but no new files will be written to the file space. OFFLINE – Usually, if a file space is unexpectedly unavailable, VideoManager stops writing files to all file spaces. However, if a file space is marked as offline, VideoManager can continue using other file space. Files in the offline file space will be unplayable and inaccessible. EVACUATE – This option automatically moves all data in the file space to the other file space(s) of the same type, which is useful if an old file space should not have any new files written to it, but the existing files within it should be kept. Note: If another administrator on the system is viewing, editing, or exporting the data in a file space that is being evacuated, the evacuation is forced to wait until the other actions have finished. If relevant, from the Encryption drop-down list, select an encryption type. The options are as follows: None , AES-128 , AES-192 , or AES-256 . Note: If unsure, Motorola Solutions recommends choosing AES-256 . The encryption type cannot be changed later. If an encryption mode is chosen, you must download the encryption key after creation, and store it offsite. This action ensures that the data can be recovered later in case of a disaster. To download the encryption key, you must click Go to file space next to the file space whose encryption key should be downloaded, and click Download Key . The key is downloaded to the default download location of your PC. It should be transferred to a secure location offsite. Optional: If you want all information relevant to the file space to be sent to the file space until it is full, set Preferred to Yes . If multiple file spaces have Preferred set to Yes , VideoManager alternates between those file spaces when storing resources. If no file spaces have Preferred set to Yes , VideoManager alternates between all file spaces when storing resources. To save the changes, click Confirm . Relocating Files If you want to relocate the files in a file space to a new location, Motorola Solutions recommends creating an entirely new file space with the new desired path, and evacuating all files in the old file space over to it. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Storage section. If the new file space has not already been created, click Create file space . The Create file space window opens. Enter the path for the new file space. Configure the rest of the settings as desired, and ensure that Preferred is set to Yes . Click Confirm . Next to the old file space whose path must be changed, click Go to file space . From the Category drop-down list, select Evacuate . The data in the old file space is evacuated to the file space with the new path. The evacuation can take some time. Optional: After the old file space has been fully evacuated, delete it by clicking Delete file space . Changing the Path of File Spaces Prerequisites: Stop the VideoManager service from the services control panel on the PC running VideoManager. Manually move the files to the new location, for example, by dragging and dropping the files into the new location on the PC. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Storage section. Next to the file space whose path you want to change, click Go to file space . Click Change . Enter the new path. Click Confirm . Note: VideoManager will not save the changes if the data has not already been manually moved to the location specified in the new path. Changing the Size of File Spaces Changing the size of a file space can be necessary if more or less space has become available, or a space should be redistributed between file spaces. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Storage section. Next to the file space whose size you want to change, click Go to file space . In the Max size field, make the relevant changes. Note: You cannot make the file space smaller than the size of the files which are already in the file space. Click Confirm . Deleting File Spaces Deleting a file space involves evacuating all files in the file space to another suitable file space. Procedure: Ensure that there is at least one other file space on VideoManager whose Category matches that of the file space that is being deleted, and whose State is set to Online . Next to the file space to be deleted, click Go to file space . From the Category drop-down list, select Evacuate . Click Confirm . The data in the deleted file space is evacuated to the other file space(s). This process may take hours or days, depending on the amount of information in the file space. Optional: After the evacuation has finished, to check that all of the files have been evacuated correctly, click Evacuation report . Next to the now empty file space, click Delete file space . Note: File spaces should not be deleted until they have been evacuated. However, as a last resort, administrators can delete a file space whose status has been set to OFFLINE , if the files in the file space have been irretrievably lost. Configuring File Space Warnings You can configure file space warnings, which appear when file spaces reach a certain threshold. The warnings are useful because they ensure that administrators can take action before the file spaces are completely full. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Storage section. In the File space warnings section, enable the relevant alarms and enter a percentage between 1 and 100% above which an alarm will be triggered. The options are as follows: Warn when media storage is above threshold Warn when export storage is above threshold Warn when backup storage is above threshold Click Save settings . From now on, whenever the Footage , Exports or Backups file spaces grow larger than the specified percentage, a system warning appears in the Notifications pane on the administrator's homepage, and in the System pane of the Status tab. Configuring Report Settings VideoManager automatically deletes reports if the report file space is becoming full. You can configure when your reports should be deleted and when scheduled reports should be run. You can also import a custom report schedule. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Reports section. In the Minimum auto-delete age field, enter the minimum number of days for which reports must have existed, before they are considered for deletion. In the Scheduled report time field, select the time of day at which scheduled reports should run. This setting affects all scheduled reports on VideoManager, and only dictates when reports are generated, not what times they cover. In the Organization name field, add your organization's name. From the Download reports as drop-down list, select the preferrable format of the downloaded report. If you select ZIP or CSV , you can select either format from the drop-down list before downloading. If you select ZIP or CSV , the report is automatically downloaded in the selected format. Click Save settings . You can create a custom report schedule, which dictates what dates a scheduled report should cover, and is selectable by users when creating a scheduled report from the Status tab. To create and import a custom schedule, perform the following actions: Create a JSON file with the desired schedule. You can create multiple schedules within one JSON file. The format is as follows: "name":" <NAME OF SCHEDULE> ", "scheduleDates": "startDay": <DAY OF MONTH> ,"startMonth": <MONTH> ,"endDay": <DAY OF MONTH> ,"endMonth": <MONTH> The day and month should be entered numerically, so for example, April = 4, May = 5, etc. In the following example, the JSON would import the schedule Test , which covers April 1st until May 20th. "name":"Test", "scheduleDates": "startDay":1,"startMonth": 4,"endDay":20,"endMonth":5 In the following example, the JSON would import the schedules Test and Test-2 , which cover April 1st until May 20th and June 1st until July 20th, respectively. "name":"Test", "scheduleDates": "startDay":1,"startMonth": 4,"endDay":20,"endMonth":5 "name":"Test-2", "scheduleDates": "startDay":1,"startMonth": 6,"endDay":20,"endMonth":7 Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Reports section. In the Custom report schedule pane, click Import custom schedule . Select the relevant JSON file and click Import . The imported schedule(s) immediately appear in the Custom report schedule pane. Users can now select the schedule from the Schedule drop-down list when they create a report. For more information, see Performing Report Actions . Note: If you import a new JSON file to VideoManager, then all schedules with the same name are overwritten, and all schedules not mentioned in the new JSON file are deleted. Click Save settings . Configuring Listen and Public Addresses of VideoManager A public address determines how users, devices, and docks access VideoManager on the network. A listen address determines which connections VideoManager accepts from these users, devices, and docks. It is possible to assign different purposes to different public and listen addresses. For example, one listen address for devices and one for users to access VideoManager via a browser. It is important to configure a public address because otherwise users will only be able to access VideoManager on the PC where it is installed. Configuring the Listen Address By default, VideoManager will listen on port 9080 for all traffic. Before you add a new listen address, you should confirm that your organization’s firewall settings will allow access before changing ports. Otherwise, your users, devices or sites may lose access to VideoManager. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Web Server section. In the Listen Addresses section, click New listen address . From the Purpose drop-down list, select Client certificate authenticated users . Optional: If VideoManager should only listen on a certain address, in the Server address field, specify the server address. In the Server port field, enter the server port. Note: The server port must be different for each one for the list of listen addresses. Set Use SSL? to On . In the SSL certificate , click Configure . The same SSL certificate can be used for multiple listen address configurations. Click Choose file . The certificate format is usually .p12 or .pfx . Select the certificate and click Open . Enter the password. Click OK . Click Save settings . The server restarts. Configuring the Public Address A public address is the address that web clients and devices use when not on the same network as the VideoManager instance. You must configure at least one public address. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Web Server section. Scroll down to the Public Addresses section. At the bottom of the section, in the lower right-hand corner, click New public address . From the Purpose drop-down list, select all purposes of the new address. In the Public URL field, enter the fully qualified public URL used to access the service. URL must include http:// or https:// at the beginning and the port number at the end, for example 9999 Click Save settings . The server restarts. Configuring Web Server Behaviour The following options are available in the Web Server Behaviour section. Procedure: If you want to use web sockets for transmitting feed data instead of polling, set Use web socket feeds to On . When enabled, currently logged on users must refresh their browsers to get the updated setting. Note: This setting must be enabled for live viewing. If you want sites to connect to this service to make their media available, set Central VideoManager Mode to On . Uploaded media are available at the Centre once fetched. Postrequisites: Click Save settings . Configuring SSL Certificates for Device Authentication Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Web Server section. In the Listen Addresses section, click New listen address . From the Purpose drop-down list, select Client certificate authenticated devices . Optional: In the Server address field, enter the server address. In the Server port field, enter the server port. Optional: Set Use certificate forwarding? to On . Enabling this option allows you to download the certificate. Ensure that Use SSL? is set to On . In the SSL certificate field, click Configure . Click Choose file . Note: Acceptable certificate formats are BASE64 and PEM. Select the certificate and click Open . Enter the password. Click OK . Click Save settings . Migrating Access Control Key Authenticated Devices to New Addresses As part of the implementation of the Device Server Certificate Verification section, all access control key authenticated devices must have their own listen address. To enable certificate verification without having to manually reconfigure all docks, you can access the migration wizard to add new listen and public addresses for access control key authenticated devices, which will automatically send the new configuration to all connected docks. Prerequisites: Ensure that all of your docks are connected. Note: Any docks that are not connected when you run the migration wizard will not be updated and will retain their previous settings. If certificate verification is enabled, devices may appear as unverified or locked depending on the selected mode until they are manually reconfigured or updated by running the migration wizard again. Ensure that the port you choose is available in your network and reachable from all docks. Allow for a maintenance window of up to one hour to complete the process. Keep access control key authenticated devices on both the old and new listen addresses simultaneously, until all docks are reconfigured. Ensure that the listen address set for access control key authenticated devices has an SSL certificate in place. The Multi-Domain (SAN) for the certificate must contain the host name or IP address of the VideoManager instance to be valid. Procedure: To access the migration wizard, perform the following actions: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Web Server section. In the message at the top informing you that access control key authenticated devices must be on separate listen and public addresses, click Click to start setup . The migration wizard opens in a new window. In the Getting started page, click Next . In the New server port field, enter the server port. Enable the Use SSL toggle. The Import SSL certificate button appears. Click Import SSL certificate and select the certificate from your PC. If the certificate is locked, the Passphrase field appears. In the Passphrase field, enter the password for the certificate and click Unlock . If the password is correct, more information about the certificate appears such as validity and subject. If the password is incorrect, you receive an error message. Ensure that the public URL is correct. Note: If the public URL is incorrect, docks may not be able to establish a connection. Confirming saves your new addresses, restarts the server, and logs out all users. Click Confirm . The Test connection page informs you how many docks are connected, how many of those require reconfiguration, and how many are ready for reconfiguration. If not all docks requiring reconfiguration pass the test, the docks retain the previous settings and you need to either manually reconfigure them or run the migration wizard again. If no docks passed the test, an error message appears. You must review your configuration settings and ensure that they are valid. Note: Reconfiguration can take some time. During the process, the docks will restart and all users will be logged out. To start reconfiguration, click Start . Note: During the process, you cannot close the window or refresh the page. If the process is interrupted, any remaining docks will not be reconfigured and you will have to relaunch the migration wizard to complete the process. Once the process is complete, the message appears informing you how many docks were successfully reconfigured. If any docks failed to receive the new configuration, you can update them later by either running the migration wizard again once the docks are connected or by reconfiguring them manually. For more information, see Configuring Listen and Public Addresses of VideoManager . Click Finish . Postrequisites: Once all docks are reconfigured to point to the new listen address/public address, remove access control key authenticated devices from the original server port. Creating and Configuring Backup Databases VideoManager offers a backup database service to help prevent the loss of crucial files in the event of an IT failure. A backup contains database metadata, such as the audit log, custom configurations, and descriptions of media files, incidents, and exports. These backups can be used by Motorola Solutions to restore an administrator's instance of VideoManager. The backup function only backs up the system state and does not back up the contents of the media, exports or reports filespaces. Note: Backups should be regularly transferred to a secure location offsite. Creating Backup Databases You can initiate an immediate backup, which captures the state of VideoManager at the time when the immediate backup was created. Note: Only users with the Initiate immediate database backup permission can initiate the backup of the database. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Backup Databases section. Click Backup now . The backup is sent to the location that has been configured in the Storage section. For more information, see Performing File Spaces Actions . Configuring Backup Databases You can configure recurring backups, which run automatically every hour. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Backup Databases section. Set Enabled automatic database backups to On . This action enables you to configure more settings relating to automatic backups. Enter the number of most recent daily and hourly backups that should be retained. A daily backup is the last hourly backup within a 24-hour window. It is recommended to configure both of these settings. Optional: If you want backups to only occur when there is little or no activity occurring on VideoManager, in order to minimise system load, set Avoid busy times to On . Click Save settings . The backup is sent to the location that has been configured in the Storage section. For more information, see Performing File Spaces Actions . The current backup status, as well as the start and end date of the backup, are displayed at the bottom of the pane. Importing and Deleting Licences The Licences pane enables you to licence features of VideoManager, which would otherwise be inaccessible. It also allows you to view the licences you have already bought, the expiry dates of the licences, and the number of devices which your licences support. Importing Licences Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Licences section. Click Import licence . Click Choose file . Note: You should select the licence provided to you by Motorola Solutions. For more information, contact Motorola Solutions Support. The maximum size of the licence can be 1 MB. In the Activation key field, enter the key provided by Motorola Solutions in the licence email. Note: If the key entered here does not match the key set by Motorola Solutions, the licence will not work. Click Import . If successful, the licence appears as Valid . All licences are on and enabled by default once imported. Deleting Licences An imported licence usually has an expiry date. A warning will appear on VideoManager when a licence is one week away from expiration. When the licence expires, VideoManager restarts. It can be necessary to delete a licence after it expired. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Licences section. Click Delete licence . If the licence is still valid, VideoManager presents a list of all the features which will stop working when the licence is deleted. Click Tick to confirm . Click Yes . Note: If the licence was still valid at the time of deletion, all VideoManager features associated with it immediately stop working. Advanced Settings Configuration The advanced settings file allows you to configure specialised features, for a demonstration or tutorials. All edits to the file can be done from the Advanced Settings section of the System pane, in the Admin tab. Note: The configuration should only be done if you have been given explicit permission from Motorola Solutions Support, and should not be attempted otherwise. Setting the System Time Zone of VideoManager For on-premises instances, by default, the System Time Zone is the time zone of the operating system on which users are accessing VideoManager. For cloud instances, by default, System Time Zone is the time zone of the server on which VideoManager is being hosted. The system time zone of VideoManager affects a number of functions, including: The start and end times for reports. When scheduled reports run. The interpretation of bandwidth rules, which apply to specific times or days. The system time zone of VideoManager does not necessarily dictate video metadata, which is determined by the time zone of the device on which the video was recorded, which is itself determined by the following: The time zone of the device profile. For more information, see Device Profiles . If the time zone of the device profile is left as the default, the time zone of a video is determined by the time zone of the dock to which the device is docked. For more information, see Performing Dock Actions . If the time zone of the dock is left as the default, the time zone of a video is determined by the system time zone of VideoManager. Note: The system time zone can be changed to be independent of the host server time zone by users with the permission to edit System time zone . Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the System Time Zone section. From the Time zone drop-down list, select the system time zone of VideoManager. Click Save settings . Exporting and Importing the Configuration of VideoManager Exporting or importing the configuration of VideoManager can be necessary if, for example, VideoManager has been configured on a test server, and the results should be imported into a live, working version. Exporting a System Configuration Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Import/Export System Config section. Optional: From the Replace this configuration on target system drop-down list, select which policies should be added to the system configuration file. To add a set of information to the exported configuration, click . Note: Imported policies overwrite previously existing policies on VideoManager. The options are as follows: By clicking Password complexity , the password complexity policy is exported. By clicking Deletion policy , the deletion policy is exported. Optional: From the Merge this configuration with target system drop-down list, select which roles, fields, and profiles should be added to the system configuration file. To add a set of information to the exported configuration, click . Note: If any of the imported roles, fields, or profiles from the original VideoManager have the same names as previously existing roles, fields or profiles on the new instance of VideoManager, the latter will be overwritten. The options are as follows: By clicking Shareable device keys , the access control keys are exported. By clicking Roles , roles are exported. By clicking Import profiles , import profiles are exported. By clicking Export profiles , export profiles are exported. By clicking User defined fields , incident fields, media fields, media playback reason fields, incident access reason field, and incident share reason fields are exported. By clicking Device profiles , device profiles are exported. By clicking Network profiles , network profiles are exported. Click Save settings . Click Export system config . The exported configuration is downloaded to the default download location of your PC. Importing a System Configuration Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Import/Export System Config section. Click Import system config . Select the previously downloaded system configuration and click Confirm . Viewing Legal Information You can view information about VideoManager related to legality and the terms of service. Procedure: Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click About . You can view the following fields: Product name is the name of the system. Product version is the version number of the system. Copyright notice describes who has copyrighted the system, and for how long. View licence agreement – By clicking View , you can check the licence agreement, which will have already been agreed to when initially logging on to the system. Creating a System Health Check Normally, the IT department is able to monitor computers and ensure that they are working properly. However, in some deployment scenarios, it can be helpful to configure an automated check of the health of the computer and warn users that they should contact support if there is something wrong. In this case, the administrator can create a script to check the health of the local computer, for example, check that the disk RAID array is working correctly, and if not, provide a suitable error message to show to the user. Procedure: Navigate to the config folder of VideoManager. By default, the folder is in the path C:\ProgramData\Motorola Solutions\VideoManager . Note: If ProgramData is not visible, you should navigate to the View tab at the top of the pane, and select the Hidden Items check box. In the config folder, create a file called health-check.bat . The script should return an exit code of 1 to indicate that a warning should be shown to users and 2 to indicate that there is an error and that users should be prevented from using VideoManager. If the script outputs a line beginning Message: , then the message will be shown to users. For example, the following batch file script would show the message This is an error to users and disable VideoManager: echo Message:This is a warning exit /b 1 Save the file, and from the Server Controls section, restart VideoManager. Perform one of the following actions: Option Actions Configuring when the health check is run automatically Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Advanced Settings File section. In the file, enter the following: health.check.period.secs=number of seconds This action sets the period between health checks while healthy to the number of seconds specified. health.check.error.period.secs=number of seconds This action sets the period between health checks while in an error state to the number of seconds specified. Note: The default time period for a reccurring healthy system check is an hour. The default time period for a reoccurring error system check is three minutes. Running the health check manually Navigate to the Admin tab. Select the System pane. Click the Web Server section. Click Run Health Check .
