full_content: Performing Network Profile ActionsVideoManager uses network profiles to control the connectivity options available for a device. A network profile is a collection of WiFi networks, which a device can connect to when attempting to live stream media.Creating Network ProfilesProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theNetwork Profilessection.ClickCreate network profile.In theNamefield, enter a name for the network profile.If you want the network profile to be the default, setDefault profiletoOn.If set toOn, devices assigned with single issue via RFID and Permanent allocation will automatically use this network profile.If you want a user's user-specific WiFi networks to be added to the network profile, setUser-specific networkstoYes.User-specific WiFi networks are networks that only appear on a user's session of VideoManager. This action is useful if multiple users have their own individual mobile hotspots that should only be used by devices assigned to them.For more information, seeCreating User-Specific WiFi Networks.The following sections appear:VT50/VT100andV200/VB400/V500.IfUser-specific networksis enabled, configure the following settings:IfEnable streamingis set toOn, users with appropriate permissions can live stream media over VideoManager from devices in the field.Note:This option controls only a single network for a V200. If there is more than one network created for a VB400 or V500 and at least one of them hasEnable streamingset toOn, streaming will be available for all networks.V200/VB400/V500 only:IfEnable video offloadingis set toOn, media that has been recorded on the device will be offloaded to VideoManager over the WiFi networks within this user-specific network profile.Note:This option controls only a single network for a V200. If there is more than one network created for a VB400 or V500 and at least one of them hasEnable video offloadingset toOn, offloading will be available for all networks.IfEnable dockingis set toOn, devices offload media and are fully manageable in VideoManager when charging and connected to WiFi. Enabling this option facilitates wireless media offload and enables remote management functions such as firmware upgrades, device assignment, or configuration changes.Note:Factory reset is not supported at the moment for V200 cameras. Firmware V200 version V25.4 is required to support this functionality.Configure WiFi networks to the network profile by clickingAdd networkand performing any of the following actions:Note:Unlike user-specific WiFi networks, these WiFi networks can be used by all devices that have this network profile assigned to them, regardless of their operator.In theNetwork name (SSID)field, enter the SSID of the WiFi network.From theSecurity typedrop-down list, select the security type of the WiFi network.In thePassphrasefield, enter the passphrase for the WiFi network.Usually, you can find these credentials on the bottom of the WiFi router.From theBanddrop-down list, select which frequencies the devices should attempt to connect to.The options are as follows:Anymakes devices connect to both 2.4GHz and 5GHz frequencies.2.4GHz onlymakes all devices connect to 2.4GHz frequencies.5GHz onlymakes devices connect to 5GHz frequencies.SetDisconnect on low signaltoOn.If set toOn, devices disconnect from the network if it has a low signal. The user can configure for how long the device must be connected to the weak signal, after which the device disconnects.If you want to enable devices to connect to hidden networks, setHidden networktoOn.Note:Hidden networkshould only be set toOnif the networks within a network profile are hidden networks.Perform the configurations as described in8.If multiple networks should be contained within the network profile, repeat9until all the necessary networks have been added.Note:You can prioritise the networks by usingMove upandMove down. Devices will attempt to connect to the first network shown in the list, while the last network in the list will only be used if all the other networks are unavailable.V500 only:In theMobile networkssection, perform any of the following actions:SetEnable LTEtoYes.Note:Assigning a network profile to a device that has both WiFi and LTE enabled will not send the WiFi configuration. The device can only use WiFi if it is assigned with a network profile that has LTE disabled.If you want to enable devices to be able to live stream media over LTE networks in this network profile, setEnable streamingtoOn.If you want the media that has been recorded on the device to be offloaded to VideoManager over the LTE networks within this network profile, setEnable wireless offloadtoOn.If you have configured device profiles so that the device can place bookmarks in a media file, then only bookmarked media files are downloaded over the LTE networks.If you have not configured the device profiles, then all media files are downloaded over the LTE networks when the device is connected to power.For more information, seePerforming Device Profiles ActionsandDevice Profiles.ClickSave profile.Postrequisites:After a network profile has been created, it can be applied to devices. The options are as follows:If an operator is obtaining their device throughSingle IssueorPermanent Issue, they can manually select the network profile when they assign their device.For more information, seeDevices Assignment and Media Recording.If an operator is obtaining their device throughPermanent Allocation, VideoManager automatically selects the default network profile of the system.Editing Network ProfilesProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theNetwork Profilessection.Next to the profile to be edited, clickGo to profile.Make the relevant changes and clickSave profile.Deleting Network ProfilesProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theNetwork Profilessection.Next to the profile to be deleted, clickDelete profile.Note:The default network profilecannotbe deleted. You must first select another network profile to become the default instead. You can do so by clickingGo to profilenext to the network profile, setting itsDefault profiletoOn, and clickingSave profile. The outdated network profile can now be deleted.Duplicating Network ProfilesDuplicating network profiles can be useful if VideoManager should have multiple similar network profiles.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theNetwork Profilessection.Next to the profile to be duplicated, clickDuplicate network profile.TheCreate Network Profilepane opens, with the original information of the network profile pre-set.Optional:Edit the network profile like normal.By default, theNameof the network profile is set to<name of the duplicated network profile>(copy).Note:Each network profile must have a unique name on VideoManager. You cannot save a network profile whose name is identical to an existing network profile.ClickSave profile.Exporting Network ProfilesExporting network profiles can be useful if sites should have the same network profiles as their Central VideoManager.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theNetwork Profilessection.Next to the profile to be exported, clickExport network profile.The network profile is exported to the default download location of your PC, and can be imported to other instances of VideoManager.Importing Network ProfilesImporting network profiles can be useful if sites should have the same network profiles as their Central VideoManager.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theNetwork Profilessection.Next to the profile to be imported, clickImport network profile.Select the relevant file from your PC.ClickImport.The network profile should appear on your instance of VideoManager.Alternatively, if you want to import/export all of your network profiles simultaneously, you can do so from theImport/Export System Configsection of theSystempane, in theAdmintab. For more information, seeExporting and Importing the Configuration of VideoManager. Performing Vehicle Network Profile ActionsCreating Vehicle Network ProfilesYou must create a vehicle network proﬁle for your M500/M500E(s) to enable the M500/M500E to connect to the router in a vehicle, and by extension to VideoManager.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theVehicle Network Profilessection.ClickCreate vehicle network profile.In theNamefield, enter a name for the network profile.Optional:If you want the network profile to be the default, setDefault profiletoOn.If set toOn, devices assigned with single issue via RFID and Permanent will connect in the vehicle.If you are unsure, Motorola Solutions recommends choosingWired.To configure a list of WiFi networks for M500E, under theM500E Onboard Wireless Clientsection, clickAdd networkand perform the following actions:In theNetwork name (SSID), enter the SSID of the WiFi network.In thePassphrasefield, enter the password of the WiFi network.You can also perform any of the following actions:To hide the network, setHidden networktoOn.To move the network up in the list of networks, click.To move the network down in the list of networks, click.To permanently delete the network, next to the network that you want to delete, click.The configured networks allow the M500E to offload evidence using WiFi.Under theM500 Interview Recording Systemsection, define parameters of the connection to the specific IP devices.Note:IP devices are to be installed only for the M500 used in the interview room.ClickSave profile.Editing Vehicle Network ProfilesProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theVehicle Network Profilessection.Next to the profile to be edited, clickGo to profile.Make the relevant changes and clickSave profile.Deleting Vehicle Network ProfilesProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theVehicle Network Profilessection.Next to the profile to be deleted, clickDelete profile.Note:The default vehicle network profilecannotbe deleted. You must first select another vehicle network profile to become the default instead. You can do so by clickingGo to profilenext to the network profile, setting itsDefault profiletoOn, and clickingSave profile. The outdated vehicle network profile can now be deleted.Duplicating Vehicle Network ProfilesDuplicating vehicle network profiles can be useful if VideoManager should have multiple similar vehicle network profiles.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theVehicle Network Profilessection.Next to the profile to be duplicated, clickDuplicate vehicle network profile.TheCreate Vehicle network profilepane opens, with the original information of the vehicle network profile pre-set.Optional:Edit the vehicle network profile like normal.By default, theNameof the vehicle network profile is set to<name of the duplicated vehicle network profile>(copy).Note:Each vehicle network profile must have a unique name on VideoManager. You cannot save a vehicle network profile whose name is identical to an existing vehicle network profile.ClickSave profile.Exporting Vehicle Network ProfilesExporting vehicle network profiles can be useful if sites should have the same vehicle network profiles as their Central VideoManager.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theVehicle Network Profilessection.Next to the profile to be exported, clickExport vehicle network profile.The vehicle network profile is exported to the default download location of your PC, and can be imported to other instances of VideoManager.Importing Vehicle Network ProfilesImporting vehicle network profiles can be useful if sites should have the same vehicle network profiles as their Central VideoManager.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theVehicle Network Profilessection.Next to the profile to be imported, clickImport vehicle network profile.Select the relevant file from your PC.ClickImport.The vehicle network profile should appear on your instance of VideoManager.Alternatively, if you want to import/export all of your network profiles simultaneously, you can do so from theImport/Export System Configsection of theSystempane, in theAdmintab. For more information, seeExporting and Importing the Configuration of VideoManager. Creating APNsProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theLTE APNssection.ClickCreate APN.TheCreate APNwindow opens.Fill in the following information:APNThis field is mandatory.Mobile country codeMobile network codeUserPasswordClickSave profile. Performing Bandwidth Rules ActionsYou can configure bandwidth rules, which affect how much bandwidth is used when downloading data from both sites and docks.Creating and Applying Bandwidth RulesProcedure:On the Central VideoManager (if creating a bandwidth rule for sites), or on VideoManager (if creating a bandwidth rule for docks), navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theBandwidth Rulessection.ClickCreate bandwidth rule.In theNamefield, enter a name for the bandwidth rule.Optional:If you want all docks that are added to this rule to be part of the same "group" and share the same bandwidth limit, setShared bandwidth grouptoOn.This action is useful if multiple docks are on the same network connection, and you want to stagger the downloads.If you want all docks who are added to this rule to continuously download media to VideoManager, ignoring the overall download limit, setSlow connectiontoOn.This action is useful if the docks have a slow network connection.To create an individual rule, clickAdd rule.You can create multiple rules within one bandwidth rule, which is useful if there are certain "busy" times when media and other data should not be offloaded, and other "quiet" times when media and data should be offloaded.If there are multiple rules within one bandwidth rule, you should order them using thecontrols next to each rule. If there are two overlapping rules, for example, two rules apply on Saturday, the rule that is highest in the list takes priority.You can delete an individual rule within a bandwidth rule by clickingDelete bandwidth rule.Configure any of the following settings:The day(s) of the week when the rule should occur.In thefromfield, enter the time of day when the rule should begin.In theuntilfield, enter the time of day when the rule should finish.In thelimit tofield, enter the number of kilobits per second to which uploads should be limited while the rule applies.ClickCreate bandwidth rule.After a bandwidth rule is created, it must be manually applied in order to take effect.Perform one of the following actions:OptionActionsApplying a bandwidth rule to a dockNavigate to theDevicestab.Select thedockspane.Next to the relevant dock, clickView details.You can filter docks byName,Serial, andVersion.In theBandwidth Rulepane, click the drop-down menu, and select the relevant rule.Optional:If you want all media from the selected dock to be downloaded as quickly as possible, setHigh Priority docktoOn.If the dock is part of a bandwidth rule that has theShared bandwidth groupsetting enabled, it halts the downloads of other docks in the group until all of its media has been downloaded.ClickSave Bandwidth Rule.Applying a bandwidth rule to a siteThe bandwidth rule can either be applied upon creation or the site can be edited afterward to include the rule. For more information, seeConfiguring Sites.Copying Bandwidth RulesCopying bandwidth rules enables to create multiple, similar bandwidth rules.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theBandwidth Rulessection.Next to the relevant bandwidth rule, clickCopy bandwidth rule.The name of the copied bandwidth rule is the name of the original bandwidth rule with_1(if it is the first copy of the bandwidth rule) at the end.Note:Unlike groups and users, it is possible to create two bandwidth rules with the same name, but it is not recommended.Make any necessary changes to the copy of the bandwidth rule, and clickSave bandwidth rule.Editing Bandwidth RulesProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theBandwidth Rulessection.ClickGo to bandwidth rule.Make the relevant changes, and clickSave bandwidth rule.The bandwidth rule automatically updates across all docks to which it has been applied.Deleting Bandwidth RulesProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theBandwidth Rulessection.Next to the relevant bandwidth rule, clickDelete bandwidth rule.Note:If the deleted bandwidth rule was previously applied to a dock or site, the bandwidth setting for those docks and sites immediately changes toNo restrictionuntil another bandwidth rule is manually reapplied. Configuring Email SettingsConfiguring email settings is necessary to enable additional functionality: users can reset their own passwords, self-register without administrative help, and receive notifications when specific actions are performed on VideoManager.Prerequisites:Enable theNotificationlicence.For more information, seeImporting and Deleting Licences.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theEmail Settingssection.SetEmail notifications enabledtoOn.In theDefault propertiessection, configure the following settings:In theSender email addressfield, enter the email address from which all VideoManager emails should be sent.This includes email notifications, password reset emails, and user profile creation emails.In theHostfield, enter the host from which emails should be sent.For Gmail, the host issmtp.gmail.comIn thePortfield, enter the port from which emails should be sent.For Gmail, the port is587IfAuthenticationis set toOn, enter the username and password belonging to the email address entered in theSender email addressfield.Note:The password is not necessarily the same password that is utilised to log on to the email address's account.Gmail only:Create an app password by performing the following actions:Open the account settings pane for the email address entered in theSender email addressfield.Click theSecuritysection.ClickApp passwords.From theSelect appdrop-down list, selectOther (Custom name).EnterVideoManagerClickGenerate.Copy the password and paste it into thePasswordfield.IfSTARTTLS enableis set toOn, all emails sent from VideoManager are protected with Transport Layer Security (TLS).IfTrust server certificatesis set toOn, VideoManager trusts the SMTP server.If set toOff, VideoManager will check server certificates.Optional:In theCustom propertiessection, add specific properties that dictate how VideoManager interacts with the SMTP server by performing the following actions:ClickAdd property.In thePropertyfield, enter the name of the property.This should be the name of a JavaMail SMTP property. For example,mail.smtp.timeoutormail.smtp.reportsuccessIn theValuefield, enter the value of the property.The format of the value (milliseconds, true/false, host name, and more) depends on the property name entered in thePropertyfield.Optional:In theCustom templatessection, configure the notification email that is sent to users when specific actions are taken on VideoManager by performing any of the following actions:If you want to configure the email that users receive when another user on VideoManager logs on for the first time, setFirst time logintoOn.If you want to configure the email that users receive when a device starts streaming, setDevice stream starttoOn.This could be the user's own device, or a device assigned to someone they supervise, depending on the way the user's permissions are configured.Optional:In theTest Propertiessection, in theTest recipientfield, enter the email address to which the test email should be sent, and clickTest.Postrequisites:You can also configure how password reset emails and user profile creation emails are sent. For more information, seeConfiguring User Self Service. Configuring Email NotificationsAfter you have configured email settings on VideoManager, you can enable and configure email notifications. This action involves optionally configuring the email template which users will receive for various events, enabling notifications for individual roles, and ensuring that users in those roles have email addresses associated with them.Procedure:Optional:Configure the emails that users will receive when specific actions are taken on VideoManager by performing the following actions:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theEmail Settingssection.Scroll down to theCustom templatessection.The options are as follows:IfFirst time loginis set toOn, you can configure the email that users receive when another user on VideoManager logs on for the first time.If left asOff, the default message isUser has logged in to<system>for the first time. User<username><displayName>has logged in.IfDevice stream startis set toOn, you can configure the email that users receive when a device starts streaming. This could be the user's own device, or a device assigned to someone they supervise, depending on the way the user's permissions have been configured.If left asOff, the default message isDevice started streaming.<device>started streaming to<system>.IfFile storage threshold warningis set toOn, you can configure the email that users receive when one of file spaces of VideoManager is nearly full.If left asOff, the default message isA File Space on<system>has exceeded the threshold:<#list storageWarnings as message><message.category>:<message.level></#list>.Configure which users should receive notifications on a role-by-role basis by performing the following actions:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theUserspane.Click theRolessection.Next to the role to be edited, clickGo to role.Enable the relevant permissions.First time login– Users receive a notification when other users first log on to VideoManager.Personal device stream start– Users receive a notification when a device assigned to them starts streaming.Supervised device stream start– Users receive a notification when a device assigned to users they supervise starts streaming.File storage threshold warnings– Users receive a notification when VideoManager is low on storage space.ClickSave role.Ensure that all users in the notification-enabled roles have email addresses associated with them on VideoManager by performing the following actions:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theUserspane.Click theUserssection.Locate the user to be edited by filtering users in one of the following ways:In theNamefield, enter the user's username or display name.In theAuthentication IDfield, enter the user's authentication ID.In theIn groupfield, enter the group name of the user's group.If you enter a group name in theIn groupfield, you have the option to change ifOnly immediate membersis set toOnor not. If set toOn, only users that are assigned directly to the specified group are returned, as opposed to if user A is assigned indirectly to group B because A belongs to group C, which is assigned to group B.In theEmailfield, enter the user's email.In theUser UUIDfield, enter the user's UUID which is a unique, non-sequential ID for a user.Note:You need correct permissions to either view or search by this field. For more information, seeUser Permissions.From theRoledrop-down list, select the user's relevant role.You can clickto reset the filter.Next to the user to be edited, clickGo to user.In theEmail notificationsfield, enter an email address for the user.ClickSave user. Configuring Mobile App SettingsIf the mobile application has been licenced from Motorola Solutions, you can configure its settings from VideoManager. You should do this before you start operating your mobile application.For more information about setting up the mobile applications with VideoManager, you can navigate tohttps://www.motorolasolutions.com/en_xu.htmland search forVideoManager: VB SmartControl User Guide,VideoManager VB Companion GuideorSmartControl User Guide.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theConnectivitypane.Click theMobile App Settingssection.In theVB Companion settingssection, perform the following actions:In theUpdate app configuration afterfield, enter the number of days after which VB Companion must receive an updated configuration from VideoManager.Note:For the action to be successful, the phone running VB Companion must be able to reach the instance of VideoManager from which it was provisioned, for example over a WiFi network or VPN, and the administrator must clickRefresh configin VB Companion. If VB Companion cannot reach VideoManager within the number of days specified, it stops working.In theDevices must be docked everyfield, enter the number of days after which the devices associated with individual instances of VB Companion must be redocked.Only one device can be associated with an instance of VB Companion at any one time. However, multiple instances of VB Companion can be associated with one instance of VideoManager.Optional:If you want all communication between the device and the user's phone to be encrypted with SSL, setUse SSLtoYes.If enabled, you are presented with an SSL certificate which you must download and install onto the phone which is running VB Companion.In theVB SmartControl settingssection, perform any of the following actions:If you want all communication between the device and the user's phone to be encrypted with SSL, setUse SSLtoYes.If you want watermarks to be displayed on video playback in the mobile application, setEnable playback watermarkstoYes.From theSmartControl default auth mode, select which authentication method you will use during provisioning.The options are as follows:Client certificateorBluetooth.Note:Depending on the mobile application, a device supports different authentication modes:For VB Companion, a device supports onlyClient Certificatemode.For VB SmartControl, a device supports onlyBluetooth Authenticationmode.For SmartControl, a device supports bothClient CertificateandBluetooth Authenticationmodes, withClient Certificateas the default.Note:V500 supports onlyBluetooth Authenticationmode.ClickSave settings.
description: This section covers the procedures for performing network profile actions within the VideoManager application, which allows users to manage connectivity options for devices. Key features include creating network profiles, setting default profiles, and enabling user-specific WiFi networks for individual users, as well as configuring streaming permissions for live media. Users can search for terms like "network profile creation," "user-specific WiFi networks," and "streaming configuration" to find relevant information.

You must have at least one successful test before you can save your changes.ClickSave.Postrequisites:For newly created RFID settings, you can perform any of the following actions in theRFID Card Typessection:To delete the RFID setting, next to the relevant setting, clickand confirm by clickingYes.To edit the the RFID setting, next to the relevant setting, click.
description: This section covers the configuration of RFID settings for processing tags on a per-tag type basis, allowing users to set modes and post-processing scripts. Key features include the ability to retain legacy RFID settings, create new RFID configurations, and enable Lua post-processing scripts for custom ID transformations. Users can navigate through the Admin tab to access the Devices pane and adjust settings for various card types, including MIFARE and DESFire.

title: Configuring Deletion Policies

IfBookmark statusis set toOn, from the drop-down list, select how bookmarked media should be treated by the deletion policy of VideoManager. From the drop-down list, you can select for how long bookmarked media should be kept:the same period as non-bookmarked media– If this option is selected, the deletion policy treats bookmarked and non-bookmarked media identically.specified amount of time– If this option is selected, you have the option to configure for how long bookmarked media is kept. The default is 90 days.IfIf it is part of a recordingis set toOn, an entire recording is kept if one media file within it has been added to an incident.If set toOff, only media files that have been added to incidents are preserved. The larger recording is subject to the deletion policy of VideoManager like normal.Overrides & recoveryIfIncident grace periodis set toOn, enter the number of days for which media is protected after it has been removed from an incident. Media in an incident is never deleted unless:It has been manually removed from the incident.The incident it is a part of has been deleted, in which case the media is subject to normal deletion policies.Forced deletionis set toOn.IfRecovery periodis set toOn, enter the number of days for which media is kept after deletion is requested, in case a media file has been deleted accidentally.IfForced deletionis set toOn, media is deleted even if it is part of an incident.Normally, media is never deleted while it is part of an incident.Click theIncidentssection and select one of the following:Search:ColumnNameDescriptionExport to ExcelExport to CSVNameDescriptionNever delete incidentsThe default selection.Delete after a certain amount of timeAllows you to specify the amount of time in days, months or years after the start date after which the incidents should be deleted.From the start date drop-down list, you can choose betweenCreation date,Earliest incident clip start time, andLatest incident clip start time.Delete based on their categoryCategories are set up in theIncident Fieldssection using either a tag list or drop down field. For more information, seeCreating Incident Fields.Select the category source from the drop-down list. You can manage your category sources from theIncident Fieldssection.Each category has aRetention periodandStart time.Retention periodallows you to keep a specific category for a specified number of days, months or years.From theStart timedrop-down list, you can choose betweenCreation date,Earliest incident clip start time, andLatest incident clip start timeafter which the retention period begins.Note:Incidents always take precedence with deletion policies. Once removed from an incident, retention policy falls back to the media retention policy.Use advanced configurationIf selected, the deletion policy automatically deletes outdated incidents from VideoManager. There is some configuration involved:From theIncident Fieldssection, create a new incident field like normal.For more information, seeCreating Incident Fields.From theTypedrop-down list, selectComputed Auto-delete.Note:There can only be oneComputed auto-deleteincident field per instance of VideoManager. If one already exists, this option is not visible in the drop-down list.In theDelete incident iffield, enter the conditions under which this policy should go into effect, using the Motorola Solutions custom predicate language.The most simple input would betrue, which would delete all incidents meeting the date specified in theAuto-deletion datefield. For more information, seeCustom Predicate Language.In theAuto-deletion datefield, enter the relevant time period, which determines when an incident should be deleted, using the Motorola Solutions custom predicate language.The most simple input would be something similar todateAdd(<6, day, creation-time>), which would delete incidents that are six days old.For more information, seeCustom Predicate Language.ClickSave settings.Navigate back to theDeletion Policysection.SetAutomatically delete old incidentstoOn.If there are incidents to be deleted within the next seven days due to the policy configured in theAuto-deletion datefield, you can preview these incidents by clicking<0>incidents will be scheduled for deletion over the next seven days.If there are incidents to be deleted immediately due to the policy configured in theAuto-deletion datefield, you can preview these incidents by clicking<1>incident is scheduled for immediate deletion.ClickSave settings.ClickYes, make these changes.and then,Yesagain to save the changes.Result:The following toggle appears:Enable email alerts for incidents nearing deletion.IfEnable email alerts for incidents nearing deletionis set toOn, theUser or group to notifyfield appears where you can add users or groups to receive email notifications for incidents scheduled to be deleted within 30 days. You should ensure that selected users or groups have valid emails.Note:To enable email alerts, you must enable email notifications. For more information, seeConfiguring Email Settings.Click theExportssection, setAutomatically delete old exportstoOnand enter the number of days for which exports are kept after being created.If set toOn, outdated exports on VideoManager are automatically deleted, even if the export has not yet been downloaded to the user's PC.Note:The original incident is never deleted, only the export is.Click theAudit logssection and configure any of the following:IfRolling audit log deletionis set toOn, determine for how many days audit logs should be retained before they are automatically deleted by VideoManager.IfAnnual audit log deletionis set toOn, determine for how many years an audit log entry should be retained before it is automatically deleted by VideoManager.The age of the audit log entry is calculated from midnight, January 1st. If a log entry is not the configured number of years old by that date, it is kept until the next year. For example, if the deletion policy is configured so that all entries are kept for one year, an audit log entry created on January 2nd 2020 will be deleted on January 1st 2022, because it was not one year old on January 1st 2021.Note:If bothRolling audit log deletionandAnnual audit log deletionare set toOn, audit logs are deleted in line with whichever policy sets the earlier deletion date.Click theDashboardsection and in theShow media scheduled to be deleted in<7>daysfield, enter the number of days within which a media file should be deleted, before it will show up on a user's dashboard.This setting only applies to users that have theView media scheduled to be deleted on dashboardpermission set toYes.Optional:ClickDownload change summary.This action downloads a CSV file directly to your PC. The file contains information about any changes to which media files and incidents should be deleted as a result of the new policy.ClickSave settings. Creating and Editing File ContainersIf media and other data are stored in object storage instead of a file system, administrators must create file containers on VideoManager, which contain information about the object store. This action enables file spaces on VideoManager to connect to the cloud.Note:You can only perform this procedure if you are using Amazon S3 Object Storage or Azure Blob Storage. If you are using filesystem storage, you can skip this procedure.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theStoragesection.ClickCreate file container.In theNamefield, enter a name for the file container.The file container will be identified by that name on VideoManager.From theTypedrop-down list, select eitherS3 Object StorageorAzure Blob Storage.Perform one of the following actions:If…Then…If you are using S3 Object Storage,perform the following actions:In theBucket namefield, enter the bucket name.Motorola Solutions suggests using a unique fully qualified domain name of VideoManagerIn theEndpointfield, enter the endpoint of the file container.To check this information, you must open the AWS console, navigate to thePropertiestab, and select theBucket overviewpane. In theRegion section, make a note of the region.Then, you must enter the region in theEndpointfield, with the following format:s3.<region code>.amazonaws.comwhere<region code>is the region.Note:The endpoint must match the region where the bucket was created.In theKeyandSecretfields, enter the key and secret of the IAM user, respectively.You can only get this information immediately after creating an IAM user with S3 access. If you do not have the key and secret for the IAM user, you must create another user and make a note of the key and secret's information, which is presented when the user is saved.If you are using Azure Blob Storage,perform the following actions:In theContainer namefield, enter the name of the container.You can either enter the name of a container that already exists in your Azure account, or enter the name for a new container. If a new container name is entered, Azure Blob Storage automatically creates the container. To check whether the action has been successful, on Azure, navigate to theStorage accountstab, select theStorage accountpane, and click theContainerssection. The new container should be visible.In theEndpointfield, enter the endpoint of the file container.To check this information, in theEndpointstab, you must click theBlob servicepane, and copy and paste the value from theBlob servicefield.In theAccountfield, enter the name of the Azure Blob Storage account.In theSecretfield, enter the secret of the container.To check this information, on Azure, you must navigate to theAccess Keystab, clickShow keys, and copy and paste either of the keys.ClickConfirm. Performing File Spaces ActionsFile spaces determine where files from VideoManager are stored, how much space VideoManager can use, and whether the files are encrypted when they are stored. Files can be stored on the administrator's PC (if administrators have accepted the default file space configuration, file spaces are stored on the PC with the pathC:\ProgramData\Motorola Solutions\VideoManager.), network-attached storage, or Amazon S3 Object Storage/Azure Blob Storage (if it has been purchased). It is important to note that some files, such as temporary files and config files, are always kept on the local hard drive, even if VideoManager has been configured to use a different kind of storage.Note:VideoManager only supports Amazon S3 Object Storage or Azure Blob Storage. Other kinds of object storage are not compatible and cannot be used to store files from VideoManager.Devices generate large numbers of very large files. It is important to consider how much storage capacity will be required and how much bandwidth the storage system will require, which is why Motorola Solutions recommends dedicated network-attached storage. When file spaces are full, associated system functions will stop working. For example, devices will be unable to download media files, and will enter an error state.You can administer your file spaces, which includes creating new file spaces, moving files within them, increasing their sizes, and deleting them.Creating File SpacesYou can create new file spaces alongside existing ones. This action can be necessary if files should be stored in a different location, or if a file space of one type is becoming full and more space should be added.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theStoragesection.ClickCreate file space.TheCreate file spacewindow opens.Enter the path for the new file space.If you have purchased S3 Object Storage or Azure Blob Storage, you should enter the name of a folder within the bucket, which will then be created.Note:If you are using a grid configuration, you must ensure that the path can be accessed by all workers in the grid. For more information about setting up grids with VideoManager, seeVideoManager and Grids Explained.From theCategorydrop-down list, select a category for the file space.The options are as follows:Footageis where media on VideoManager are stored. Additionally, imported media files are stored here, too.Exportsis where exports on VideoManager are stored.Reportsis where reports on VideoManager are stored.Backupsis where system backups on VideoManager are stored.Resourcesis where theme resources, such as logos, colour schemes, and device firmware, are stored on VideoManager.Import Workspaceis where temporary files are stored. This option is only necessary if a grid system with import workers is being used with VideoManager.From theContainerfield, select the type of container for the file space.The options are as follows:Filesystem– The file space is contained in the filesystem.If you have created a file container whose details correspond to either a S3 Object Storage or Azure Blob Storage container, you can select either of these storages.In theMax sizefield, enter the maximum size that VideoManager should use in the file space.Motorola Solutions recommends that the maximum size is not set to the absolute upper limit of the disk/drive, as VideoManager will behave incorrectly when the disk/drive is completely full.Note:Because many object storage systems do not have a maximum capacity, this field ensures that storage costs are capped.From theStatedrop-down list, select a state for the file space.In most cases, the option isOnline.The other options are as follows:OBSOLETE– Files in an obsolete file space are still available, but no new files will be written to the file space.OFFLINE– Usually, if a file space is unexpectedly unavailable, VideoManager stops writing files to all file spaces. However, if a file space is marked as offline, VideoManager can continue using other file space. Files in the offline file space will be unplayable and inaccessible.EVACUATE– This option automatically moves all data in the file space to the other file space(s) of the same type, which is useful if an old file space should not have any new files written to it, but the existing files within it should be kept.Note:If another administrator on the system is viewing, editing, or exporting the data in a file space that is being evacuated, the evacuation is forced to wait until the other actions have finished.If relevant, from theEncryptiondrop-down list, select an encryption type.The options are as follows:None,AES-128,AES-192, orAES-256.Note:If unsure, Motorola Solutions recommends choosingAES-256.The encryption type cannot be changed later. If an encryption mode is chosen, you must download the encryption key after creation, and store it offsite. This action ensures that the data can be recovered later in case of a disaster.To download the encryption key, you must clickGo to file spacenext to the file space whose encryption key should be downloaded, and clickDownload Key.The key is downloaded to the default download location of your PC. It should be transferred to a secure location offsite.Optional:If you want all information relevant to the file space to be sent to the file space until it is full, setPreferredtoYes.If multiple file spaces havePreferredset toYes, VideoManager alternates between those file spaces when storing resources.If no file spaces havePreferredset toYes, VideoManager alternates between all file spaces when storing resources.To save the changes, clickConfirm.Relocating FilesIf you want to relocate the files in a file space to a new location, Motorola Solutions recommends creating an entirely new file space with the new desired path, and evacuating all files in the old file space over to it.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theStoragesection.If the new file space has not already been created, clickCreate file space.TheCreate file spacewindow opens.Enter the path for the new file space.Configure the rest of the settings as desired, and ensure thatPreferredis set toYes.ClickConfirm.Next to the old file space whose path must be changed, clickGo to file space.From theCategorydrop-down list, selectEvacuate.The data in the old file space is evacuated to the file space with the new path. The evacuation can take some time.Optional:After the old file space has been fully evacuated, delete it by clickingDelete file space.Changing the Path of File SpacesPrerequisites:Stop the VideoManager service from the services control panel on the PC running VideoManager.Manually move the files to the new location, for example, by dragging and dropping the files into the new location on the PC.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theStoragesection.Next to the file space whose path you want to change, clickGo to file space.ClickChange.Enter the new path.ClickConfirm.Note:VideoManager will not save the changes if the data has not already been manually moved to the location specified in the new path.Changing the Size of File SpacesChanging the size of a file space can be necessary if more or less space has become available, or a space should be redistributed between file spaces.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theStoragesection.Next to the file space whose size you want to change, clickGo to file space.In theMax sizefield, make the relevant changes.Note:You cannot make the file space smaller than the size of the files which are already in the file space.ClickConfirm.Deleting File SpacesDeleting a file space involves evacuating all files in the file space to another suitable file space.Procedure:Ensure that there is at least one other file space on VideoManager whoseCategorymatches that of the file space that is being deleted, and whoseStateis set toOnline.Next to the file space to be deleted, clickGo to file space.From theCategorydrop-down list, selectEvacuate.ClickConfirm.The data in the deleted file space is evacuated to the other file space(s). This process may take hours or days, depending on the amount of information in the file space.Optional:After the evacuation has finished, to check that all of the files have been evacuated correctly, clickEvacuation report.Next to the now empty file space, clickDelete file space.Note:File spaces should not be deleted until they have been evacuated. However, as a last resort, administrators can delete a file space whose status has been set toOFFLINE, if the files in the file space have been irretrievably lost. Configuring File Space WarningsYou can configure file space warnings, which appear when file spaces reach a certain threshold. The warnings are useful because they ensure that administrators can take action before the file spaces are completely full.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theStoragesection.In theFile space warningssection, enable the relevant alarms and enter a percentage between 1 and 100% above which an alarm will be triggered.The options are as follows:Warn when media storage is above thresholdWarn when export storage is above thresholdWarn when backup storage is above thresholdClickSave settings.From now on, whenever theFootage,ExportsorBackupsfile spaces grow larger than the specified percentage, a system warning appears in theNotificationspane on the administrator's homepage, and in theSystempane of theStatustab. Configuring Report SettingsVideoManager automatically deletes reports if the report file space is becoming full. You can configure when your reports should be deleted and when scheduled reports should be run. You can also import a custom report schedule.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theReportssection.In theMinimum auto-delete agefield, enter the minimum number of days for which reports must have existed, before they are considered for deletion.In theScheduled report timefield, select the time of day at which scheduled reports should run.This setting affects all scheduled reports on VideoManager, and only dictates when reports are generated, not what times they cover.In theOrganization namefield, add your organization's name.From theDownload reports asdrop-down list, select the preferrable format of the downloaded report.If you selectZIP or CSV, you can select either format from the drop-down list before downloading. If you selectZIPorCSV, the report is automatically downloaded in the selected format.ClickSave settings.You can create a custom report schedule, which dictates what dates a scheduled report should cover, and is selectable by users when creating a scheduled report from theStatustab.To create and import a custom schedule, perform the following actions:Create a JSON file with the desired schedule.You can create multiple schedules within one JSON file.The format is as follows:"name":"<NAME OF SCHEDULE>", "scheduleDates": "startDay":<DAY OF MONTH>,"startMonth":<MONTH>,"endDay":<DAY OF MONTH>,"endMonth":<MONTH>The day and month should be entered numerically, so for example, April = 4, May = 5, etc.In the following example, the JSON would import the scheduleTest, which covers April 1st until May 20th."name":"Test", "scheduleDates": "startDay":1,"startMonth": 4,"endDay":20,"endMonth":5In the following example, the JSON would import the schedulesTestandTest-2, which cover April 1st until May 20th and June 1st until July 20th, respectively."name":"Test", "scheduleDates": "startDay":1,"startMonth": 4,"endDay":20,"endMonth":5 "name":"Test-2", "scheduleDates": "startDay":1,"startMonth": 6,"endDay":20,"endMonth":7Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theReportssection.In theCustom report schedulepane, clickImport custom schedule.Select the relevant JSON file and clickImport.The imported schedule(s) immediately appear in theCustom report schedulepane. Users can now select the schedule from theScheduledrop-down list when they create a report.For more information, seePerforming Report Actions.Note:If you import a new JSON file to VideoManager, then all schedules with the same name are overwritten, and all schedules not mentioned in the new JSON file are deleted.ClickSave settings. Configuring Listen and Public Addresses of VideoManagerA public address determines how users, devices, and docks access VideoManager on the network.A listen address determines which connections VideoManager accepts from these users, devices, and docks.It is possible to assign different purposes to different public and listen addresses. For example, one listen address for devices and one for users to access VideoManager via a browser.It is important to configure a public address because otherwise users will only be able to access VideoManager on the PC where it is installed.Configuring the Listen AddressBy default, VideoManager will listen on port 9080 for all traffic. Before you add a new listen address, you should confirm that your organization’s firewall settings will allow access before changing ports. Otherwise, your users, devices or sites may lose access to VideoManager.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theWeb Serversection.In theListen Addressessection, clickNew listen address.From thePurposedrop-down list, selectClient certificate authenticated users.Optional:If VideoManager should only listen on a certain address, in theServer addressfield, specify the server address.In theServer portfield, enter the server port.Note:The server port must be different for each one for the list of listen addresses.SetUse SSL?toOn.In theSSL certificate, clickConfigure.The same SSL certificate can be used for multiple listen address configurations.ClickChoose file.The certificate format is usually.p12or.pfx.Select the certificate and clickOpen.Enter the password.ClickOK.ClickSave settings.The server restarts.Configuring the Public AddressA public address is the address that web clients and devices use when not on the same network as the VideoManager instance. You must configure at least one public address.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theWeb Serversection.Scroll down to thePublic Addressessection.At the bottom of the section, in the lower right-hand corner, clickNew public address.From thePurposedrop-down list, select all purposes of the new address.In thePublic URLfield, enter the fully qualified public URL used to access the service.URL must includehttp://orhttps://at the beginning and the port number at the end, for example9999ClickSave settings.The server restarts.Configuring Web Server BehaviourThe following options are available in theWeb Server Behavioursection.Procedure:If you want to use web sockets for transmitting feed data instead of polling, setUse web socket feedstoOn.When enabled, currently logged on users must refresh their browsers to get the updated setting.Note:This setting must be enabled for live viewing.If you want sites to connect to this service to make their media available, setCentral VideoManager ModetoOn.Uploaded media are available at the Centre once fetched.Postrequisites:ClickSave settings. Configuring SSL Certificates for Device AuthenticationProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theWeb Serversection.In theListen Addressessection, clickNew listen address.From thePurposedrop-down list, selectClient certificate authenticated devices.Optional:In theServer addressfield, enter the server address.In theServer portfield, enter the server port.Optional:SetUse certificate forwarding?toOn.Enabling this option allows you to download the certificate.Ensure thatUse SSL?is set toOn.In theSSL certificatefield, clickConfigure.ClickChoose file.Note:Acceptable certificate formats are BASE64 and PEM.Select the certificate and clickOpen.Enter the password.ClickOK.ClickSave settings. Migrating Access Control Key Authenticated Devices to New AddressesAs part of the implementation of theDevice Server Certificate Verificationsection, all access control key authenticated devices must have their own listen address. To enable certificate verification without having to manually reconfigure all docks, you can access the migration wizard to add new listen and public addresses for access control key authenticated devices, which will automatically send the new configuration to all connected docks.Prerequisites:Ensure that all of your docks are connected.Note:Any docks that are not connected when you run the migration wizard will not be updated and will retain their previous settings. If certificate verification is enabled, devices may appear as unverified or locked depending on the selected mode until they are manually reconfigured or updated by running the migration wizard again.Ensure that the port you choose is available in your network and reachable from all docks.Allow for a maintenance window of up to one hour to complete the process.Keep access control key authenticated devices on both the old and new listen addresses simultaneously, until all docks are reconfigured.Ensure that the listen address set for access control key authenticated devices has an SSL certificate in place. The Multi-Domain (SAN) for the certificate must contain the host name or IP address of the VideoManager instance to be valid.Procedure:To access the migration wizard, perform the following actions:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theWeb Serversection.In the message at the top informing you that access control key authenticated devices must be on separate listen and public addresses, clickClick to start setup.The migration wizard opens in a new window.In theGetting startedpage, clickNext.In theNew server portfield, enter the server port.Enable theUse SSLtoggle.TheImport SSL certificatebutton appears.ClickImport SSL certificateand select the certificate from your PC.If the certificate is locked, thePassphrasefield appears.In thePassphrasefield, enter the password for the certificate and clickUnlock.If the password is correct, more information about the certificate appears such as validity and subject.If the password is incorrect, you receive an error message.Ensure that the public URL is correct.Note:If the public URL is incorrect, docks may not be able to establish a connection. Confirming saves your new addresses, restarts the server, and logs out all users.ClickConfirm.TheTest connectionpage informs you how many docks are connected, how many of those require reconfiguration, and how many are ready for reconfiguration.If not all docks requiring reconfiguration pass the test, the docks retain the previous settings and you need to either manually reconfigure them or run the migration wizard again.If no docks passed the test, an error message appears. You must review your configuration settings and ensure that they are valid.Note:Reconfiguration can take some time. During the process, the docks will restart and all users will be logged out.To start reconfiguration, clickStart.Note:During the process, you cannot close the window or refresh the page. If the process is interrupted, any remaining docks will not be reconfigured and you will have to relaunch the migration wizard to complete the process.Once the process is complete, the message appears informing you how many docks were successfully reconfigured. If any docks failed to receive the new configuration, you can update them later by either running the migration wizard again once the docks are connected or by reconfiguring them manually. For more information, seeConfiguring Listen and Public Addresses of VideoManager.ClickFinish.Postrequisites:Once all docks are reconfigured to point to the new listen address/public address, remove access control key authenticated devices from the original server port. Creating and Configuring Backup DatabasesVideoManager offers a backup database service to help prevent the loss of crucial files in the event of an IT failure. A backup contains database metadata, such as the audit log, custom configurations, and descriptions of media files, incidents, and exports. These backups can be used by Motorola Solutions to restore an administrator's instance of VideoManager.The backup function only backs up the system state and does not back up the contents of the media, exports or reports filespaces.Note:Backups should be regularly transferred to a secure location offsite.Creating Backup DatabasesYou can initiate an immediate backup, which captures the state of VideoManager at the time when the immediate backup was created.Note:Only users with theInitiate immediate database backuppermission can initiate the backup of the database.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theBackup Databasessection.ClickBackup now.The backup is sent to the location that has been configured in theStoragesection. For more information, seePerforming File Spaces Actions.Configuring Backup DatabasesYou can configure recurring backups, which run automatically every hour.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theBackup Databasessection.SetEnabled automatic database backupstoOn.This action enables you to configure more settings relating to automatic backups.Enter the number of most recent daily and hourly backups that should be retained.A daily backup is the last hourly backup within a 24-hour window. It is recommended to configure both of these settings.Optional:If you want backups to only occur when there is little or no activity occurring on VideoManager, in order to minimise system load, setAvoid busy timestoOn.ClickSave settings.The backup is sent to the location that has been configured in theStoragesection. For more information, seePerforming File Spaces Actions.The current backup status, as well as the start and end date of the backup, are displayed at the bottom of the pane. Importing and Deleting LicencesTheLicencespane enables you to licence features of VideoManager, which would otherwise be inaccessible. It also allows you to view the licences you have already bought, the expiry dates of the licences, and the number of devices which your licences support.Importing LicencesProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theLicencessection.ClickImport licence.ClickChoose file.Note:You should select the licence provided to you by Motorola Solutions. For more information, contact Motorola Solutions Support.The maximum size of the licence can be 1 MB.In theActivation keyfield, enter the key provided by Motorola Solutions in the licence email.Note:If the key entered here does not match the key set by Motorola Solutions, the licence will not work.ClickImport.If successful, the licence appears asValid. All licences are on and enabled by default once imported.Deleting LicencesAn imported licence usually has an expiry date. A warning will appear on VideoManager when a licence is one week away from expiration. When the licence expires, VideoManager restarts. It can be necessary to delete a licence after it expired.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theLicencessection.ClickDelete licence.If the licence is still valid, VideoManager presents a list of all the features which will stop working when the licence is deleted.ClickTick to confirm.ClickYes.Note:If the licence was still valid at the time of deletion, all VideoManager features associated with it immediately stop working. Advanced Settings ConfigurationThe advanced settings file allows you to configure specialised features, for a demonstration or tutorials. All edits to the file can be done from theAdvanced Settingssection of theSystempane, in theAdmintab.Note:The configuration should only be done if you have been given explicit permission from Motorola Solutions Support, and should not be attempted otherwise. Setting the System Time Zone of VideoManagerFor on-premises instances, by default, theSystem Time Zoneis the time zone of the operating system on which users are accessing VideoManager. For cloud instances, by default,System Time Zoneis the time zone of the server on which VideoManager is being hosted.The system time zone of VideoManager affects a number of functions, including:The start and end times for reports.When scheduled reports run.The interpretation of bandwidth rules, which apply to specific times or days.The system time zone of VideoManager does not necessarily dictate video metadata, which is determined by the time zone of the device on which the video was recorded, which is itself determined by the following:The time zone of the device profile.For more information, seeDevice Profiles.If the time zone of the device profile is left as the default, the time zone of a video is determined by the time zone of the dock to which the device is docked.For more information, seePerforming Dock Actions.If the time zone of the dock is left as the default, the time zone of a video is determined by the system time zone of VideoManager.Note:The system time zone can be changed to be independent of the host server time zone by users with the permission to editSystem time zone.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theSystem Time Zonesection.From theTime zonedrop-down list, select the system time zone of VideoManager.ClickSave settings. Exporting and Importing the Configuration of VideoManagerExporting or importing the configuration of VideoManager can be necessary if, for example, VideoManager has been configured on a test server, and the results should be imported into a live, working version.Exporting a System ConfigurationProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theImport/Export System Configsection.Optional:From theReplace this configuration on target systemdrop-down list, select which policies should be added to the system configuration file. To add a set of information to the exported configuration, click.Note:Imported policies overwrite previously existing policies on VideoManager.The options are as follows:By clickingPassword complexity, the password complexity policy is exported.By clickingDeletion policy, the deletion policy is exported.Optional:From theMerge this configuration with target systemdrop-down list, select which roles, fields, and profiles should be added to the system configuration file. To add a set of information to the exported configuration, click.Note:If any of the imported roles, fields, or profiles from the original VideoManager have the same names as previously existing roles, fields or profiles on the new instance of VideoManager, the latter will be overwritten.The options are as follows:By clickingShareable device keys, the access control keys are exported.By clickingRoles, roles are exported.By clickingImport profiles, import profiles are exported.By clickingExport profiles, export profiles are exported.By clickingUser defined fields, incident fields, media fields, media playback reason fields, incident access reason field, and incident share reason fields are exported.By clickingDevice profiles, device profiles are exported.By clickingNetwork profiles, network profiles are exported.ClickSave settings.ClickExport system config.The exported configuration is downloaded to the default download location of your PC.Importing a System ConfigurationProcedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.Click theImport/Export System Configsection.ClickImport system config.Select the previously downloaded system configuration and clickConfirm. Viewing Legal InformationYou can view information about VideoManager related to legality and the terms of service.Procedure:Navigate to theAdmintab.Select theSystempane.ClickAbout.You can view the following fields:Product nameis the name of the system.Product versionis the version number of the system.Copyright noticedescribes who has copyrighted the system, and for how long.View licence agreement– By clickingView, you can check the licence agreement, which will have already been agreed to when initially logging on to the system.
description: This section covers the configuration of deletion policies within the Motorola system, which manage the automatic deletion of media, incidents, exports, and audit logs to optimize storage space. Key features include setting retention periods based on recording or offload dates, suspending deletion for exported media, and categorizing media with specific retention settings. Users can navigate through the Admin tab to access the System pane and configure these policies effectively.
